headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Petroleum Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.I would now like to tu
componenttext:
Welcome to the Marathon Petroleum Corporation Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to Lisa Wilson, Director of Investor Relations. Ms. Wilson, please go ahead.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Webcast and Conference Call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found at our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab.On the call
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Webcast and Conference Call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found at our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab.
On the call today are Gary Heminger, President and CEO; Tim Griffith, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and other members of MPC's executive team.
We invite you to read the safe harbor statements on Slide 2. As a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the call and during the question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from what we expect today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ are included there as well as in our filings with the SEC.
Now, I will turn the call over to Gary Heminger for opening remarks and highlights. Gary?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lisa, and good morning to everyone. Before I begin, I want to take the opportunity to introduce Lisa Wilson, our new Director of Investor Relations. Lisa is replacing Geri Ewing who is transferring to our finance department. Lisa has nearly 25 yea
componenttext:
Thanks, Lisa, and good morning to everyone. Before I begin, I want to take the opportunity to introduce Lisa Wilson, our new Director of Investor Relations. Lisa is replacing Geri Ewing who is transferring to our finance department. Lisa has nearly 25 years of experience for the company, with most recently our director financial services and insurance.
We are pleased to report fourth quarter 2015 earnings of $187 million, ending a strong year with $2.85 billion in earnings. These results include a $370 million pretax charge to value our inventory at lower cost to market. We remained very encouraged by the environment for U.S. refiners and we're pleased to see resilient supported by attractive product price realizations and continued strong gasoline demand in the fourth quarter. We believe lower prices at the pump will remain constructive for retail demand as we move through 2016.
Crude oil prices continued to see pressure with the lifting of the Iranian sanctions, resiliency of domestic producers and sentiment in the market. Crude differentials have been and will likely remain volatile.
WTI has traded at parity, and in fact, higher than Brent recently, and we expect this trading pattern could continue in the near term. However, longer-term, we believe it will revert back to a differential based on product quality and transportation cost between the grades.
We believe more favorable sweet sour spread will continue to exist and had benefit MPC's complex refinery configuration in the Midwest and Gulf Coast.
In December, the South Texas Extension Pipeline, or SAX, came online provided increased logistics flexibility in crude optionality, allowing us to more cost-effectively move Bakken and Canadian crudes into our Midwest refineries.
SAX allows MPC to access additional advantage crudes and adjust our slate based on the best economics. Speedway continued its solid performance during the fourth quarter, finishing the year with nearly $1 billion of EBITDA.
I want to recognize Tony Kenney and his team's efforts in completing the planned conversions of our East Coast and Southeast retail locations to the Speedway brand well ahead of schedule. The team's aggressive execution strategy facilitated the realization of these synergies from these locations much sooner than anticipated and beyond our original projections.
The acquisition of these high-quality assets has been a tremendous value driver and has exceeded our expectations in virtually every area. In addition to our strong financial and operational results in 2015, we also made tremendous progress in our strategic objectives of growing the more stable cash flow segments of our business and enhancing our refining margins. An example of enhancing our refining margins is a condensate split that came online in 2015 at our refinery, which allows the refinery to process condensate produced in the region and thus improve its realized margins. 
Completion of the MPLX and MarkWest merger in early December was a significant accomplishment in the company strategy. Through this combination, we have created a diversified, large-cap MLP that positions the partnership as a midstream leader with compelling long-term growth opportunities.
We continued to believe MPLs have create substantial value to MPC shareholders through its general partner interest and associated incentive distribution rights and we are eager to develop the numerous commercial synergies available to the combined partnership.
I would also like to comment on our long-term commitment to returning capital to shareholders. Through share buyback programs and dividends, we returned a total of $1.6 billion of capital to shareholders in 2015, included $362 million during the fourth quarter.
Delivering attractive capital returns to our shareholders continues to be an instrumental part of our strategy. To year end 2015, we have purchased over $7 billion of MPC common stock or approximately 28% of the shares that were outstanding when we became a standalone company. Our approach for the allocation of capital continues to be balanced and long-term in nature, taking into consideration the requirements of the business, returns to our shareholders and our overall capital structure.
As a result, we may increase or decrease the amount of share repurchase activity in any given year based on these variables. Through disciplined strategic investments in our business, and returning capital to shareholders, we remained focused on the long-term value proposition for our investors. This discipline and prudent approach carries over to our sponsorship of MPLX. As we evaluate the continued decline in commodity prices, and the market's increasing belief that these price conditions will persist for some period of time, MPLX' producer customers are directly impacted. While MPLX' producers are in some of the best areas and continues to manage their capital and production clients very carefully, changes in volume growth will continue to impact the income growth for the partnership. At the same time, valuations within the MLP space, including MPLX, had been severely impacted, resulting in yield levels that are substantially higher than what we anticipated at the time of the merger, even with the strong support we expect to continue to make available through the partnership. These factors contributed to MPLX' decision to provide new distribution growth guidance.
Current market [indiscernible] to an expected 12% to 15% distribution growth rate for 2016, revised from prior 25%. Even with this change, MPLX' distribution growth continues to be among the highest for large-cap diversified MLPs. We are asked at our Investor Day meeting that there's a tipping point as to when higher growth guidance will not make sense. I share then that if conditions did not improve in MPLX' valuation and resulting yield, we would likely revisit the growth outlook for the partnership. 
Based on the continued deterioration we have seen since then, we have reached that point and this change in distribution growth is necessary. The commodity and equity market conditions we are now experiencing could be temporary and we will assess the growth path for 2017 later this year, providing guidance around the partnership's distribution growth capabilities at that time. We will take into consideration the capital allocation of these both MPC and MPLX but expect to continue providing support to the partnership as it navigates through this challenging environment.
In support of MPLX' 2016 growth plans, MPC offered to contribute its marine Business from MPLX at what we believe will be supported value and we anticipate receiving MPLX equity in exchange for these assets. The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter of 2016, pending requisite approvals.
This drop-down of additional logistics assets through the partnership further diversifies its high-quality earnings stream and underscores our flexibility -- our sponsorship at MPLX.
MPC is focused on strengthening the earnings power of all aspects of its business, with the expanded margin enhancing investments across the enterprise. We recently announced plans to invest $2 billion to the Galveston Bay refinery over the next 5 years and investment program referred to as the South Texas Asset Repositioning program, or STAR. The investments planned as part of the STAR program, of which approximately $150 million will be spent in 2016, are intended to increase production of higher value products and improve the facility's reliability as well as increase processing capacity. These high return investments will fully integrate our Galveston Bay refinery with our Texas City refinery, making it the second-largest refinery in the U.S.
We expect a rapid payback on the states investment plan for the STAR program, including an earning stream in 2016. By using the flexibility inherent in our refining system and optimizing our logistics and transportation network, we are able to react quickly to changing crude oil and refined product market conditions, maximizing our profitability.
In addition, as our downstream earnings demonstrate, our business produces strong results in a wide variety of commodity price environments. We remained optimistic on the long-term prospects for our business and continued to believe returns will be compelling, including our sponsorship and GP interest in MPLX.
With that, let me turn the call over to Tim to walk through the financial results for the fourth quarter. Tim?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings growth on an absolute and tertiary basis for the fourth quarter and full-year of 2015. Earnings $187 million or $0.35 per diluted share during the fourth quarter compared to $798 million or $1.43 diluted share in la
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings growth on an absolute and tertiary basis for the fourth quarter and full-year of 2015. Earnings $187 million or $0.35 per diluted share during the fourth quarter compared to $798 million or $1.43 diluted share in last year's fourth quarter.
For the full year 2015, our earnings were almost $2.9 billion or $5.26 per diluted share compared to 2014 earnings of $2.5 billion or $4.39 per diluted share.
Chart on Slide 5 shows, by segment, the change in earnings from the fourth quarter last year to the fourth quarter of 2015. As Gary mentioned, the earnings were impacted during the quarter by a $370 million accrued tax charge to adjusted inventories to market values. $345 million of this charge is included in the Refining & Marketing segment and $25 million is reflected in [indiscernible] segment.
After adjusting for the charge, earnings were down $374 million versus fourth quarter last year, largely attributable to our refining market -- Refining & Marketing and Speedway segments, partially offset by lower income taxes associated with the lower earnings. I'll talk about each of these segments and the changes compared to the prior period shortly.
Results for the quarter also included income from MarkWest since the December 4 merger date with MPLX, which is included in the renamed midstream segment, previously known as Pipeline Transportation, and we'll continue to consolidate MPLX for reporting purposes.
Turning to Slide 6, Refining & Marketing segment income from operations was $207 million in the fourth quarter compared to just over $1 billion for the fourth quarter of last year. The decrease was primarily due to less favorable crude oil and feedstock acquisition costs relative to our market indicators, largely resulting from narrow crude differentials and lower dollar-based refinery volumetric gains resulting from overall lower refined product prices.
In addition, the fourth quarter of 2015 reflected an unfavorable LIFO accounting effect of approximately $45 million as compared to a favorable effect of approximately $240 million in the fourth quarter of last year. All these unfavorable impacts are included in the $784 million other gross margin step on the slide.
In addition, segment results were negatively impacted in the quarter by the $345 million LCM charge I just mentioned, which is broken out separately here. The unfavorable impact on segment income were partially offset by higher LLS spreads in Chicago and the Gulf coast, favorable market structure and improvement in the sweet/sour differential in the quarter, along with slightly higher sour runs.
The blended crack was 6 65 per barrel in the fourth quarter 2015 compared to 5 42 per barrel in the fourth quarter of '14. You may recall the crack spreads we provided in our market metrics on our website are product and crude prices. The price we actually paid for crude on the other hand is established over the calendar month that we processed the crude, but takes no account the market structure. The contango effect is reflected $192 million favorable difference reflected as market structure on the walk and relates to this difference between the top crude prices we used for market metrics in the actual crude acquisition cost.
Slide 7 provides the drivers for the change in Refining & Marketing segment income on a year-over-year basis. Refining & Marketing segment income from operations is nearly $4.2 billion for the full year of 2015 compared to $3.6 billion in 2014. The LLS 6-3-2-1 blended crack spread had a $1.3 billion favorable impact on full-year earnings, the Chicago cracks, $1.11 per barrel better than '15 and Gulf Coast cracks $1.88 per barrel higher.
Based on our estimated mix of 38% Chicago and 62% Gulf Coast, which resulted in the blended crack spread of $9.70 per barrel or about $1.59 better than 2014. In addition, favorable market structure, more favorable product price realizations and lower direct operating costs driven primarily by lower turnaround activity and lower purchase energy cost, had positive impacts on earnings year-over-year. This positive impacts on earnings were partially offset by less favorable crude oil and feedstock acquisition costs relative to our market indicators, largely resulting from narrow crude differentials and lower refinery volumetric gains.
In addition, the LCM and LIFO accounting impacts I described earlier also impacted 2015 full-year earnings. The impact of more favorable product price realizations, less favorable crude oil and feedstock acquisition costs relative to market indicators, lower volumetric gains and the unfavorable LIFO impact are all reflected in the $1.5 billion of other gross margin in the graph.
Other Refining & Marketing segments net expenses increased $396 million compared to 2014 as a result of a number of items, including higher terminal and transportation cost and lower equity affiliated income.
Slide 8 shows the Speedway segment earnings both for the fourth quarter and full-year. Speedway's income from operations was $135 million in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to fourth quarter 2014 record quarterly income of $273 million. Lower gasoline and distillate margins were significant changes in the quarter-over-quarter comparison, decreasing segment income by $93 million. Gasoline and distillate margins averaged 18.23 cents per gallon in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to 24.51 cents in the fourth quarter of 2014. The non-cash LCM charge of $25 million and higher operating expenses also had negative impacts on segment income compared to the fourth quarter of 2014.
These unfavorable impact in the income were partially offset by higher merchandise margin, which increased from $324 million in the fourth quarter of 2014 to $340 million in the fourth quarter of 2015. The $16 million is a result of higher overall merchandise sales in addition to higher margins on those sales.
On a same-store basis, gasoline sales volumes were essentially flat, decreasing 3 tenths of a percent and merchandise sales, excluding cigarettes, decreased 2.7% in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared with 2014. Speedway same-store gasoline sales growth was lower than estimated U.S. demand growth, as we continue to strive to optimize total gasoline contribution between volume and margin to ensure fuel margins remain adequate.
In January 2016, we've seen a slight increase in demand within approximately 1% increase in same-store gasoline sales volume versus the prior year, impacted to some extent by the winter storms in the east in the last few weeks.
Speedway's income from operations for full-year 2015 was $673 million compared with $544 million for 2014. Results for 2015 include a full year of income from the operations acquired from Hess, we have 2014 results only include income form those locations in the fourth quarter.
Gasoline and distillate margins increased $401 million from 2014, primarily due to higher volumes resulting from additional locations acquired as well as higher margins. Gasoline and distillate margins were 18.23 cents per gallon in 2015 compared to 17.75 cents per gallon in 2014.
Speedway's merchandise margin increased $393 million to $1.4 billion in 2015, primarily due to the increase in the number of locations as well as higher margins on the merchandise sold. Partially offsetting increases in Speedway income from operations for the year were higher operating expenses, primarily attributed to increasing in the number of stores.
Turning to Slide 9. As I mentioned, we changed the name of the segment this quarter, instead of a Pipeline Transportation segment, we now report a midstream segment, which continues to include 100% of MPLX' results, including income contributed by MarkWest since the December 4 merger. The addition of MarkWest is the only change to what's included in this segment.
Midstream segment income was $71 million and $289 million for the fourth quarter and full-year 2015 compared with $58 million and $280 million for the comparable period in 2014. The decrease for the quarter was primarily due to the inclusion of MarkWest from the December 4 merger date and higher income from our pipeline affiliates, partially offset by $26 million of transaction costs associated with the merger.
The increase for the full year was primarily due to the MarkWest merger and higher transportation revenue resulting from higher average pipeline tariff rates. These favorable impacts were partially offset by $30 million of transaction costs associated with the merger and higher pipeline operating expenses.
Slide 10 presents the significant drivers of changes in our cash flow for the fourth quarter of 2015. At December 31, our cash balance was $1.1 billion. Operating cash flow before changes to working capital was $1.2 billion source of cash. The $340 million use of working capital, noted on the slide, primarily relates to a $693 million decrease in accounts payable and accrued liabilities, partially offset by a $361 million decrease in accounts receivable. The decrease in accounts payable and accounts receivable were primarily due to the significant drop in crude and refined product prices during the quarter.
We completed a $1.5 billion public debt offering during the quarter, of which a little more than half was used to extinguish our obligation for the March 2016 3.5% notes. These new notes, net of some pay down on MPLX revolver resulted in the $655 million net source of financing cash shown in long term that year.
Cash flow is also impacted by the approximately $1.2 billion paid to former MarkWest unitholders as part of the transaction consideration during the quarter, which is shown separately on the graph.
As Gary highlighted, we continued delivering our commitment to balance investments in the business with return of capital to our shareholders. Returned a total of $362 million to shareholders in the fourth quarter, bringing the total for the year to $1.6 billion.
Turning to Slide 11. In the fourth quarter, we paid a $0.32 per share dividend, representing a 28% increase over the dividend paid during the same quarter last year. We've increased our dividend 5x since becoming a stand-alone company in mid-2011, resulting in a 29.5% compound annual growth rate in dividend. Our continued focus on growing regular quarterly dividend demonstrates our ongoing commitment to our shareholders to share in the success of the business, and we're pleased to affirm that commitment with a $0.32 per share dividend declared earlier this week.
Slide 12 provides an overview of our capitalization as of the end of the year. With just under $12 billion of total consolidated debt reflects the $6.7 billion of debt at MPC, plus the $5.3 billion of debt at MPLX, including the $4.1 billion of MarkWest notes assumed in the transaction.
Total debt to book capitalization was about 38% and represented a manageable 1.9x last 12 months consolidated EBITDA. Operating cash flow for the quarter was about $1.2 billion before reflecting the $342 million use of cash for working capital in the quarter.
Slide 13 provides a breakdown by segment of our 2015 capital expenditures and investments, excluding MPLX' acquisition of MarkWest, along with the revised capital plan for 2016.
In light of the challenging commodity price environment that Gary talked about, our focus will be to aggressively manage CapEx spending. As part of this process, MPLX lowered its 2016 capital plan from an estimated $1.7 billion to a range of $1 billion to $1.5 billion. The midpoint of the revised range represents a decrease of approximately $450 million from the previous forecast.
Throughout the course of '16, we'll continue to evaluate our capital program carefully and identify further opportunities to reduce or defer investments where appropriate, given the cash and capital constraints of the business.
Slide 14 provides updated outlook information on key operating metrics for MPC for the first quarter of 2016. We're expecting first quarter throughput volumes of 1.7 million barrels per day, which are lower than fourth quarter 2015 volumes due to more planned maintenance this quarter. Our projected first quarter corporate and other unallocated items are expected to be about $85 million for the first quarter.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Lisa. Lisa?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of focus is going to be on capital allocation, so I'll kick off from that, talk about midstream CapEx, can you give a little bit of guidance as to what of the program And how the program might evolve into '17, for example, if commodity price
componenttext: I think a lot of focus is going to be on capital allocation, so I'll kick off from that, talk about midstream CapEx, can you give a little bit of guidance as to what of the program And how the program might evolve into '17, for example, if commodity prices stay low? And I have a follow-on.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, can you handle that please.
componenttext: Don, can you handle that please.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Ed, this is Don. A majority of the decline in that CapEx forecast is around the money we were going to spend in Utica and Marcellus. So you will recall that our original forecast was around $1.7 billion. And on the legacy MPLX side of the business,
componenttext: Sure. Ed, this is Don. A majority of the decline in that CapEx forecast is around the money we were going to spend in Utica and Marcellus. So you will recall that our original forecast was around $1.7 billion. And on the legacy MPLX side of the business, that money was going to be spent on cornerstone and modest and butane and a couple of those projects that are continuing on. The remainder was with respect to our GMP segment and a lot of that spending is going to be matched consistent with our adjusted just-in-time capital spending program to be able to meet or produce our customer's demand but not to deploy the capital in advance of their demands or their needs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the follow on the still on capital. Folks worry about a recession, people have many different views on that, but you've got -- you revised capital down to 3.7, if you did have a period where the market was stressed and you had to cut CapEx even f
componenttext: And then the follow on the still on capital. Folks worry about a recession, people have many different views on that, but you've got -- you revised capital down to 3.7, if you did have a period where the market was stressed and you had to cut CapEx even further, maybe just talk a little bit through the flexibility that you have in the capital program to manage a downturn?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In fact, we're analyzing that right now, Ed. We have several areas where we can manage our capital. And that's the prudent thing we're doing here. While I know it's difficult to lower the capital guidance and lower the distribution growth guidance, we jus
componenttext: In fact, we're analyzing that right now, Ed. We have several areas where we can manage our capital. And that's the prudent thing we're doing here. While I know it's difficult to lower the capital guidance and lower the distribution growth guidance, we just feel it's necessary to make sure we always manage within our means. So we have those opportunities. We can push some of the retail spending out if we had to that we are getting very high returns and really are very pleased with the returns we're getting there. But we're going through that exercise right now and we've already identified the areas where we can be flexible.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that this will be the theme on capital allocation. Gary, the market is fully concerned on the midstream CapEx and MPC's potential carry of MPLX CapEx, potentially the expense of the buyback, given the state of new issuance market. I mean can you f
componenttext: I think that this will be the theme on capital allocation. Gary, the market is fully concerned on the midstream CapEx and MPC's potential carry of MPLX CapEx, potentially the expense of the buyback, given the state of new issuance market. I mean can you further elaborate how far you can go down at MPLX capital spending, I mean given the well of dropped assets?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan, that's -- our first statement here, while the entire MLP market has been under tremendous stress, almost since the day that we announced this transaction, but it was cleared, even with our increase in distribution last week that the market is still
componenttext: Evan, that's -- our first statement here, while the entire MLP market has been under tremendous stress, almost since the day that we announced this transaction, but it was cleared, even with our increase in distribution last week that the market is still under tremendous stress and it's challenge not to recognize that value. So that is why we evolved really retched back our distribution growth, which is certainly part of the capital allocation as we look at it into MPLX. Don just mentioned, how far we have gone, so far it got back to capital of MPLX and in the -- if need be, because you could trim back some more on the MPC and -- excuse me on the MPLX side. What we are clearly going to do, and there's always been part of our core strategy and part of our flexibility is that we will manage to our capital budget if -- whether it's out of refining or there's out of midstream or whether it's out of retail, we will be able to ratchet back to maintain a strong balance sheet.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And how does the consideration of a buyback? I mean given your view of value and sort of relative underperformance of the stock, how does the view of the potentials capital allocation to your buyback way against a potential further reduction of cap
componenttext: Great. And how does the consideration of a buyback? I mean given your view of value and sort of relative underperformance of the stock, how does the view of the potentials capital allocation to your buyback way against a potential further reduction of capital spending, whether it be in refining or midstream?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Tim, you want to take that?
componenttext: Sure. Tim, you want to take that?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Evan. I mean again I think the considerations around the total capital allocation for the enterprise will continue to focus on balance. I think as we suggested even at Investor Day and this morning, the amount of share buybacks that we do at any poi
componenttext: Sure, Evan. I mean again I think the considerations around the total capital allocation for the enterprise will continue to focus on balance. I think as we suggested even at Investor Day and this morning, the amount of share buybacks that we do at any point in time is going to flex depending on the needs of the business. But I think certainly in an environment of capital constraints, what we will revisit with spending, again, I think the intent of the plan for us is that the commitment around return of capital is really a long-term commitment. We won't get too focused in any one particular quarter or one period, but certainly we what we need to look at that across the full scope of the capital allocation of the enterprise.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you walk us through the new guidance from 25% down to 12% to 15%. Is there a way to bridge or quantify how much of the delta comes from different components? For example, how much of it is a change in drop down multiples versus a change in the m
componenttext: Gary, can you walk us through the new guidance from 25% down to 12% to 15%. Is there a way to bridge or quantify how much of the delta comes from different components? For example, how much of it is a change in drop down multiples versus a change in the margin environment of MarkWest or a change in capital spending?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And Neil, I'm going to ask Don and Tim to take this, I'm overseas and I need to change phones here. Can you guys take that?
componenttext: Right. And Neil, I'm going to ask Don and Tim to take this, I'm overseas and I need to change phones here. Can you guys take that?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Neil, this is Don. I guess we were evaluating the full year and there are a number of factors that we considered. Clearly, there is the pressure on volumes, but we're still seeing good volume growth and expect good volume growth in Marcellus and Utic
componenttext: Yes. Neil, this is Don. I guess we were evaluating the full year and there are a number of factors that we considered. Clearly, there is the pressure on volumes, but we're still seeing good volume growth and expect good volume growth in Marcellus and Utica to support our underlying business. We're very confident in the legacy MPLX business or the pipeline business. We're very confident in the steady cash flow of the Marine business that has been offered to MPLX. I would say probably the biggest factor that we have been considering and have been analyzing and evaluating is the yield environment and the pressure that the yield environment puts on growth as we're funding our growth and issuing new units or funding it with debt, that has put -- incremental pressure on that. So I would say that a lot of our decisions and our evaluation has not been based upon the underlying cash flows of the business, but it's really been a function of the way the market has performed since we announced the combination and even since early end of November when we're probably in the 4.5% kind of yield range. We're more than 200 basis points wide of that in just a couple of months time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's very clear, Don. And then, Gary, I'm not sure if you're back on the line, but maybe the team can take it here. As it relates to gasoline, it's the topic that's been top of mind here. Week 1 it felt like we could dismiss it to inventory build
componenttext: Right. That's very clear, Don. And then, Gary, I'm not sure if you're back on the line, but maybe the team can take it here. As it relates to gasoline, it's the topic that's been top of mind here. Week 1 it felt like we could dismiss it to inventory builds due to fog or weather conditions, but we've seen a relentless build in gasoline inventory. so I want you guys to comment in terms of what you're seeing on demand, it sounds like you're up 1% in gasoline same-store sales, so that sounds fine. So why do you think we're seeing that level of inventory build? And how do you think about the gasoline outlook from here?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neil. I'm back online. Sorry, if I'm cut off. As you guys as we said in our conference call, we were surprised to see that, that big of a build and expected it to be reversed due to a lot of operating issues and it hasn't reversed to the area that we
componenttext: Yes, Neil. I'm back online. Sorry, if I'm cut off. As you guys as we said in our conference call, we were surprised to see that, that big of a build and expected it to be reversed due to a lot of operating issues and it hasn't reversed to the area that we thought it would. But the gasoline demand continues to be strong. And when we look at our exports, we average 330,000 barrels per day in the fourth quarter of exports, granted we have a couple of turnarounds here early in the first quarter, but -- that will reduce our number of exports overall, so our total volume and capacity will be down a little bit in the first quarter due to the experts. We see gasoline demand, as Tim stated, up 1%. And we see that continuing on and I think I stated in our Analyst Day meeting that we expect first quarter to be up over first quarter last year due to continued lower price versus same period last year. But gasoline and octane continued to be very strong. Diesel has -- and diesel has picked up a little in comparison to the fourth quarter across our same-store sector and our diesel exports continued to be strong as well. So I will -- Mike Palmer see if has additional comments.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, Gary, the only thing that I would add is that, obviously, this time of year we typically see gasoline builds, especially in PADD 2. And that's what we're seeing now. We're getting ready to go into the turnaround season and part of the build that
componenttext: You know, Gary, the only thing that I would add is that, obviously, this time of year we typically see gasoline builds, especially in PADD 2. And that's what we're seeing now. We're getting ready to go into the turnaround season and part of the build that you see is in order to handle the shortfall that we're going to have been those refineries go down. So that's the only other thing that I would add to your comments.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again on MPLX. I'm curious about the projects that you discussed that had sort of more direct synergies to Marathon itself, the appellation project and so on. Has the timeline for those projects been pushed back?
componenttext: So again on MPLX. I'm curious about the projects that you discussed that had sort of more direct synergies to Marathon itself, the appellation project and so on. Has the timeline for those projects been pushed back?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not at this time, Brad. And when we laid out all those projects in the third and fourth quarter last year, it was always anticipated that these were longer lead projects, and we're continuing to work those very hard. We're in some engineering on a couple
componenttext: Not at this time, Brad. And when we laid out all those projects in the third and fourth quarter last year, it was always anticipated that these were longer lead projects, and we're continuing to work those very hard. We're in some engineering on a couple of those projects, but we do not anticipate at this time to move those out. The alkylation project is very important, very important for the producers, very important for our octane needs and the distribution of octane into the refining system. We're still looking at a very strong interest in a solution in order to be able to move propane either to an East Coast market or move propane down into the Gulf Coast. So those are still continuing along, and those are the 2 biggest synergy projects that we had outlined at the time of the transaction. And both of those, as I say, we're continuing to work on.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, this is Don, I might even add one more comment, particularly on the NGL project. One of the things that we believe is really important is that our producer customers are very much in need of an opportunity to increase there -- the netback on particu
componenttext: Brad, this is Don, I might even add one more comment, particularly on the NGL project. One of the things that we believe is really important is that our producer customers are very much in need of an opportunity to increase there -- the netback on particularly on propane. I mean we've been challenged in terms of getting into a market where they can realize a higher price. And so in our efforts to make sure that we are very sensitive to and focused on our producer customers, we think it's important for us to deliver a project or projects that allow them to get the highest netback they possibly can as quickly as they can. So speed is of the essence in terms of those types of projects.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understood, thanks for that. And then thinking about the refining business, I'm just curious around the crude slate, how things have changed of late, how you're changing what you're running in the context of mediums and heavies appearing to be much
componenttext: Okay. Understood, thanks for that. And then thinking about the refining business, I'm just curious around the crude slate, how things have changed of late, how you're changing what you're running in the context of mediums and heavies appearing to be much more attractive and life is being less so.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike?
componenttext: Mike?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Brad, this is Mike Palmer, yes you did the nail on the head. I think what we're seeing now is when you look at the light sweet domestic production in this country, we think that, that those volumes are coming off and there is tightness. But at the sa
componenttext: Yes. Brad, this is Mike Palmer, yes you did the nail on the head. I think what we're seeing now is when you look at the light sweet domestic production in this country, we think that, that those volumes are coming off and there is tightness. But at the same time, we're seeing very good values on the sour side of the barrel. We're getting a lot of Middle Eastern crudes that are moving into the Gulf. As you know, the Gulf of Mexico itself has grown and continues to grow. And the Canadian sour -- heavy sour crude continues to be a good value. So I think that's exactly what did you see happening is this going to be probably less sweet ones and the shift to us sour.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first question is just follow up on Neil's question on refining fundamentals. Gary, you've been pretty upbeat about your outlook for the full year and obviously you know it's just start of the year in January, it doesn't make a full year, but I'm just
componenttext: The first question is just follow up on Neil's question on refining fundamentals. Gary, you've been pretty upbeat about your outlook for the full year and obviously you know it's just start of the year in January, it doesn't make a full year, but I'm just curious if what we've seen thus far in any way reduces your conviction and the full-year refining outlook? Or if you still think refining margins should be up in '16 over '15, or at least the first half?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Phil, I still think refining should be strong in the first half, as I said earlier by gasoline demand, and driven by octane. The crude oil prices have been quite choppy over the last 3 weeks here, trying to get some momentum and fell soft. But -- tha
componenttext: Yes. Phil, I still think refining should be strong in the first half, as I said earlier by gasoline demand, and driven by octane. The crude oil prices have been quite choppy over the last 3 weeks here, trying to get some momentum and fell soft. But -- that will be a little bit of a driver and the differentials, of course, that goes along with that. But overall demand, again, driven by gasoline, as I said, we've seen some uptick in our diesel over the road demand here so far in the first quarter. But the whole thing clearly in the market right now are the diesel inventories, as Mike Palmer explained, we will look at diesel as we go through the turnaround season within the industry here, already started in the Gulf coast that will move up into PADD II and PAD I starting in the second quarter. Should take care of the overhang and the diesel inventory. But if there's any overhang in the margins, I believe it's going to really be diesel driven.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. The second question is on midstream side, you guys have talked a lot about the levers available to pull, one of which is, of course, the support from the MPC side. And you still have this significant backlog of droppable inventory. So I gues
componenttext: Okay, thanks. The second question is on midstream side, you guys have talked a lot about the levers available to pull, one of which is, of course, the support from the MPC side. And you still have this significant backlog of droppable inventory. So I guess I just want to understand a little bit more how you're thinking about that support mechanism move forward. Are you less certain about wanting to do drops beyond marines at this point, just because of what we were seeing on valuations? Any thoughts around the puts and takes there would be helpful.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Phil. We still have all the flexibility and still have all the interest, in supporting MPLX supporting, the midstream since as we've stated. It's just, as Don outlined, if you look at our yield from the time we announced the transaction, to the date
componenttext: Sure, Phil. We still have all the flexibility and still have all the interest, in supporting MPLX supporting, the midstream since as we've stated. It's just, as Don outlined, if you look at our yield from the time we announced the transaction, to the date of closing until yesterday, and obviously, as we speak today, the yield continues to back up. I've always outlined that we believe that the differentiator in the MLP space is a quality of earnings and the quality of distribution growth. We've highlighted very clearly what that quality is and what the flexibilities we have. However, the market is the indicator on how that's going to be recognized. And today the entire market is under complete stress and the MLPs have backed up in that yield value. So we just think it's prudent at this time not to chase that yield. As I said, the last question I had at the Analyst Day meeting, we will continue to assess but there's no reason to chase the yield that is backing up when we have very, very high quality assets, very high distribution growth that we can make happen. I think it's just best that we settle back, we see how the entire market continues to recognize MLP investments. And as I said in my call, we expect this to be temporary and we expect to be able to revert to our initial distribution growth guidance down the road as market settle down a little bit.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Gary, I have to apologize, first, because I'm going ask a similar question, about the people on the MPLX side. I understand that once you go into a certain construction or that you have certain commitment, so if we based on the commitment and the construction that you already have to date, what is the minimum the CapEx that you have to spend in the MPLX in 2016 and 2017? And also what is the maximum that the MPC support on an annual basis that you're willing to do for that CapEx?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've already outlined, Paul, that on the MPLX side, we dropped the capital back about $450 million from where we had initially approved the capital and I'll let Don and Frank take it from there, if there's any -- how much more room they have, but I
componenttext: Sure. We've already outlined, Paul, that on the MPLX side, we dropped the capital back about $450 million from where we had initially approved the capital and I'll let Don and Frank take it from there, if there's any -- how much more room they have, but I know we have more room to drop back from there. And then I'll have Tim cover the maximum that we would support.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, we have not given specific guidance on sort of what the minimum is. I think that it's important to us to be able to flex in order to be able to meet the increase in volumes that our producers are experiencing and we expect them to experience. And so
componenttext: Paul, we have not given specific guidance on sort of what the minimum is. I think that it's important to us to be able to flex in order to be able to meet the increase in volumes that our producers are experiencing and we expect them to experience. And so we will continue to monitor that. We do have a lot of knobs to pull or levers to pull and we feel like we can manage capital in a very, very efficient way. I mean we expect, for example, that in fractionation or in processing in Utica and Marcellus, we would expect processing to increase by 20% year-over-year and fractionation to increase by 30% year-over-year. So we're expecting good volume increases and we're going to make sure we're managing our capital appropriately to be able to support our producer customers.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Paul, with regard to what's the maximum offer MPC would be prepared to support? Again, the commitment to supporting the partnership as the needs arises there, that support can take a number of different forms. We've highlighted this morning that the m
componenttext: And Paul, with regard to what's the maximum offer MPC would be prepared to support? Again, the commitment to supporting the partnership as the needs arises there, that support can take a number of different forms. We've highlighted this morning that the marine assets are being offered in the partnership at what we believe people will see as a very support multiple, that's a fantastic opportunity. We would be taking back all units for it, limiting the partnership's need to access the equity markets. We've got options with regard to intercompany funding, either in a loan or equity basis, we can look at potential modifications to GP cash flows, we've a host of things that we'll look at. I'm not sure that there's a hard target number in terms of what supports necessary. But we'll continue to look at it and the totality of how the entities will manage each other and MPC is fully supportive of helping the partnership achieve the objective that it's got laid out. So we'll see what the environment holds. As Don indicated and Gary highlighted, what really makes things challenging is the higher yield. I mean, obviously, for the partnership, every -- for every dollar of growth or earnings that goes into it, either on an organic or acquired business, this just that mean more units go out. So we'll have to assess as we move along. The support is there and we will remain flexible with regard to what form make the most sense, given the time and circumstances involved.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Before I ask the second question, Tim, if I may, I would just say that in the market where there's a north [indiscernible] and concern, I think both your shareholder in MPLX and MPC may benefit if the company would come up with a more definitive answer in
componenttext: Before I ask the second question, Tim, if I may, I would just say that in the market where there's a north [indiscernible] and concern, I think both your shareholder in MPLX and MPC may benefit if the company would come up with a more definitive answer in terms of what is the maximum support and also corresponding what is the roadmap that MPLX will be able to self fund the remaining? I think your share price on both side probably we would do much better if you will be able to come up with an answer in more directly for that. My second question, Tim, is for you. When I'm looking at the refining operation, in addition to your manufacturing cost, your turnaround cost, your DTN, as a bottom that there's always a whole sort of a terminal cost and other expand on refining. In the past a couple of years ago that is roughly about $250 million a quarter. In the last several quarter, since running at about in the $350 million to $375 million a quarter. So the question is that, is that a reasonable run rate going forward? And if it is, what may have caused the increase over the last couple of years?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Paul, I think you're short of referring to the elements of other gross margin in terms of how we've look at earnings quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year?On when we do a simple math in the model, if I look at what you've recorded, say gross mar
componenttext:
Well, Paul, I think you're short of referring to the elements of other gross margin in terms of how we've look at earnings quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year?
On when we do a simple math in the model, if I look at what you've recorded, say gross margin in refining, and your throughput and then the core 3 items that you gave after we do that, there's a gap between what you reported as your profit and what model will suggest that GAAP in the past is about $250 million a quarter and in the last several quarter, it's become more like in the $350 million. So I just want to see and I think in the past one, I understand is that that's including this order, the terminal cost and other that is embedded and one is a core business inside the refining?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, there certainly some seasonal factors that enter into, but you're talking about things that would include sort of marketing transportation, other expenses that gets factored in. Again, I wouldn't say there's been any structural change to the s
componenttext: Yes. Again, there certainly some seasonal factors that enter into, but you're talking about things that would include sort of marketing transportation, other expenses that gets factored in. Again, I wouldn't say there's been any structural change to the sort of run rate around the expenses related. A lot of it will move higher based on some unplanned turnaround activity to the extent that comes in We've certainly been impacted and benefit from the lower overall fuel cost related to natural gas. But I would say, as a structural matter, there's nothing that has moved dramatically and the notion that there is roughly $200 million GAAP, again I think it's difficult to predict based on the environment. But with regard to the refining system itself, there's nothing that has structurally change that would impact that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pual, this is Don, I maybe 1 other common or observation. That number, when prices are going up really quickly or prices are coming down really quickly, that number seems to expand or contract. While we've had volatility in the markets, I mean we've had s
componenttext: Pual, this is Don, I maybe 1 other common or observation. That number, when prices are going up really quickly or prices are coming down really quickly, that number seems to expand or contract. While we've had volatility in the markets, I mean we've had sort of relative -- the prices haven't moved -- relatively haven't moved down as fast or up as fast. So we get impacted in there when prices move up really quickly or move down really quickly, we get impacted when commodity prices are moving up really quickly or down quickly. So because we've had a little bit more, even though it's a new price environment, because we've got a little bit more steady action there, I think that's probably was moderated a little bit from some of the previous quarters.

I might also add, we've been making some investments in Bluewater, our joint venture with Crowley. The investment in the blue water vessels, those are some of the things that are sitting up in MPC and not in the MPLX number.

componenttext: Yes. Gary, 1 sure can. The 2 splitters, has a design capacity of 35,000 barrels a day. Compton is 25,000 barrels a day, total of 60,000. That condensate production is holding up well. Our strategy is working well. We did have a little bit of weather issue in January. But really that's all we've seen. So it continues to work for plan.

componenttext: I have 2 questions, if I may. The first 1 is also on MPLX, Gary to you. As taking units from MPLX when MPLX already very, very weak. I think about the saturation of sort of filing on top of existing MPLX shareholders, why not just slow down or defer the marine drop done you would originally going to do and then force more equity to the market. What's probably going to have to be relatively multiple for MPC shareholders?

componenttext: That's certainly is one of the things that we have looked, Doug. And let me turn it over to Tim, as Tim has done all the analysis and what we think the most options are.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think, ultimately, as we scope the distributal cash flow necessary to support growth in the partnership, adding incremental earnings into the partnership is necessary, frankly just to support the distribution growth even as we provided this morn
componenttext:
I mean, I think, ultimately, as we scope the distributal cash flow necessary to support growth in the partnership, adding incremental earnings into the partnership is necessary, frankly just to support the distribution growth even as we provided this morning.
So I defer would put the partnership in a more compromised position and obviously, giving the earnings space recalibrated. I mean in addition to the growth of distributable cash flow, we are also sort of very carefully watching the leverage profile of the partnership and the capacity to take on any incremental debt, there was more limited. So business the, really a necessary step to keep us in the path that was designed and has been shared with the investments community with regard to distribution growth. We've looked at the number of different alternatives and I think adding the Marine business in MPLX, both from a diversification and to support the growth of distributable cash flow is what we think it is mix the most sense at this point.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up to that. Just to clarify what I'm asking, so MPLX right now is trading on about 6.5 multiple of enterprise value based on your guidance you've given today. And there's the legacy drop-down for the industry, the whole MLP argument or
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up to that. Just to clarify what I'm asking, so MPLX right now is trading on about 6.5 multiple of enterprise value based on your guidance you've given today. And there's the legacy drop-down for the industry, the whole MLP argument or case was predicated on an 8 to 10x multiple. So from an MPC standpoint, of MPC shareholder is going to get value regurgitation dropping down in this environment. That's what kind of I'm asking.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think so. I mean again for the entirety of the MLP space to extend the yields have moved up, it's highly likely that multiples who likely would move lower. And that's I think you'll see evidence of that as we get through our transaction here. But
componenttext: Well, we think so. I mean again for the entirety of the MLP space to extend the yields have moved up, it's highly likely that multiples who likely would move lower. And that's I think you'll see evidence of that as we get through our transaction here. But again, we think the long-term value to MPC again relates to the GP and the potential IDR steam and cash flows that have generated from the partnership over a period of time and the growth in distributions made possible by the drop of Marine and other assets from MPC will help to accomplish that over time. Obviously, it slows a bit here, relative to our initial expectation on growth, but we still think the long-term value proposition is very strong.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
