componenttext: And it's going to be the same old subject. Just one on gasoline, Gary. Your same-store sales were negative, very mildly negative in Q4. I was wondering, why you would then think -- how you could square the circle between being relatively optimistic on demand against what looks like quite a weak number, actually, to end the year. Additionally, could just repeat the point about you think the gasoline inventory's being built here, specifically with a view to a big turnaround season about to come? Because it does seem that we are in turnaround season. And then just to hurry things up, I'll tell you the follow-up is totally separate. Do you have a CapEx, a longer-term CapEx guidance for MPLX and MarkWest, given the changes since the Analyst Meeting?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, on [indiscernible] demand, I'll have Tony cover it in more detail, but let me remind everyone that one of the -- a same-store calculation really takes into account 2 things: overall demand, but overall posture and how we're pricing into the marketpl
componenttext: Okay, on [indiscernible] demand, I'll have Tony cover it in more detail, but let me remind everyone that one of the -- a same-store calculation really takes into account 2 things: overall demand, but overall posture and how we're pricing into the marketplace. And as Tim had in his script, we are always going to optimize and maximize what we believe to be the pricing posture in order to be able to get adequate returns within the Speedway space. And Tony, I'll turn it over to you that -- I believe that's exactly how you operate it. So you want to make a few comments?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Gary, sure will. And you're exactly right. There's a lot of factors, Paul, that go into what really determines our same-store calculation. Speedway's on a growth profile and we're continuing to add new stores, as one example. And some of the opportun
componenttext: Yes. Gary, sure will. And you're exactly right. There's a lot of factors, Paul, that go into what really determines our same-store calculation. Speedway's on a growth profile and we're continuing to add new stores, as one example. And some of the opportunity is to move volume to our new stores. So overall for the quarter, if you look at Speedway's total light-product volume, we're actually up in total gallons. But when you do it on a true same-store basis, because of a lot of variables, one being the movement of volume, other factors within the PADD that we're seeing, as well as what Gary talked about in terms of the balance between volume and margin that we take going forward.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So you've got some pricing power, which gives you the knowledge that demand is pretty good?
componenttext: Got it. So you've got some pricing power, which gives you the knowledge that demand is pretty good?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And the other thing, Paul, we've recognized here in January, early part of January, the numbers Tim stated in his script were up 1.1%, I believe, so far this month, but we were up higher than that in the first half of the month. And very strong sam
componenttext: Right. And the other thing, Paul, we've recognized here in January, early part of January, the numbers Tim stated in his script were up 1.1%, I believe, so far this month, but we were up higher than that in the first half of the month. And very strong same-store month-on-month. But then the bump in crude prices and the quick response to the Street cost you some volume. And when you're one of the leaders in the market, that's what happens. So we still continue to be very bullish on gasoline demand going into the second part of the year. Don, you want to take the question on the capital? And then I'll follow up with a little bit more on the MPLX guidance.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've not provided incremental outlook on capital spending, I guess. I would say it this way, Paul, the resource exists, we're confident it does. Our producer customers are in what we believe to be very good regions and plays. The projects exist, an
componenttext: Sure. We've not provided incremental outlook on capital spending, I guess. I would say it this way, Paul, the resource exists, we're confident it does. Our producer customers are in what we believe to be very good regions and plays. The projects exist, and what we're really doing is we're managing the completion of projects to coincide with the volumes that our producer customers are producing. And so we believe that the projects and the revenue opportunities are there. It is likely that some of those may get stretched a bit, and we will match our capital plan to deal with the potential stretching in the volumes. But we're very confident in our producer customers and the resource and their ability to -- long-term, to deliver those volumes.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: No, just thinking, I mean, should we just cut some of the long-term assumptions based on what you said, and assume that even '16 will be a relatively high year? Post the cut, it's still high relative to the future?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Paul, to that point -- and I know there are a number of questions that we had throughout this call. We reduced our guidance on this call and, as I stated, we've decided at this time to suspend talking about guidance beyond '16. And I -- we just think
componenttext: And Paul, to that point -- and I know there are a number of questions that we had throughout this call. We reduced our guidance on this call and, as I stated, we've decided at this time to suspend talking about guidance beyond '16. And I -- we just think that is the prudent thing to do. As we looked at the overall business, we've been very clear; we have a temporary pullback here. I expect, and my entire team expects, that this is temporary. As Don just stated, if crude prices rebound like we anticipate they will in the second half of this year, that could lead to volume growth, that could lead to producers being more -- or being quicker to return into the -- into their producing regions, especially in the Utica and Marcellus. That is very important to our Midstream. But I want to temper any concerns about going past '16 because it's just important that we take care of the work at hand here. And then we'll look at what happens beyond '16. Again, I think prices will recover in the second half, and we'll see where we go from there. But there's no reason to get into a discussion beyond '16 at this time. And Lisa, I'll turn it back to you.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Marathon Petroleum Corporation. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I'll now turn the call over t
componenttext:
Welcome to the First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Marathon Petroleum Corporation. My name is Katie, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I'll now turn the call over to Lisa Wilson, Director of Investor Relations. Ms. Wilson, please go ahead.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's first quarter 2016 earnings webcast and conference call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab.O
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's first quarter 2016 earnings webcast and conference call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab.
On the call today are Gary Heminger, President and CEO; Tim Griffith, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and other members of MPC executive team.
We invite you to read the safe harbor statements on Slide 2. It's a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the call and during the question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from what we expect today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ are included there as well as in our filings with the SEC.
Now, I will turn the call over to Gary Heminger for opening remarks and highlights.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and can you please turn to Slide 3.Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings of $1 million which included charges of $0.06 per diluted share related to a goodwill impairment recorded by our consolidated subsidiary, FPLS, and a l
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and can you please turn to Slide 3.
Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings of $1 million which included charges of $0.06 per diluted share related to a goodwill impairment recorded by our consolidated subsidiary, FPLS, and a lower cost to market inventory charge. The lower earnings this quarter were largely attributable to weak crack spreads, especially in the first 2 months of the quarter as well as high turnaround activity.
We completed significant turnaround activity at the Robinson and Galveston Bay refineries ahead of schedule and under budget. As part of these turnarounds, we commissioned the light crude upgrade project at our Robinson refinery to increase light crude processing and overall crude capacity. This upgrade will improve the refiner's flexibility to optimize its crude slate and product yields in a variety of market conditions.
We also implemented additional process improvements and synergy projects at our Galveston Bay refinery in Texas City, and an ongoing initiative to enhance margins at that complex. Even with the challenging market conditions at the first 2 months of the year, we remain encouraged by the strengthening of crack spreads late in the quarter as gasoline inventories decline and refiners responded to market conditions. In addition, we're also encouraged by the supply and price competitiveness of sour crude oil as we enter into the summer asphalt season. Heavy Canadian crude oil is still growing and it's attractive both for our Midwest and U.S. Gulf Coast refineries. Medium sour crude also looks very promising. U.S. Gulf of Mexico sour production is growing, and we are seeing more sour cargo opportunities than we have for some time as OPEC competes for market share.
SEC can capitalize on these opportunities since we can process even the very heavy high asset and high salted crude oil at both our Galveston Bay and Garyville refineries.
We are also well positioned to take advantage of the expected strength in gasoline demand given our high gasoline yield and pure leading alkylation every form of capacity.
We reported strong financial results from our Speedway and Midstream segments, which underscores the value of our ongoing strategic objective through growing the core stable cash flow segments of our business.
Speedway continued its exceptional performance of the first quarter. In addition to higher light product sales volumes, Speedway's merchandise margins increased in the quarter, reflecting progress towards our goal to generate 2/3 of our profitability for merchandise sales. This approximates the earnings contributions of merchandise sales prior to the acquisition of the East Coast and Southeast locations after the end of September 2014. We are focusing on the significant marketing enhancement opportunities at our recently converted retail locations, further optimizing the value of these assets and building out the earnings power of the entire Speedway business.
We're also pleased with our Midstream segment, including MPLX's financial and operational results this quarter. MPLX completed several key operational projects this quarter while generating strong distributable cash flow to the partnership. Despite the challenging environment for midstream MLPs, we've remained enthusiastic about the quality of the partnership's gathering and processing assets and the diversified customer base they support, particularly at prolific Marcellus and Utica Shale regions. We believe that partnership is very well positioned to take advantage of the continued volume growth as NGL prices improve. Over 1/3 of the total U.S. gas rigs currently in service are in the rich and dry areas, where MPLX operates and enjoys acreage dedications. 
Over the last year, the partnership commissioned almost 1.5 billion cubic feet per day of processing capacity to support its customers growth plans. This year, MPLX anticipates these processing facilities in the Marcellus and Utica to average approximately 80% utilization as expect this overall process best clients in this region to increase by approximately 15%, a normal increase in light of the current commodity environment.
At the end of the quarter, we completed the contribution of our inland marine business to MPLX S, added support evaluation in exchange for additional and MPLX equity. Our near-term support of the partnership in this challenging environment for MLPs is intended to contribute to the long-term value MPLX creates for our shareholders through our limited partner and general partner distributions, drop-down process and the overall value of our equity interest in MPLX. 
We continue to believe the addition of the MarkWest business will be a powerful value driver for MPC and its shareholders over the long term. We will continue our disciplined investment strategy across all segments of the business, balancing value enhancing investments with returning capital to shareholders over the long term. We also remain committed to strong liquidity in an investment-grade credit profile through all cycles. 
In the first quarter, we returned $244 million of capital to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases and announced a significant reduction of nearly 30% of our 2016 capital expenditure plan.
MPLX announced yesterday its $1 billion private placement of convertible preferred securities with third party investors. The partnership elected to take advantage of very strong investor interest in convertible preferred securities by privately placing $1 billion with a select group of investors. Originally contemplated as a transaction with MPC, the private placement provides an attractive funding source for the partnership while preserving MPC's capital and financial flexibility.
The combination of some opportunistic AGM issuance in the first quarter, combined with the supplier placement, provides for the partnership's funding needs for the remainder of 2016 and into 2017. Therefore, enabling MPLX to continue its execution of attractive organic growth projects that will contribute to distributable cash flow and long-term value for the partnership. The transaction is expected to close in early may.
Marathon is well positioned as market conditions improve. In addition to our financial strength, we have a sustained competitive advantage from our refining system, premiere retail assets and enhanced logistics and storage network and the addition of the MarkWest assets to MPLX. We remain bullish about the prospects for the enterprise as we go forward this year and beyond. 
And with that, let me turn the call over to Tim, who will walk through the financial results for the quarter.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings on both an absolute and per-share basis. MPC had $1 million of earnings for the first quarter 2016 compared to $891 million in the first quarter of last year. As Gary mentioned, first quarter earnings included charg
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings on both an absolute and per-share basis. MPC had $1 million of earnings for the first quarter 2016 compared to $891 million in the first quarter of last year. As Gary mentioned, first quarter earnings included charges of $0.06 per diluted share to impair a portion of the goodwill recorded in connection with the acquisition of MarkWest as well as a lower cost to market inventory charge. The impact of the goodwill impairment charge on diluted earnings per share only includes the impact of our 21% equity interest in MPLX.
The chart on Slide 5 shows by segment the changes in earnings from the first quarter of last year. The primary drivers for the change were the $1.4 billion decrease in refining and marketing income and the $129 million goodwill impairment charge, partially offset by lower income taxes and higher income from our Midstream segment, which reflects the full -- first full quarter of results from the combination of MPLX and MarkWest.
Turning to Slide 6. Our refining and marketing segment reported a $62 million loss in the first quarter of 2016 compared to the income from operations of $1.3 billion in the same quarter last year. The decrease was primarily due to weaker crack spreads in both Chicago and Gulf Coast, higher cost related to the turnaround activity at Robinson and Galveston bay, and a narrower LLS/WTI differential. In addition, we have less favorable crude oil and feedstock acquisition costs relative to our market indicators resulting from narrower crude differentials, which is included in the $199 million of other gross margin negative impacts highlighted on the slide.
The lower blended crack spreads had a negative impact on earnings of approximately $869 million. The blended crack spread was over $5 per barrel lower at $4.62 per barrel in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $9.69 per barrel for the same period last year. The LLS/WTI differential narrowed $2.57 per barrel from $4.23 per barrel in the first quarter of 2015 to $1.66 per barrel in the first quarter of 2016. This had an approximately $81 million negative impact on earnings based on the WTI link crudes in our slate.
The $231 million year-over-year increase in direct operating cost related primarily to higher turnaround activity during the first quarter. Turnaround and major maintenance costs increased $1.64 per barrel or about $260 million compared to the first quarter of 2015. The higher turnaround activity also impacted throughputs which were 78,000 barrels per day lower in the first quarter last year.
Partially offsetting these negative impacts was favorable market structure during the quarter. This contango effect is reflected in the $117 million favorable difference on the and relates to the difference between the prompt crude prices we use for market metrics and the actual crude acquisition cost.
Moving forward to the other segments. Slide 7 provides the Speedway segment earnings compared to the first quarter last year. Speedway's income from operations was consistent with last year's first quarter at about $167 million. Last year was a record first quarter for our Speedway business, even before including the retail assets acquired along the East Coast and Southeast, so we're very pleased to the continuing strong performance in the first quarter of this year.
Gasoline and distillate margins were about $0.03 lower than the first quarter of 2015. This was offset by higher merchandise margins, higher gasoline and distillate sales volumes, and a $24 million gain from the sale of a retail location in the quarter. Gasoline and distillate margins averaged $0.168 in the first quarter of 2016 compared to a $0.197 in the first quarter of 2015. This decline reflects some of the stickiness in price at the retail level when crude prices move rapidly as we experienced later in the first quarter.
On a same-store basis, gasoline sales volumes increased 1% over the same period last year. Merchandise margins were $19 million higher than the first quarter 2015, due to overall higher merchandise sales and the higher margins realized on those sales. Merchandise sales in the quarter excluding cigarettes increased 3.1% on a same-store year-over-year basis, reflecting some of the progress we're making in merchandising across the entire business.
In April, we've seen an increase in demand with approximately 1.4% increase in same-store gasoline sales volumes compared to last April.
Slide 8 provides changes in the Midstream segment income versus the first quarter last year. Please note that we changed our operating segment presentation this quarter in connection with the contribution of our inland marine business to MPLX. Previously, the inland marine business and our investment in Ocean Partners were included in our refining and marketing segment.
First quarter and going forward, we include all of the marine-related businesses in the Midstream segment. The $90 million shown here for the first quarter of 2015 has also been adjusted for comparability between periods. The $77 million increase quarter-over-quarter was primarily due to the combination of MarkWest at the end of last year, which contributed $72 million of incremental segment income to the first quarter. The remaining increase of $5 million was primarily due to an increase in income from our equity affiliates and higher transportation revenues, partially offset by higher operating expenses versus last year.
Slide 9 presents the significant elements of changes in our consolidated cash position for the first quarter. Cash at the end of the first quarter was $308 million. Core operating cash flow was a $604 million source of cash. The $277 million use of working capital noted on the slide primarily relates to a decrease in accounts payable and accrued liabilities, partially offset by decreases in accounts receivable and inventory. The decrease in these accounts are primarily due to the drop in crude oil and refined product prices during the quarter versus the fourth quarter 2015, which led to the net use of cash given the generally longer terms on the crude purchases.
Net debt repayments resulted in a $372 million use of cash during the quarter. This net reduction resulted from some opportunistic ATM issuances at MPLX in the quarter, generating equity proceeds of about $315 million. These funds were used to pay down a portion of MPLX's then outstanding revolver balance.
The equity proceeds are also reflected as part of the $281 million of other cash flows in the quarter shown on the walk.
We continued delivering our commitment to returning cash to our shareholders. We repurchased 75 million of shares and paid 169 million of dividends in the first quarter. While the share repurchase activity may vary based on the needs and the cash flow characteristics of the business in any particular period, our commitment to continue returning capital remains a fundamental element of our strategy and an important part of the value proposition for our investors.
Share count at the end of the quarter was approximately 530 million shares, reflecting repurchase activity of about $7.3 billion, retiring about 28% of the then outstanding shares since the spin. In addition, the $0.32 per share dividend announcement by our board yesterday contributes to the 28% compound annual growth rate in our dividend since the spin.
Slide 10 provides an overview of our capitalization and financial profile at the end of the quarter. We had $11.6 billion of total consolidated debt, including $4.7 billion of debt at MPLX. Total consolidated debt-to-book capitalization was about 37% and represented a manageable 2.1x last 12 months adjusted EBITDA of just over -- close to $5.6 billion. Operating cash flow for the quarter was $604 million before reflecting the $277 million use of cash for working capital in the quarter.
Slide 11 provides updated outlook information on key operating metrics for MPC for the second quarter of this year. We're expecting second quarter volumes to be down slightly compared to second quarter 2015 due to the maintenance. Total direct operating cost are expected to be $6.75 per barrel on total throughputs of 1.875 million barrels per day, which reflects the impact of higher turnaround activity. Our projected second quarter corporate and other unallocated items will be about $75 million.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Lisa.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, my first question, I know you've been constructive on refining margin outlook. And curious for any updates there, particularly on Midcon margins for the balance of the year and then diesel.  And somewhat related, I mean, is your system currently at
componenttext: Gary, my first question, I know you've been constructive on refining margin outlook. And curious for any updates there, particularly on Midcon margins for the balance of the year and then diesel.  And somewhat related, I mean, is your system currently at a maximum gasoline versus distillate yield?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will let Ray talk about whether or not we're maximum gas and distillate, we are that [indiscernible] talked about that, but let me speak to the overall refining segment first within the industry, Evan. And I guess I look at it from a inventory position
componenttext: I will let Ray talk about whether or not we're maximum gas and distillate, we are that [indiscernible] talked about that, but let me speak to the overall refining segment first within the industry, Evan. And I guess I look at it from a inventory position and this brings inventories for the first time you see. And as I said in my script, I'm very pleased how the industry really have, I think, [indiscernible] into balance, if you look at pad 2, we are now spot on the same inventory level as we were same time last year across pad 2. 0 increase in gasoline and 0 increase in [indiscernible] for diesel same periods. So I see that as a very positive from where we were coming into the year. And I think that is really should provide for strength as we go into the gasoline season here at the end of Q2 and Q3. Secondly, the Gulf Coast, while gasoline is still a little bit up, there's still some turnarounds being finished in the Gulf Coast. And with the exports, I think the Gulf Coast can get into balance is we go into the summer grade gasoline, [indiscernible] to balance very quickly. Lastly, the thing to really watch is the significant demand in asphalt across the country. And specifically, we're the largest manufacturer of asphalt in the refining system and we're expecting a big asphalt season. And with our ability to broaden a lot of sour crude oil and what we've been seeing right now, the Mars outspread and not only mars, but if you look at several cargo opportunities, the [indiscernible] have really started to improve here in the second quarter. And we see that as very positive going into the balance of the second quarter and Q3. So Ray, do you want to talk about max gas versus max diesel?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Gary. We've completed all of our planned turnaround work which was heavy in the first quarter and we're back up running all our refineries a plan and at maximum. And our swing streams right now are directed to the gasoline stream. We have the capabi
componenttext: Sure, Gary. We've completed all of our planned turnaround work which was heavy in the first quarter and we're back up running all our refineries a plan and at maximum. And our swing streams right now are directed to the gasoline stream. We have the capability to swing about 10% between gasoline and diesel and that's all pointed to gasoline right now.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I'll keep my second question to the macro yet it shifted to maybe your NGL outlook. I know you got significant direct exposure now in there's 6 new ethane crackers starting up in '17 and '18, it's almost 550,000 barrels a day ethane demand exports
componenttext: Great. I'll keep my second question to the macro yet it shifted to maybe your NGL outlook. I know you got significant direct exposure now in there's 6 new ethane crackers starting up in '17 and '18, it's almost 550,000 barrels a day ethane demand exports in the third quarter. New propane exports have lowered inventories there and in line with the 5-year average. I mean, any thoughts on the NGL outlook? Where things look to be improving? And as you think about sensitivities at the MPLX level, I'd appreciate it.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Don, do you want to handle it, please?
componenttext: Sure, Don, do you want to handle it, please?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Evan, we do see improving pricing around NGLs. And we are optimistic and look favorably upon what's happening in the market. I think as it relates specifically to MPLX and our producer customers, particularly in the Marcellus and Utica, absolute pri
componenttext: Sure. Evan, we do see improving pricing around NGLs. And we are optimistic and look favorably upon what's happening in the market. I think as it relates specifically to MPLX and our producer customers, particularly in the Marcellus and Utica, absolute prices are important but so is basis differential. And one of the challenges that they had particularly last summer was there were discounts from other markets. And so our goal right now in the activities that we're undertaking are really focused on, relieving the excess volumes in the basin and allowing them to get to markets that are either more liquid or international markets. So our projects like rail to the East Coast are projects -- and this will be a little bit longer term but a consideration of butane alkylate, our efforts to load the unit trains, our -- the positive news about ethane being shipped from the basin over to the East Coast and making its way onto in international shipment. Those are all very positive in our view for the producer customers that we have a regular interaction with and that impact our business the most.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: I guess a broader kind of question to begin with. Obviously, you made a lot of strategic changes. That quarter was quite tough because of maintenance and then some of the environment issues, you end up with $300 million of cash. Can you just talk about what you think are the main levers that you're going to pull to rebuild that cash balance? Clearly the summer may be good but we're 7 years into a business cycle.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, let me have -- Tim will cover the balance sheet part, let me talk about our strategy. And you're right, we have -- since we spoke at your conference, in fact, in February, we rolled out our plans to reduce capital this year. We made significant headwa
componenttext:
Ed, let me have -- Tim will cover the balance sheet part, let me talk about our strategy. And you're right, we have -- since we spoke at your conference, in fact, in February, we rolled out our plans to reduce capital this year. We made significant headway in reducing capital. We are making tremendous headway in self-help and reducing operating expenses across all segments of our business. And that's going to happen and we're going to continue to do the job with that. But as we go forward, to relieve any distraction within our business, as you recognize yesterday we announced the convertible preferred. I thought it was important, the whole team thought it was important that we get any distraction as I outlined at your conference when I spoke to get any distraction between MPC and MPLX off the table, and we've accomplished that with the $1 billion of convertible preferred that will take care of the capital budget at MPLX into 2017.
Secondly, as we continue to digest this acquisition, Tony and his team have done a tremendous job at being able to digest the acquisition. [indiscernible] into a mode and into a rhythm of being able to harvest the cash from these businesses and buildup that stockpile of cash and clearly, intent to get back into a more robust share repurchase program as we go down the road. Tim?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. With regard to the cash balances, as you may recall for the Analyst Day last year, we highlighted the fact that as we go through our core liquidity analysis and how much we need to support the business and protect for all the potential contingencies,
componenttext: Yes. With regard to the cash balances, as you may recall for the Analyst Day last year, we highlighted the fact that as we go through our core liquidity analysis and how much we need to support the business and protect for all the potential contingencies, there's a number of elements of that analysis that are a function of absolute crude prices. And the amount of core liquidity in the form of cash that we would keep at $100, $80, $60 oil is much higher than where it is at oil at between $30 and $40 and $45. So I think we are very comfortable a t the 3 0 8 number. We expect it's going to be anywhere between sort of 0 and $0.5 billion. And with the committed capacity we have on the facilities and the sort of tools we have available to us with working capital and otherwise, I think we are very comfortable that at these absolute price levels that they were at appropriate levels to protect the business on a going forward basis. So there's a -- and I think there's an ocean at least crude prices that we necessarily need to build cash balances back. I think we're comfortable with were at that as Gary said, a lot of opportunity for sort of earnings enhancements as we go forward and we'll certainly have those levers available to us as we go.

Our capital budget that we have currently, the $1 billion capital budget, I think is reflective of what we believe are current drilling plans at 4 customers, our producer customers. We obviously -- within there is some flex there but I don't anticipate that there will be any significant movement from the number that we've publicly quoted.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, I guess previously you sort of touched on this but I was hoping you could provide a little more color. I'm just curious, the $1 billion private placement MPLX, how that freeze up MPC? And the extent to which that reduces the support that may be thou
componenttext: Gary, I guess previously you sort of touched on this but I was hoping you could provide a little more color. I'm just curious, the $1 billion private placement MPLX, how that freeze up MPC? And the extent to which that reduces the support that may be thought you might have to provide to MPLX. And I'm thinking about the specifically in the context of are we going to continue to see drops at the very advantageous multiple for MPLX? There's take some of the things like maybe IDR givebacks off the table?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Brad, as you know, this is -- with the MLP markets the way they are today, is a very dynamic situation and it's a buyer -- my answer has to be addressed those dynamic cases. But certainly, that is our expectation. That's in our goal. As we did the d
componenttext: Well, Brad, as you know, this is -- with the MLP markets the way they are today, is a very dynamic situation and it's a buyer -- my answer has to be addressed those dynamic cases. But certainly, that is our expectation. That's in our goal. As we did the drop of the inland marine system, it was a very supportive drop and that was to be able to bridge and MPLX over this time of challenge within that the MLP market. And MPLX has responded very, very well since early February and very pleased with the support and the improvement in the yield since that point in time. Secondly, as I said in my prepared remarks, we thought that was very important to get this distraction at any overhang. Your question is spot on. What -- in order to be able to be supportive to the MLP, what did the sponsor need to do? You're right, we dropped the supportive multiple. We certainly don't expect to be dropping those type of multiples going forward. And that was a bridge to get to where we are today. The same thing with the convertible preferred here. A very strong support for MPLX but it takes that overhang and it takes that distraction outside of MPC. And I believe as we go forward and look at any next props, I think where we are situated now, we don't need to make any more drops in '16. We'll see how far out into '17 before we really do need to consider that. But our plan is as MPLX continues to improve and the yields continue to improve, which I'm confident they're going to, I think we're going to be able to cure this bridge or kind of rebuild this bridge that we've been working on for the last 3 or 4 months. Tim, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I would just reiterate the notion that, Brad, I think as we assess things, the convertible preferred provides a very efficient form of equity capital in a market that's been sort of volatile with elevated yields. Obviously, through the first quarter y
componenttext: No, I would just reiterate the notion that, Brad, I think as we assess things, the convertible preferred provides a very efficient form of equity capital in a market that's been sort of volatile with elevated yields. Obviously, through the first quarter you saw, common units yields, which were extraordinarily high and I think we were careful thinking about exactly what that could mean for the partnership on a long-term basis. So with the amount of investor interest around these securities and structuring a security that we think makes  sense, as Gary said, provide a fantastic funding source. It takes '16 off the table, right into '17. And again, allows the focus on the business to be the continued growth and production, the organic projects and positions the partnership well. What this will mean for sponsor support, I think MPC stands ready in all of its varying forms and all the varying tools. To step in to help support the partnership when there's sufficient capital available in the marketplace, we'll avail ourselves of that. And that's not available, MPC will stay ready. So we're pleased with getting this security done. As Gary said, there was some thoughts that MPC would provide this funding. MPC is still prepared to do so, but with the third-party money available at terms that we feel attractive, we thought that was a good session we move forward on.

componenttextpreview: So Gary, I want to touch -- start off on retail. And the right structure for it to be in, and I know, I've seen this in the past. What do you think about doing a retail spinoff. We just keep on seeing these Marcs out there, these retail c corps that are t
componenttext: So Gary, I want to touch -- start off on retail. And the right structure for it to be in, and I know, I've seen this in the past. What do you think about doing a retail spinoff. We just keep on seeing these Marcs out there, these retail c corps that are trading at 11, 12x EBITDA. Does that make sense to monetize that asset?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, and you're right, we have talked about this before and as we've look at that question, the answer has to be, how do we think shareholders are valuing Speedway inside of MPC today, and therefore, what is the Delta. When I step back and really look at
componenttext: Neil, and you're right, we have talked about this before and as we've look at that question, the answer has to be, how do we think shareholders are valuing Speedway inside of MPC today, and therefore, what is the Delta. When I step back and really look at the Delta that may be available, it certainly -- it was not a number that I think gives credence to separating from the long-term strategic value that we see in having Speedway under the control of our -- I should say not under control but inside the value system. And inside the supply chain system of Marathon. It's always been one of our key value with inside Marathon. We've fireback a lot of work in some other transactions that have happened starkly were company spun off the retail. It appeared to be a pretty small bump in share value that can be eroded for many different reasons across the value chain. With all of that said, we continue to look at it. We continue to analyze it. And I clearly, as you and I spoke, I clearly see what the values that are being garnered inside the retail only space. And as always, we'll continue to analyze this as we get on the road.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Gary, I just want your perspective on the crude markets on 2 different fronts. First, on your views on the differentials which continue to be tight, certainly for these and differentials but they are on the light have is in the medium sours. And
componenttext: And then Gary, I just want your perspective on the crude markets on 2 different fronts. First, on your views on the differentials which continue to be tight, certainly for these and differentials but they are on the light have is in the medium sours. And then also just on the left flap price, I know you're in Saudi Arabia a couple of weeks ago. Just any thoughts in terms of how you think OPEC acts through the balance of the year?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Neil, as I spoke to your conference early in the year, I mean the prediction that crude will be somewhere mid-50s to 60 by the end of the year. And Brent topped 47 yesterday, and it looks to have a momentum going into today. And I still believe tha
componenttext: Right. Neil, as I spoke to your conference early in the year, I mean the prediction that crude will be somewhere mid-50s to 60 by the end of the year. And Brent topped 47 yesterday, and it looks to have a momentum going into today. And I still believe that crude is -- will continue and what's so important is that this hinges up slowly. You don't want a spike on a very short-term basis because I think the pain on a spike in that coming off that spike would be -- will have a longer lasting effects on the marketplace. So you want to have a very slow gradual move. And we're seeing that happening. And I still stand by our thoughts on that your code is going to continue to move. And I think that's a beneficial across the entire energy sector. I think that it improves demand if you get prices up and you get people in the oil fields, I think it's important again for the entire worldwide global demand sector. What I said in my remarks that I'm glad you brought it up is that we're starting to see the medium sours, the models and some other cargoes of Mars, medium and other look-alike type barrels over the last month or so, we're starting to see that Mars spread, that medium sour spreads widen out. And I think that it's very supportive of the industry, very supportive to those refiners who have the ability to run this medium sour crude. And have the residual processing capability that handle and the reason and us being the largest manufacturer of asphalt in the country, it really helps us as we went to the asphalt season. So I see crude continuing to move up for the balance of the year. I think it's very good for the medium and heavy sour refiners and at the same time, we'll see what happens. I would expect that there's going to be another meaning of the OpEx numbers here in May and I expect to see these places to put in place. And if that happens, I think it will continue to have some pressure on the LLS agreed us for us and spreads. But I think it will continue to benefit the medium sour players.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Distillate demand is down. It's just a combination of a number of things when we look at the overall numbers that we're looking at in diesel. The over-the-road component is soft. it's probably down in the neighborhood of about 2% and that's the large
componenttext: Yes. Distillate demand is down. It's just a combination of a number of things when we look at the overall numbers that we're looking at in diesel. The over-the-road component is soft. it's probably down in the neighborhood of about 2% and that's the large 18-wheel freight business. And some of the regional business is down a little less than that, probably in the 1% person area. And there are some other factors that are affecting overall distillate as well demand for U.S. for example, all the shale production that was shut-in, there were some large consumption on distillate for that activity which is obviously slowed down significantly.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do negative numbers like that historically in particular to the figure. And if so, what would be the redrew to the U.S. economy? Or do you guys did not take it quite that far?
componenttext: Do negative numbers like that historically in particular to the figure. And if so, what would be the redrew to the U.S. economy? Or do you guys did not take it quite that far?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You heard me say many times that over-the-road diesel is I think a precursor to the overall economy. Due to some of the -- if you go back to the first quarter, we just analyzed our diesel demand over-the-road the soul demand in the first quarter, there ar
componenttext: You heard me say many times that over-the-road diesel is I think a precursor to the overall economy. Due to some of the -- if you go back to the first quarter, we just analyzed our diesel demand over-the-road the soul demand in the first quarter, there are times across the eastern seaboard, we loss 4 and 5 days of diesel demand because of severe weather. But you have severe weather in different pockets of the country every year. But it seemed to be more severe in the markets in which we operate today. But you're right, it has always historically somewhat of a predictor of the overall economy. I look at some of our big, big customers on the diesel side and they are down probably 2% to 3% on a same-store basis on diesel demand, yet in talking to a lot of the big trucking companies, the trucking companies books, they say looks strong going into Q2 and for the summer months. So it remains to be seen. I expect that diesel, I don't think for the year we're going to be down 3% but as you know, we had tremendous growth in the cell in the last 3 or 4 years and I think some of that is just leveling off of what the demand has been. But we still -- you go back to last 3 or 4 years, probably in total of around 10%. So when your average is out, I think the market is still very good.

componenttext: Yes, I don't know that we have any particular insight to the trouble's that Venezuela is seeing right now where did you do. I can tell you that it is difficult doing business with them. They have a lot of trouble trying to keep their upgraders, for example, going. And there hasn't been a lot of spot opportunities from Venezuela for us so far this year. So that's certainly been difficult.

componenttext: Well, I don't know that there's a hard target again. This is something that we'll sort of assess as we go, obviously, a relatively weak quarter on the earnings side and the resulting cash flow, so I think you could expect that the activity would've been lower in first quarter. But again, I think our focus is that the -- we've talked about 100% of free cash flow through cycle as the business generates cash and sort of carefully looking at capital, we expect that the activity is going to vary based on any given quarter. So I wouldn't say there's a target but a continued long-term focus on making that important part of our overall capital plans.

componenttextpreview: With the Robinson turnaround, we completed the project to increase our light crude processing capability. And what that allow us to do is increase our handling of light crude by 30,000 barrels a day on a string day basis. And at the same time, that gives
componenttext: With the Robinson turnaround, we completed the project to increase our light crude processing capability. And what that allow us to do is increase our handling of light crude by 30,000 barrels a day on a string day basis. And at the same time, that gives us an overall increase in total crude throughput of about 20,000 barrels a day at that refinery. So significant improvement in that refinery.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Can you talk about the yield impact on the product side?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the yield impact, which basically follow our normal distribution of about between gasoline and diesel. There wouldn't be a large change there overall. One thing that we've done at that refinery to, at the end of last year is we increased our hydrocr
componenttext: Well, the yield impact, which basically follow our normal distribution of about between gasoline and diesel. There wouldn't be a large change there overall. One thing that we've done at that refinery to, at the end of last year is we increased our hydrocracker capacity by about 10,000 barrels a day. So this plays along with that too.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess along those lines, it just seems like a lot of your current refined projects are focused on increasing production. And maybe this back to Doug's question. With demand soft, how concerned are you about not only your increases on capacity, just the
componenttext: I guess along those lines, it just seems like a lot of your current refined projects are focused on increasing production. And maybe this back to Doug's question. With demand soft, how concerned are you about not only your increases on capacity, just the broad global increase we've seen in the last couple of years, the thing that's going to play out on the cracks for diesel going forward here maybe in the next couple of years?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Chi, I would say that if you go back and look at our exports, and look at the exports of the industry, still about 2:1 the global demand for diesel in the export is what we're seeing. As I said earlier, we're back to all the diesel inventories acros
componenttext: Well, Chi, I would say that if you go back and look at our exports, and look at the exports of the industry, still about 2:1 the global demand for diesel in the export is what we're seeing. As I said earlier, we're back to all the diesel inventories across pad 2. Our balance to where we were same period of last year still up about 7 million barrels of inventory in pad 3. I think that can be cleared relatively easy as we go into the balance for the quarter. It's all back to answer the question the as a. What is overall the overall diesel demand equation, what happens to that in the near term? But as we see, and it's always been our position, we work very hard to always balance the diesel inventory in pad. Pad 3, diesel inventory moves into pad 1, moves into pad 2, with the demands in any dislocation that may happen in the marketplace. But most importantly, the export demand for diesel going back to Doug's question about Venezuela and I think some other markets. We're continuing to see very strong demand but we're also seeing improvement in gasoline demand as some of those export markets as well. So I understand your question. And I think the entire industry is continuing to assess and I'd be very careful in any incremental diesel projects. But as you know, Chi, we don't do one of these products overnight. Their long-term in the planning and long-term that generally these a small upgrades or you get that supply, to have a major terror on cycle plan. So it's all going come back to the balance of over the road demand and the balance of export demand going forward.

componenttext: No, it wasn't a throwaway comment. It's just -- you read the same things I do but I go back in history and look at how all these distractions play out. There's a tremendous amount of disappointment in a number of the OPEC numbers that this wasn't solved. In the April 17 meeting. And the expectation is there will be another meeting here in May. And this goes along with my entire pieces of where we think crude prices are going to go. I, of course, don't have any inside knowledge of a letter there will be or will not be but it certainly comes from my years of experience but expect that I'll see you in the other meeting.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Gary, you talked several times about the distraction, that you've got past the direction of the MPLX CapEx. Could you talk about the outlook for MPC CapEx? Update us on the major projects that you're undertaking. And you mentioned that you're hoping to bring CapEx down further and I think fairly strongly said that are going to be prioritizing cash return to shareholders. If you could give us the CapEx side of that balance outlook for MPC, that would be grateful.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. And we stated early February when we reduced the capital. We reduced the capital budget around $1 billion across both MPLX and MPC side of the equation. Our major projects, we are just embarking on very, very early stages of the big STAR proje
componenttext: Sure, Paul. And we stated early February when we reduced the capital. We reduced the capital budget around $1 billion across both MPLX and MPC side of the equation. Our major projects, we are just embarking on very, very early stages of the big STAR project and that goes out 6 years for the South Texas asset redevelopment projects. So that goes out for a number of years and we do not have any large projects or large cap expenditures or any individual projects off once. We will continue to look at the capital. Don has done a very good job at being able to squeeze capital out of the midstream side, as well as Tony has on the retail side would be very efficient and probably to the backloads of projects where we saw was opportunistic to reduce summer capital spend. And we continue to look at that every month as we close our books. My comments on capital deployment and getting back into share repurchases was that as we went through this big acquisition in Speedway, now almost 1.5 years ago. And that's, as I said earlier, we're way ahead of schedule on the EBITDA that it is generating and MPLX, I believe, we are really have that grow going in the right direction that our plan is, as conditions improve and Tim just answered the question from Chi on share repurchases. We do not have a month-by-month plan on what we're going to do but our strategy -- or I mean, we know we want to do but not to plan on exactly any share buybacks and when that might happen. But we want to get back into our rhythm as we log in the next few years of being able to harvest from these businesses that we've acquired. And really set this company up very, very strong across all 3 segments of the business that we will be able to harvest and get back to a strong share buyback program over the long term.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, obviously, as Gary indicated, we have and we'll continue to look very careful a capital. There's a certain portion of the capital budget at MPC that is what we'll probably describe as a little bit more maintenance in nature, a little bit more regula
componenttext: Phil, obviously, as Gary indicated, we have and we'll continue to look very careful a capital. There's a certain portion of the capital budget at MPC that is what we'll probably describe as a little bit more maintenance in nature, a little bit more regulatory pieces. But for all the pieces and certainly when we think about some of the investments in Speedway, in TNL, obviously the STAR project we've announced, we've sort of extended that to push it out. There are elements and good pockets within the capital budget that probably we'll continue to have flex capability to them depending on how things go. I mean, there are number of things thicken sort of setup and pursue more rapidly if conditions improve. And we see the earnings and cash flows that could support investment there. Or frankly, defer further, defer into '17 and potentially beyond as the needs of the business sort of migrate over time. So there is, I think, with any refining business, you'll see an environment of capital that may be has a little bit less flexibility to it but we still have significant and we'll l to look at over the course of this year and into next in terms of where we may want to make some adjustments.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Phil, this is Don, on the MPLX side or midstream side. In our budget this year has been reduced our going to manage it down to something closer to $1 billion. Of that, probably 60 percentage or so was  and 40% was logistics and storage. And in that 40
componenttext: And Phil, this is Don, on the MPLX side or midstream side. In our budget this year has been reduced our going to manage it down to something closer to $1 billion. Of that, probably 60 percentage or so was  and 40% was logistics and storage. And in that 40%, we're a couple of projects that are underway that we're going to compare this year that won't continue on into next year that give us some flexibility. So, for example, the cornerstone project will be completed by, we're projecting that will be completed by the fourth quarter of this year. And that was roughly half of the budget that we had for the LNS business. On the GMP side of the business, this year, in our budget, about 60% of the total year budget was around gathering and 40% was sort of processing and fractionation. The remainder of the year, it's actually a higher proportion of gathering the pricing and fractionation. We've essentially completed the major projects that we were undertaking. So we have the ability to flex that capital next year, really dependent upon how our producer customers and what they're planning to do and how quickly they continue to grow their volumes. So I believe there's a lot of flex, I believe that on the MPLX side, particularly capital is probably closer to a number that we had this year but we'll continue to manage that as the year progresses.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: The second question is just around on the refining side. Tim, probably your favorite topic. On an absolute basis, the other gross margin was only about $15 million in the quarter. You mentioned crude differentials as a key variance factor year-over-year. I was just wondering if was there anything else maybe one time in the quarter because it was a big down time quarter, obviously, there's a weak margin quarter to begin with but if there's any additional color there might be useful.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I don't know if there's any very unique one-timers. Again, a lot of what we've seen on the other gross margin sort of as it tracked struggle over time, has really been a function of where absolute crude prices are. Because obviously, we have lower
componenttext: Yes. So I don't know if there's any very unique one-timers. Again, a lot of what we've seen on the other gross margin sort of as it tracked struggle over time, has really been a function of where absolute crude prices are. Because obviously, we have lower crude prices, you'll see things like volumetric gains decline in terms of the value ascribed to the gain with the refining system as absolute refined product prices are lower. You'll see with a lot of the differentials having come in, you also see a lot of the benefits that we have seen historically on the stack and feedstock into the system, those spreads relative to LS have come in as well. There's a little bit less opportunity again at these absolute levels to regard the benefits of feedstocks and then stocks into the system as well. So again, a lot of that has been sort of trending that way, just at the absolute levels and some of the differentials coming up and those are probably the biggest drivers of there's nothing in first quarter that was particularly unusual relative to the transit we're seeing really over the course over last year.
