headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Marathon Petroleum Corporation. My name is Katie, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.I will now turn the call to Lis
componenttext:
Welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Marathon Petroleum Corporation. My name is Katie, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
I will now turn the call to Lisa Wilson, Director of Investor Relations.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's second quarter 2016 earnings webcast and conference call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab. O
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's second quarter 2016 earnings webcast and conference call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab. On the call today are Gary Heminger, Chairman, President and CEO; Tim Griffith, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and other members of MPC's executive team.
We invite you to read the Safe Harbor statements on Slide 2. It is a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the call and during the question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from what we expect today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ are included there as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
Now I will turn the call over to Gary Heminger for opening remarks and highlights.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lisa, and good morning to everyone. Thank you for joining us. If you please turn to Slide 3.Earlier today, we reported second quarter earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per share. Earnings included net benefited  of $0.44 per share, primarily rel
componenttext:
Thanks, Lisa, and good morning to everyone. Thank you for joining us. If you please turn to Slide 3.
Earlier today, we reported second quarter earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per share. Earnings included net benefited  of $0.44 per share, primarily related to a reversal of our lower cost of market inventory valuation reserve. All segments of the business performed well in the second quarter. Earnings benefited from improving crack spread's, robust product demand entering the summer driving and Asphalt season, strong retail margins and the inclusion of MarkWest in our consolidated results. 
The refining and marketing segment delivered strong results despite less favorable comforting and marketing conditions during the quarter. Our integrated refinery and extensive logistics network allows us to capture advantage feedstock and other raw materials, as well as enhanced price realization to are refined product distribution system.
Our unique asset mix and flexibility position us to optimize the operations even during this disruption, such as those costs in the second quarter by the Canadian and refinery outages.
Speedway continued its outstanding performance with record set second quarter segment income. In addition, to higher like product sales volume and margins, the business delivered higher merchandise margins in the quarter.
This improvement is consistent with a strategy to drive marketing enhancement opportunities. We're pleased with our progress and realizing synergies across the Speedway network, earlier than originally planned and believe this will be continued source of value to the business.
Speedway provides significant and growing stable cash flow, complementing MPCs integrated refining and distribution network. Speedway is MPC's most ratable distribution channel, provides a solid base to enhance overall supply reliability and allows us to optimize our entire refining pipeline and terminal operations.
The Midstream segment including MPLX financial and operational results also delivered strong comments during the quarter. MPLX remains on target to achieve it's 2016 distribution growth guidance without the need for additional drop-down from MPC during the year. 
During the quarter, MPLX expanded its Midstream presence in the Southwest with the completion of its gas process complex in the Delaware Basin, where utilization is exceeding initial expectations.
Construction of the Cornerstone Pipeline is also progressing as planned, with completion expected in fourth quarter. Cornerstone Pipeline is designed to provide MPC's refinery with the direct supply of condensate out of the Marcellus and Utica regions and to supply natural gasoline into our Midwest refineries. 
As commodity prices recovered, excuse me optimism is growing among MPLX's produce customers and with world-class Mistry mass located in some of the best resource place in the country, MPLX is well-positioned to capitalize on an exceptional set of opportunities along the entire hydrocarbon value chain. 
As we enter the third quarter, both heavy and light Canadian crude differentials have written to more favorable levels, as the impact of the Canadian qualifiers subsided.
Canadian heavy production continues to grow and we expect good values for third and fourth quarters. Additionally, we expect to continue to see spot opportunities in foreign suit and cargos. The regional diversity of our refining assets also enables us to benefit from access to the export market. We believe, we have the right assets in the right locations with 60% of our crude oil refining capacity in the Gulf Coast and 40% in the Midwest.
We're also expect to complete the first phase of our multi-year start program at the Galveston Bay refinery in Texas City next month. This phase will revamp and expand the by 12,000 barrels per day, improving the profitability of the refinery by increasing the conversion of lower value residual oil into gas oil. The EBITDA contribution from this initial phase is expected to average approximately $80 million per year.
During the second quarter, we returned $221 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. In addition, on July 27, our board of Directors announced a 12.5% increase in the quarterly dividend to $0.36 per share. That 29% compound annual growth rate in our dividends since MPC became an independent company, demonstrates our continuing confidence in the cash flow generation of the business.
It also demonstrates our long-term focus on capital returns, while maintaining an investment credit grade profile and strong liquidity throughout the cycle.
The efficiency and flexibility of our retail refining systems drives to diversify our earnings power of our business and we remain encouraged by the long-term prospects of our business and the value proposition for our investors. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Tim to walk you through the financial results for the quarter.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings on both absolute and per share basis. MPC's second quarter 2016 earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per diluted share were down slightly from last years second quarter earnings of $826 million. We refer to the $0.44 per
componenttext:
Thank Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings on both absolute and per share basis. MPC's second quarter 2016 earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per diluted share were down slightly from last years second quarter earnings of $826 million. We refer to the $0.44 per share net benefit in the quarter, which included the investment of $0.47 per diluted share related to a reversal of lower of cost market inventory valuation reserve, and charge of $0.03 per diluted share related to impairment of 1 MPLX equity investments.
The chart on Slide 5 shows by segment the change in earnings in the second quarter of last year. As mentioned, earnings were impacted in the quarter by $385 million pretax benefit to fully reverse our lower cost to market reserve. $360 million of this benefit is included in refining and marketing segment, and $25 million is reflected in Speedway segment.
After adjusting for this benefit earnings were down approximately $410 million over the same quarter last year, largely attributable to lower income from our refining market segment, higher interest expense resulting from MarkWest merger and the equity impairment I just mentioned.
This negative impacts for the quarter were partially offset by higher income contributed by our Midstream and Speedway segment and lower income taxes.
Turning to Slide 6, our Refining and Marketing segment reported income from operations of almost $1.1 billion in the second quarter compared to the income from operations of $1.2 billion in the same quarter last year. The decrease after excluding the $360 million benefit from the LTM reversal was primarily due to weaker crack spread's and both Gulf coast or Chicago and WTI differential, less favorable market structure and higher cost related activity in the second quarter.
Partially offsetting these negative impact was an improvement in the differential in the quarter. The lower branded crack spread had a negative impact in earnings of approximately $502 million, the blended crack spread was $2.58 per barrel lower at $7.66 per barrel in the second quarter of 2016 compared to $10.24 per barrel in the same period last year.
segment benefited $227 million by approximately $2 per barrel differential as well as higher severance in the quarter versus last year. The LLS-WTI differential narrowed $3.25 per barrel from $4.99 per barrel in the second quarter of 2015 to $1.74 per barrel in the second quarter of this year. Which had a negative impact in earnings about $100 million based on the WTI link crudes in our 
 
The market structure effect during the quarter is reflected $78 million unfavorable variance on the and a relates to the difference between the comp prices we use for market metrics and the actual crude acquisition cost in the quarter.
The $70 million increase year-over-year in direct operating costs related primarily higher turnover activity in the quarter versus last year. Turnaround and major maintenance cost increased $0.50 per barrel or over $80 million compared to second quarter of 2015. The higher turnaround activity also impacted total throughputs, which was 62,000 barrels per day lower than the second quarter last year. 
Captured rate for the quarter was negatively impacted by the fact of rising crude oil prices on wholesale and secondary product margins, narrow crude differentials and differentials on feedstocks relative to crude. 
Turning to our other segments Slide 7 provides the Speedway segment earnings walk versus the same quarter last year. As Gary mentioned, Speedway had a record second quarter earnings of $193 million, which was up to $66 million higher than the second quarter of 2015. 
Light product margin was significant contributor of this increase, along with higher merchandise gross margin and the $25 million reversal of Speedways lower cost of market inventory reserves in the quarter.
Gasoline and distillate margins were about $0.02 higher in the second quarter of last year, then in the second quarter of last year at $0.15.5 per gallon, while volumes were up $33 million-gallon quarter-over-quarter. And same-store basis gasoline sales volumes increased over the same period last year. Merchandise gross margin was $10 million higher than the second quarter last year due to overall higher merchandise sales and the higher margins realized on those sales. Merchandise sales in the quarter, excluding cigarettes increased 2% out of same-store year-over-year basis, reflecting some of the profits we're making on enhancing merchandise model across the entire business.
In July, we've seen a decrease in gasoline demand with approximately 1% decrease in the same-store gasoline sales volumes compared to last July.  Which you may recall was a very strong month in 2015.
Speedway same-store gasoline sales growth was lower than estimated U.S. growth, as we continually to optimized total gasoline contribution between volume and margin to ensure fuel margins remain adequate.
Slide 8 provides the change in Midstream segment income versus the second quarter last year. The $98 million increase quarter-over-quarter was primarily due to the combination of MarkWest at the end of last year, which contributed $81 million of the incremental segment income to the quarter. The remaining increase of $17 million was primarily due to increase in income from our equity affiliates and lower operating expenses versus last year.
Slide 9 presents a significant element of changes in our consolidated cash position in the second quarter. Cash at the end of quarter was nearly $1.8 billion, core operating cash flow was $1.2 billion source of cash. The $1 billion source of working capital noted in the slide primarily relates to an increase in accounts payable and crude liabilities, partially offset by smaller increase in accounts receivable. 
The increases in accounts payable and receivable were primarily due to higher crude oil and refined product prices during the quarter, which led to the net source of cash, given the generally longer-term crude payables versus refined products.
As we discussed in the first quarter call in April, MPLX issued convertible preferred equity during the quarter, generating equity proceeds of about $984 million. 
Proceeds from this private replacement have broken out separately in the log. MPLX used a portion of these funds to pay down its revolver, which is included in the $521 million of net debt repayment on the Return of capital during the quarter included a repurchase of $51 million of worth of shares and $170 million of dividend. Share repurchase activity may vary from quarter-to-quarter based on our needs and the cash flow characteristics of our business in any particular period.
Our commitment to continue to return the capital remains a fundamental element of our strategy and important part of the value proposition for investors. Share count at the end of the quarter was approximately 528 million shares, reflecting repurchase activity of about $7.4 billion, which approximately 28% of the outstanding shares at the time of the spend. 
In addition, as Gary mentioned earlier, the $0.36 per share dividend announced by our board yesterday, represents a 12.5% increase over last quarter's dividend and contributes to 29% compound annual growth rate in the dividend since our spend.
Slide 10 provides an overview of the capitalization and financial profile as of the end of the quarter. We had $11.1 billion of total consolidated debt including $4.4 billion of debt at MPLX. 
Total debt to per capitalization was about 36% and represented a manageable to 2x last 12 months adjusted EBITDA of over $5.8 billion, which is pro forma for the MarkWest acquisition. 
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $1.2 billion before reflecting the $1 billion source of cash for working capital in the quarter.
Slide 11 provides updated outlook information on key operating metrics for MPC for the third quarter. We're expecting third quarter throughput volumes to be down slightly compared to third quarter in 2015 due to more plant maintenance. Total direct operating costs are expected to be $7.65 per barrel on total throughput of 1.85 million barrels per day, which reflects the impact of higher expected turnaround activity in the third quarter versus our third quarter last year. Our projected third quarter corporate and other unallocated items expected to be about $75 million.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Lisa for questions.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggett from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary those been obviously a lot of noise in the sector about the arbitrage potential value of your retail business, and I think your comments in your prepared remarks, probably underlining your thoughts. But I just wonder, if I could ask you, reiterate yo
componenttext: Gary those been obviously a lot of noise in the sector about the arbitrage potential value of your retail business, and I think your comments in your prepared remarks, probably underlining your thoughts. But I just wonder, if I could ask you, reiterate your view that retail, you're happy with the current stock of Speedway and the current business, really you would ever consider a separation to trying to exploit the arbitrage that some others are talking about.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well Doug, as you and I have talk many times of course we look at this all of time, but as in my remarks we are very happy, and it illustrates when you have a down market like the refining sector has been in the last couple quarters, how important having
componenttext:
Well Doug, as you and I have talk many times of course we look at this all of time, but as in my remarks we are very happy, and it illustrates when you have a down market like the refining sector has been in the last couple quarters, how important having a diversified portfolio and a diversified value chain is to a businesslike ours is not only the most ratable customer within our portfolio, it's also in our long-term strategy to grow the Midstream business as well as the retail business. Those 2 segments are becoming, I would say our most credible cash flow streams within the business. So yes, we are happy with the structure. But yes, we continue to analyze and annualized -- analyze very critically as you call it in arbitrage. But when you look at on arbitrage Doug, you also need to understand what the integration value is? Now the integration value is, I would I can't give a out number from a competitive reason of that integration value, but I can say it is very significant. Especially, when you look at downturn in the cycles. 
And as I've mentioned several times, you look at first half of this year the EBITDA from Speedway the first half of this year, clearly covers the total dividend and interest costs on our capital. So yes, we are happy, yes, we continue to analyze it very carefully, but I would expect that we will continue on as we are.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I appreciate that answer. Gary always easy to those kind of questions. My follow-up is really on the dividend. Obviously, a nice bump last night, you're in the midrange with the peers. Going forward, what are your thoughts on the balance in terms of distribution between buybacks and continued dividend growth, and I will leave it there

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Tim?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, the I think it has and really since the time of spin that we would have a focus around maintaining a regular dividend that's got a growth cycle to it, that's really sort of through cycle and it's got, what we'd love to see is sort of double-dig
componenttext:
Yes, Doug, the I think it has and really since the time of spin that we would have a focus around maintaining a regular dividend that's got a growth cycle to it, that's really sort of through cycle and it's got, what we'd love to see is sort of double-digit over an expanded period of time. So that's sort of our primary focus to make sure that we sort of baseline the capital turn around in attractive and growing dividend that has got sustainability through cycle. 
Share purchase for us continues to be sort of a flyable depending on the cash needs of the business, where we sit from a core liquidity perspective, and so how we're viewing things. Obviously, we've taken down our capital spending plans in 2016. And I think some of the reductions that we've seen on the share purchase side has gone in parallel with really a careful look at how the year will play out and what the cash flow generation looks like. But I think it will continue to be an important source, and it will really be a function of the cash and liquidity position, we find ourselves in as we move forward.
So continued focus, I know the activity is lower in second quarter and in the first quarter than it's been over the last several years. But again, it's really just a function of what the liquidity needs of the business are at different points in time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And Doug one more point to that as many leading analyst have already printed this morning, as MPLX now as gone into the get within the capital structure, the balance sheet and our growth going forward. And as we expect that the yield will continue to improve within MPLX, that's going to give us the ability in the future and as we have drop downs to be able to bring that cash back in and for the buy back shares. So that's a very important ingredient in our strategy as well.

componenttext:
Well Evan, now we continue to wait on the IRS to answer our PLR. We're expecting that soon, but I don't know if that means this quarter, next quarter or the following quarter. We filed a long time ago, but still are awaiting. 
The distribution that we discussed earlier is really I think an elegant way to consider Tim talked about a flywheel before, but that is an elegant way without getting caught up in a retail and kind of a block or if you will, a tax blocker to be able to drop down part of those of that value.
So we need to remain in our seats and wait for the IRS to on our request, but we feel confident that it will go forward and I'll be able to give you a better range after we get that work back from the IRS.

componenttext: And the second question is on Midstream shelves now building a cracker in Pittsburgh. 1 still 5 years out, it's very positive for MPC and MPLX both from volume growth and what it means from pricing and relative northeast pricing parity was not Bellevue. I mean could you discuss that project or how it could effect your business and maybe how you're thinking about positioning for that today?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yeah, Evan, this is Tom. We have a leading ethane position in the Marcellus and the Utica, we have invested considerable capital in the past to be able to handle ethane recovery, and our view is that there is going to be continued production of growth in
componenttext: Yeah, Evan, this is Tom. We have a leading ethane position in the Marcellus and the Utica, we have invested considerable capital in the past to be able to handle ethane recovery, and our view is that there is going to be continued production of growth in ethane, which will give us an opportunity, we're estimating probably depending on where the forecast -- weather forecasts and up, we've heard or seen forecasts that would suggest in the early 2020 that there would be 500,000 barrels per day of ethane production, and if you got to those kinds of volumes, we could anticipate having capital projects that would be in the $500 million to $1 billion range in order to be able to extract that ethane to be able to support things like the crackers, but also to support ethane needs in the Gulf Coast and also for pipelines and other projects that are taking it to the East Coast.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you comment on the state of the product market as you see it, inventories are elevated right now. Do you think that's a function of refining supply or demand. And how do we work our way out of this the ultimately think we need to see run cuts la
componenttext: Gary, can you comment on the state of the product market as you see it, inventories are elevated right now. Do you think that's a function of refining supply or demand. And how do we work our way out of this the ultimately think we need to see run cuts later this year in the world and so.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, Neil that's a very prudent question, especially, if you look at the same period last year, when we were in a very strong refining market last year, but refiners landfill out and that tremendous build in excess inventory is what really led to the
componenttext:
Yes, so, Neil that's a very prudent question, especially, if you look at the same period last year, when we were in a very strong refining market last year, but refiners landfill out and that tremendous build in excess inventory is what really led to the downturn in the fourth quarter and really first quarter this year because of the rapid buildup inventories and the long-term to be able to run those of you. When I look at the inventories, that came out yesterday Neil in the pads where we predominantly operate, gasoline and is 2.9 million barrels over same period last year and we were down 2 million barrels for the week. So we're in a pretty good shape. The Gulf Coast is still a bit high on inventories, but pointed out to me earlier today, if you look at the turnaround schedule coming up in the Gulf Coast for Pad 3 and early into Pad 4, it appears to be a significant turnaround and schedule somewhere between 700,000 and 1 million barrels are going to be down over this period of time. 
And then, of course, we're going to switch to the winter gasoline for long. On distillates both PADD II and PADD III we are fairly balanced on distillates, the way I look at across the chain or actually say across the industry. But the key point is and I believe that the refining industry has shown pretty good results in the past that there is no need to be running inventories up that are going to cause a degradation in margins into the future, but this looks pretty good shape right now gasoline PADD II pretty good shape, it's just PADD III gasoline is a bit high.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I might have missed heard out that, but did you call out same-store gasoline sales and Speedway were down 1% in July. Do you think that's just a function of comps and if can just speak to how you see the demand trends on the gasoline site for the year.

componenttext: And that's what we said, you are right Neil. Gasoline has been a real strong contributor to Speedway over the first half of the year. And I think somewhat can be timing as you know, weather has been outstanding across most of the markets, so far early in Q3 here. So I would say a bit more timing, I know Tony is on the line, Tony would you like to add what you're seeing in across the market.

componenttext: Yes, you're right the weather that is driving traffic we're seeing some nice benefits inside the store. On the volume though, I think the comment about the comps that you're hurdling from last July, pretty significant, we're close to 2% up last year and that's a big, it's a relative to both years performance isn't all that bad.

componenttext: On the MPLX so we'll see when the market opens in 2 minutes where the yield MPLX goes. But I mean, do you think the yield that MPLX is now low enough forbidden mine probably to get on the front foot growing projects at this cost of capital, assuming that the upstream customers are do it and then also to start dropping down for cash.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's kind of a soft question Ed, I think the yields where should be. No, I think the yields should be much lower than where it is, based on the tremendous of assets, both drop-down assets and organic assets. And then the other thing that we pointed out
componenttext:
That's kind of a soft question Ed, I think the yields where should be. No, I think the yields should be much lower than where it is, based on the tremendous of assets, both drop-down assets and organic assets. And then the other thing that we pointed out in the release this morning is we've indicated a double-digit growth in 2017, and we have not talked about that previously
So I think that with the increase we just had in MPLX with the expectations of growth in 2017, with the success that we've had and what we believe will be growing volumes in our base business. And then the other key to watch within MPLX as well, if you look at our capacity utilization, as commodity prices improve, we have a tremendous amount of basically free space to be able to fill up some of the capacity that we already have invested in, that will fall directly to the bottom line. 
So we're expecting that, our yield as well as continue to improve with the solid performance again, that we have had a balance sheet are in good order. But in order to be able to make a real step improvement in being able to drop-down more at favorable multiples, we expect to be more competitive in the yield going forward.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I was just guessing at the point obviously there's been an improvement in cash this quarter, obviously part of it is and working capital But if you can start dropping down cash you can start to build cash at MPC level drive of PCF per unit up and also the buyback stocks just trying to get a sense of when that process might start in your opinion.

componenttextpreview: You are absolutely, right and as we stated earlier, we are in very good shape, and we do need to have another drop here in '16. But we'll continue to see how the markets perform. And we can always if we need to. But I think we're in very good shape as we
componenttext: You are absolutely, right and as we stated earlier, we are in very good shape, and we do need to have another drop here in '16. But we'll continue to see how the markets perform. And we can always if we need to. But I think we're in very good shape as we said.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is just on the synergy capital progress, I mean obviously that's a big chunk of potential future EBITDA $6 billion to $9 billion. I mean, obviously the industry is not on the front foot yet, but I mean sure a lot of work in the backg
componenttext: And then my follow-up is just on the synergy capital progress, I mean obviously that's a big chunk of potential future EBITDA $6 billion to $9 billion. I mean, obviously the industry is not on the front foot yet, but I mean sure a lot of work in the background, so maybe just give us a bit of color on I guess you got 9 projects, how those projects maybe not each one, but how these projects in aggregate are coming on.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is down we are very focused on promising number of those projects. And as we think about the ones that we have sort of prioritize, the first priority is to help move NGL to the East Coast. So we think about our producer customer, they are seeing
componenttext:
Yes, this is down we are very focused on promising number of those projects. And as we think about the ones that we have sort of prioritize, the first priority is to help move NGL to the East Coast. So we think about our producer customer, they are seeing some optimism in terms of NGL pricing and improvement in NGL pricing, but the flat prices pricing is the only issue for our producer customers in the Utica Marshall basin it's been the differential that they've been experiencing to like Bellevue pricing.
So very focused on moving NGL's to the East Coast, and I can say that project is probably the 1 that's for ahead in terms of a in-service date and getting a solution. We're also looking at moving NGL's to the Gulf Coast and have been in regular discussion with our partner, enterprise on Centennial and evaluating the feasibility of a reversal of Centennial. And then the third major project that we have been spending a lot of time on is a project to a butane to alkylate project, that would likely be position somewhere near our processing facilities in the Utica Marcella's, and that would allow us to convert butane to alkylate and a while our producer customers to see an uplift in their overall valuation. 
But that's a big project. That's a multiyear -- would be a multi year and I would say heavy part of the engineering right now in terms of evaluating that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Gary and maybe for Tim, certainly back on the repurchases for this quarter. Obviously there was the big working capital benefit and the cash balance was up pretty significantly on a sequential basis. Can you talk about why there weren't more repurchases, is it a matter of that working capital potentially reversing next quarter?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well again, anytime we're making decisions on the liquidity position, where we are positioned it also incorporates sort of how we see things playing out from the forecast basis over the coming months and quarters. So I think we're sort of mindful that, th
componenttext:
Well again, anytime we're making decisions on the liquidity position, where we are positioned it also incorporates sort of how we see things playing out from the forecast basis over the coming months and quarters. So I think we're sort of mindful that, the working capital benefit obviously is a big function of where actually crude prices are and how quickly they move. 
So a lot of what -- and frankly, a lot of what was done from cash basis was done as really sort of a prefunding for capital spend, we would have expected MPLX over the course of the year. So that capital rates was less about trying to build into a new capital a big cash position that could be spent in more really taking care of the needs of the partnership over the back of the year. We did pay down some of the that and just open some capacity, but it's really I would say most of the proceeds that we're spoken for it at this point and probably not go back in performance share purchase.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in the prepared comments you talked about the Phase I of the STAR project coming online and the $80 million in EBITDA. I'm curious is that all EBITDA that comes online when you guys put the switch on that or is -- has some of that been seen in pr
componenttext: And then in the prepared comments you talked about the Phase I of the STAR project coming online and the $80 million in EBITDA. I'm curious is that all EBITDA that comes online when you guys put the switch on that or is -- has some of that been seen in previous quarters and additionally, what's the underlying assumption for that $80 million in EBITDA, is that a current cracks or is that some sort of five-year average number.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is I'll take a shot answering that question. The $80 million of EBITDA is on an annualized basis. So as Gary mentioned, we're bringing on Phase I of start of this year, which is actually 2 parts of that. 1 part that we did a few months ago, wher
componenttext: Yes, this is I'll take a shot answering that question. The $80 million of EBITDA is on an annualized basis. So as Gary mentioned, we're bringing on Phase I of start of this year, which is actually 2 parts of that. 1 part that we did a few months ago, where Asphalt units, we essentially did a project in its original purpose to the asphalt And then, as Gary said, by the end of next month, we'll have a rest of that project completed, but we're actually expanded by 12,000 barrels a day. So those 2 parts together lead to a combined EBITDA contribution of $80 million a year. And we continue to look at this economics on a point forward basis and we're still good based on the assumptions here that's in that range.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeff Dietert from Siemens.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeff Dietert from Siemens.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on as you look at your linear program models what the current margin environment, it looks to continue to drive relatively strong throughput for your guidance. How is the LP evolving, still maximizing summer grade gasoline, is there -- are there
componenttext: Question on as you look at your linear program models what the current margin environment, it looks to continue to drive relatively strong throughput for your guidance. How is the LP evolving, still maximizing summer grade gasoline, is there -- are there any regions where you're shifting to a more distillate based yield, and there has been some commentary about shifting to winter grade gasoline production. Could you talk about how the current pricing is shaping up for you?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is and I'll take a shot at that question to the asset -- a couple of different things here, first regarding the LP model, yes, we do run the LP model on a weekly basis and we look at our crude a and our product mix and determine what we're goin
componenttext:
Sure, this is and I'll take a shot at that question to the asset -- a couple of different things here, first regarding the LP model, yes, we do run the LP model on a weekly basis and we look at our crude a and our product mix and determine what we're going to make at what rate, and we'll only run to what economic for us, makes economic sense for us.
Regarding distillate and gasoline and winter grade production, right now we're producing summer grade and we have a about 2 months before we can legally sell start selling higher gasoline to our customers. So we're still in that mode. 
Now as far as this led to gasoline, as you know, the economics have changed frequently and right now permanently we're pointed towards diesel. And just to give you a little flavor, we have about 10% swing that we have the ability to swing back and forth on our swing between gasoline and diesel.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And secondly, product exports have been an important part for your strategy. Could you talk about what you saw on second quarter product exports and perhaps give of you on early 3Q outlook on exporting products?
componenttext: Great. And secondly, product exports have been an important part for your strategy. Could you talk about what you saw on second quarter product exports and perhaps give of you on early 3Q outlook on exporting products?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Jeff, it's Mike. I'll be happy to talk about exports. If you look at the second quarter of '16, we have exports of 325,000 barrels a day. So exports were strong. Things looked very good for us in the second quarter. When we look around the marke
componenttext:
Yes, it's Jeff, it's Mike. I'll be happy to talk about exports. If you look at the second quarter of '16, we have exports of 325,000 barrels a day. So exports were strong. Things looked very good for us in the second quarter. When we look around the markets, most of the strength was in Latin America. Although, and obviously we're well situated to supply Latin America due to the proximity. 
But we're also finding that we've had diesel cargos that are making its way over here. So that part has been more difficult, but still works under certain circumstances. 
So we see the exports been strong, we have no reason to believe that will change it on in the third quarter. The first quarter was a little light due to the supply, really to turnaround activity, but things continue to go very well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just couple of questions I guess, 1 on the crude slate it looks like you ran a really high percentage at WTI-based crudes  and the Gulf Coast in 2Q relative to recent history that's bit surprising given the TI spreads. Can talk about that, and also it loo
componenttext: Just couple of questions I guess, 1 on the crude slate it looks like you ran a really high percentage at WTI-based crudes  and the Gulf Coast in 2Q relative to recent history that's bit surprising given the TI spreads. Can talk about that, and also it looks like the heavy and medium differentials of narrowed presented particularly percentage basis. What's your outlook there on the dynamics on heavier crude markets going forward?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well actually, Mike Palmer again  With regard to your second question first I guess, with regards to sour crude. We're finding a lot of opportunities in the sour crude right now. Not only in the Gulf of Mexico, where if you look at those spreads over the
componenttext:
Well actually, Mike Palmer again  With regard to your second question first I guess, with regards to sour crude. We're finding a lot of opportunities in the sour crude right now. Not only in the Gulf of Mexico, where if you look at those spreads over the last 6 months, discounted to LLS in the range of $5 to $6, it's been pretty stable, we see that continuing, the sour crude in the Gulf are still growing and we see really good value there. coming in, we're also seeing some really good opportunities worldwide. We're bringing in more spot, sour cargoes then typically we have been able to find value in. 
And because Galveston Bay and Gary Will have the ability to run the heavy more difficult crude, high 10 crudes. That's what we tend to focus on because that's where we get the discount. So we see that continuing to go forward. 
In terms of the additional WTI kind of base crudes that's going to shift back and forth depending on what's happening at the plants, what crudes were really optimizing kind of an dailyi basis. And between the WTI and the base crudes. So I don't think there's anything structurally in the market there, it's just part of the overall optimization.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was the right question, if you look at our slate, because we talked about the same of last year. Last year, we were running about 55% of sour, this year we ran a little over 61%. So we have the ability to swing back and forth due to the composition of
componenttext: It was the right question, if you look at our slate, because we talked about the same of last year. Last year, we were running about 55% of sour, this year we ran a little over 61%. So we have the ability to swing back and forth due to the composition of our refineries and take advantage whatever the best margins are in the market. So 61% is 1 of the highest percentages of sour we run for sometime. So I just want to give you those parameters.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really high. But are you seeing Canadian barrels back to normal levels of availability at this point. And I guess, on the Gulf coast, just from the Latin America barrels, any concerns about the steel production declines we're seeing in Mexico, Colo
componenttext: That's really high. But are you seeing Canadian barrels back to normal levels of availability at this point. componenttext:
We have had a hard time trying to make sense of a lot of the Venezuela crudes sometime there, they are not very dependable and they have been declining. So I don't -- I would say that we really haven't had a big focus on much of the Latin American crudes. There are some out of Columbia that, I mean, a lot of sense for us, but it's not -- we don't really see that as a big deal.
We're seeing -- we're seeing more interest in for examples some of the Middle East heavy crudes. With regard to Canadian yes, the wildfires situation is behind us now and we've seen the Canadian spreads return back to normal, they look a lot more attractive to us and they did before. As you know, the Canadian heavy with these projects that were sanctioned prior to this fall in crude prices. Those projects continue, so the Canadian heavy continues to grow. And we see a lot of value in the Canadian heavy.

componenttext:
Well again, the focus around capital return and how we do that is going to continuing the business for as long as we can imagine. How we balance that, I think the key part Roger is may be as you alluded to a little bit of that, this is really going to a balanced approach and I think we're not inclined to go all in on for investment, we're not intending to go all full share repurchase, it's really going to be sort of finding that balances in the business, based on what the earnings looks like, what the cash flow generation could be and exactly where we find ourselves financially at each point in time. 
So again, as I referenced earlier, this really becomes to the flywheel as we evaluate exactly how we want to position the business from a capital allocation perspective, we expect a level of activity will be there and could vary in different periods in time, but would be an important part of our balance approach and the capital allocation side.

Paul, clearly, we need to have our best interest, which we continue to strive forward as we appeal for the full standard, but knowing that, that is a heavy lift, there has been a build out and reduced on the floor is bill that would limit blending at 9.7%, which really takes into account they need gas rates in the market as well. We think that needs to be supportive a tremendous amount of support, already inside the house on this bill and we need to get others on schedule as well.
The rent prices, you're right. Upwards $0.95, $0.98, I know they hit $1 over the last couple of weeks. And it's a, and I think -- I don't think I know the reason is because the markets understanding that we're going to be very close and probably will tip over the 10% ethanol blend wall this year. Therefore, rents are going to be at the demand for rents are going to outpace the supply. The steps that we have taken over the years as it illustrated as well in this morning's comments is that, we're in very good shape and we're fairly balanced on the rent side, but nevertheless, we want a significant amendment or of renewable fuel standards and are working very hard towards that are in a direction.
