componenttext:
Welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call for Marathon Petroleum Corporation. My name is Katie, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
And I will now turn the call to Lisa Wilson, Director of Investor Relations.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Webcast and Conference Call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab. O
componenttext:
Thank you, Katie. Welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Webcast and Conference Call. The synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com, under the Investor Center tab. On the call today are Gary Heminger, Chairman, President and CEO; Tim Griffith, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and other members of MPC's executive team.
We invite you to read the safe harbor statements on Slide 2. It is a reminder that we will be making forward-looking statements during the call and during the question-and-answer session. Actual results may differ materially from what we expect today. Factors that could cause actual results to differ are included there as well as in our filings with the SEC. 
Now I will turn the call over to Gary Heminger for opening remarks and highlights.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lisa, and good morning to everyone. Thank you for joining us. If you please turn to Slide 3.Earlier today, we reported second quarter earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per diluted share. Earnings included a net benefit of $0.44 per share, primar
componenttext:
Thanks, Lisa, and good morning to everyone. Thank you for joining us. If you please turn to Slide 3.
Earlier today, we reported second quarter earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per diluted share. Earnings included a net benefit of $0.44 per share, primarily related to a reversal of our lower of cost or market inventory valuation reserve. All segments of the business performed well in the second quarter. Earnings benefited from improving crack spreads, robust product demand entering the summer driving and asphalt season, strong retail margins and the inclusion of MarkWest in our consolidated results. 
The Refining & Marketing segment delivered strong results despite less favorable operating and market conditions during the quarter. Our integrated  7-refinery and extensive logistics network allows us to capture advantage feedstock and other raw materials, as well as enhanced price realizations to our refined product distribution system.
Our unique asset mix and flexibility position us to optimize the operations even during this disruptions, such as those caused in the second quarter by the Canadian wildfires and refinery outages.
Speedway continued its outstanding performance with a record second quarter segment income. In addition, to higher light product sales volume and margins, the business delivered higher merchandise margins in the quarter.
This improvement is consistent with the strategy to drive marketing enhancement opportunities. We are pleased with our progress in realizing synergies across the Speedway network, earlier than originally planned and believe this will be a continuing source of value to the business.
Speedway provides significant and growing stable cash flow, complementing MPC's integrated refining and distribution network. Speedway is MPC's most ratable distribution channel, provides a solid base to enhance overall supply reliability and allows us to optimize our entire refining, pipeline and terminal operations.
The Midstream segment including MPLX financial and operational results also delivered solid performance during the quarter. MPLX remains on target to achieve its 2016 distribution growth guidance without the need for additional drop-downs from MPC during the year. 
During the quarter, MPLX expanded its Midstream presence in the Southwest with the completion of its Hidalgo gas processing complex in the Delaware Basin, where utilization is exceeding initial expectations.
Construction of the Cornerstone Pipeline is also progressing as planned, with completion expected in the fourth quarter. Cornerstone Pipeline is designed to provide MPC's Canton, Ohio refinery with a direct supply of condensate out of the Marcellus and Utica regions and to supply natural gasoline to our Midwest refineries. 
As commodity prices recover -- excuse me, optimism is growing among MPLX's producer customers, and with world-class midstream assets located in some of the best resource plays in the country, MPLX is well-positioned to capitalize on an exceptional set of opportunities along the entire hydrocarbon value chain. 
As we enter the third quarter, both heavy and light Canadian crude differentials have returned to more favorable levels, as the impact of the Canadian wildfires subsided.
Canadian heavy production continues to grow and we expect good values throughout the third and fourth quarters. Additionally, we expect to continue to see spot opportunities in foreign sweet and sour cargoes. The regional diversity of our refining assets also enables us to benefit from access to the export market. We believe we have the right assets in the right locations with 60% of our crude oil refining capacity in the Gulf Coast and 40% in the Midwest.
We also expect to complete the first phase of our multi-year STAR program at the Galveston Bay refinery in Texas City next month. This phase will revamp and expand the resid hydrocracker by 12,000 barrels per day, improving the profitability of the refinery by increasing the conversion of lower value residual oil into gas oil. The EBITDA contribution from this initial phase is expected to average approximately $80 million per year.
During the second quarter, we returned $221 million to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. In addition, on July 27 our Board of Directors announced a 12.5% increase in the quarterly dividend to $0.36 per share. That 29% compound annual growth rate in our dividends since MPC became an independent company, demonstrates our continuing confidence in the cash flow generation of the business.
It also demonstrates our long-term focus on capital returns, while maintaining an investment grade credit profile and strong liquidity throughout the cycle.
The efficiency and flexibility of our integrated retail, logistics and refining systems drives the diversified earnings power of our business and we remain encouraged by the long-term prospects of our business and the value proposition for our investors. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Tim to walk you through the financial results for the quarter. Tim?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings in both on absolute and per share basis. MPC's second quarter 2016 earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per diluted share were down slightly from last year's second quarter earnings of $826 million. We refer to the $0.
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Slide 4 provides earnings in both on absolute and per share basis. MPC's second quarter 2016 earnings of $801 million or $1.51 per diluted share were down slightly from last year's second quarter earnings of $826 million. We refer to the $0.44 per share net benefit in the quarter, which included the benefit of $0.47 per diluted share related to the reversal of the lower of cost or market inventory valuation reserve, and a charge of $0.03 per diluted share related to the impairment of 1 MPLX's equity investments.
The chart on Slide 5 shows by segment the change in earnings in the second quarter of last year. As mentioned, earnings were impacted during the quarter by a $385 million pretax benefit to fully reverse our lower of cost or market reserve. $360 million of this benefit is included in the Refining & Marketing segment, and $25 million is reflected in the Speedway segment.
After adjusting for this benefit, earnings were down approximately $410 million over the same quarter last year, largely attributable to lower income from our Refining & Marketing segment, higher interest expense resulting from the MarkWest merger and the equity impairment I just mentioned.
These negative impacts for the quarter were partially offset by higher income contributed by our midstream and Speedway segments and lower income taxes.
Turning to Slide 6, our Refining & Marketing segment reported income from operations of almost $1.1 billion in the second quarter compared to the income from operations of $1.2 billion in the same quarter last year. The decrease after excluding the $360 million benefit from the LTM reversal was primarily due to weaker crack spreads in both the Gulf Coast in Chicago and narrow LLS-WTI differential, less favorable market structure and higher cost related returner activity in the second quarter.
Partially offsetting these negative impacts was an improvement in the sweet/sour differential in the quarter. The lower blended crack spread had a negative impact in earnings of approximately $502 million, the blended crack spread was $2.58 per barrel lower at $7.66 per barrel in the second quarter of 2016 compared to $10.24 per barrel in the same period last year.
R&M segment income benefited $227 million by an approximately $2 per barrel widening of the sweet/sour differential as well as higher sour runs in the quarter versus last year. The LLS-WTI differential narrowed $3.25 per barrel from $4.99 per barrel in the second quarter of 2015 to $1.74 per barrel in the second quarter of this year. Which had a negative impact in earnings of about $100 million based on the WTI linked crudes in our slate.
The market structure contango effect during the quarter is reflected $78 million unfavorable variance on the walk and it relates to the difference between the prompt crude prices we use for market metrics and the actual crude acquisition cost in the quarter.
The $70 million increase year-over-year in direct operating costs relate primarily a higher turn around activity in the quarter versus last year. Turnaround and major maintenance cost increased $0.50 per barrel or over $80 million compared to second quarter of 2015. The higher turnaround activity also impacted total throughputs, which was 62,000 barrels per day lower than the second quarter last year. 
Capture rate for the quarter was negatively impacted by the effect of rising crude oil prices on wholesale and secondary product margins, narrow crude differentials and tighter differentials on feedstocks relative to crude. 
Turning to our other segments. Slide 7 provides the Speedway segment earnings walk versus the same quarter last year. As Gary mentioned, Speedway had a record second quarter earnings of $193 million; which was up to $66 million higher than the second quarter of 2015. 
Light product margin was a significant contributor to this increase, along with higher merchandise gross margin and the $25 million reversal of Speedways lower of cost or market inventory reserves in the quarter.
Gasoline and distillate margins were about $0.02 higher in the second quarter of last year, then in the second quarter of last year at $0.15.5 per gallon, while volumes were up $33 million-gallon quarter-over-quarter. On a same-store basis, gasoline sales volumes increased over 0.3% over the same period last year. 
Merchandise gross margin was $10 million higher than the second quarter last year due to overall higher merchandise sales and the higher margins realized on those sales. Merchandise sales in the quarter, excluding cigarettes increased 2% on a same-store year-over-year basis, reflecting some of the progress we're making on enhancing our merchandise model across the entire business.
In July, we've seen a decrease in gasoline demand with approximately 1% decrease in the same-store gasoline sales volumes compared to last July.  Which you may recall was a very strong month in 2015.
Speedway same-store gasoline sales growth was lower than estimated U.S. demand growth, as we continually strive to optimize total gasoline contributions between volume and margin to ensure fuel margins remain adequate.
Slide 8 provides the changes in Midstream segment income versus the second quarter last year. The $98 million increase quarter-over-quarter was primarily due to the combination of MarkWest at the end of last year, which contributed $81 million of the incremental segment income to the quarter. The remaining increase of $17 million was primarily due to an increase in income from our equity affiliates and lower operating expenses versus last year.
Slide 9 presents a significant elements of changes in our consolidated cash position in the second quarter. Cash at the end of quarter was nearly $1.8 billion, core operating cash flow was $1.2 billion source of cash. The $1 billion source of working capital noted in the slide primarily relates to an increase in accounts payable and accrued liabilities, partially offset by smaller increases in accounts receivable. 
The increases in accounts payable and receivable were primarily due to higher crude oil and refined product prices during the quarter, which led to the net source of cash given the generally longer-terms in the crude payables versus refined products.
As we discussed in the first quarter call in April, MPLX issued convertible preferred equity during the quarter, generating equity proceeds of about $984 million. 
Proceeds from this private replacement are broken out separately in the walk. MPLX used a portion of these funds to pay down its revolver, which is included in the $521 million of net debt repayment on the walk. Return of capital during the quarter included a repurchase of $51 million of worth of shares and $170 million of dividends. Share repurchase activity may vary from quarter-to-quarter based on our needs and the cash flow characteristics of our business in any particular period.
Our commitment to continue to return the capital remains a fundamental element of our strategy and important part of the value proposition for investors. Share count at the end of the quarter was approximately 528 million shares, reflecting repurchase activity of about $7.4 billion, returning approximately 28% of the outstanding shares at the time of the spend. 
In addition, as Gary mentioned earlier, the $0.36 per share dividend announced by our Board yesterday, represents a 12.5% increase over last quarter's dividend and contributes to 29% compound annual growth rate in the dividend since our spend.
Slide 10 provides an overview of the capitalization and financial profile as of the end of the quarter. We had $11.1 billion of total consolidated debt including $4.4 billion of debt at MPLX. 
Total debt to book capitalization was about 36% and represented a manageable to 2x last 12 months adjusted EBITDA of over $5.8 billion, which is pro forma for the MarkWest acquisition. 
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $1.2 billion before reflecting the $1 billion source of cash for working capital in the quarter.
Slide 11 provides updated outlook information on key operating metrics for MPC for the third quarter. We're expecting third quarter throughput volumes to be down slightly compared to third quarter 2015 due to more plant maintenance. Total direct operating costs are expected to be $7.65 per barrel on total throughput of 1.85 million barrels per day, which reflects the impact of higher expected turnaround activity in the third quarter versus our third quarter last year. Our projected third quarter corporate and other unallocated items expected to be about $75 million.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Lisa for questions.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, there's been obviously a lot of noise in the sector about the arbitrage potential value of your retail business, and I think your comments in your prepared remarks, probably underlined your thoughts. But I just wonder, if I could ask you to reiterat
componenttext: Gary, there's been obviously a lot of noise in the sector about the arbitrage potential value of your retail business, and I think your comments in your prepared remarks, probably underlined your thoughts. But I just wonder, if I could ask you to reiterate your view that retail is -- you're happy with the current structure of Speedway and the current business? And would you ever consider a separation to try and exploit the arbitrage that some others are talking about?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well Doug, as you and I have talked many times of course we look at this all the time, but as in my remarks we are very happy, and it illustrates when you have a down market like the refining sector has been in the last couple quarters. How important havi
componenttext: Well Doug, as you and I have talked many times of course we look at this all the time, but as in my remarks we are very happy, and it illustrates when you have a down market like the refining sector has been in the last couple quarters. How important having a diversified portfolio and a diversified value chain is to a business like ours. It is not only the most ratable customer within our portfolio, it's also this and our long-term strategy to grow the Midstream business as well as the retail business. Those 2 segments are becoming, I would say our most ratable cash flow streams within the business. So yes, we are happy with the structure. But yes, we continue to analyze and annualize -- analyze very critically as you call it in arbitrage. But when you look at on arbitrage Doug, you also need to understand what the integration value is. Now the integration value is, I would say proprietary. I can't give out a number from a competitive reason of that integration value, but I can say it is very significant. Especially when you look at downturns in the cycles. And as I've mentioned several times then you look again at first half of this year the EBITDA from Speedway, the first half of this year, clearly covers the total dividend and interest costs on our capital. So yes, we are happy. Yes, we continue to analyze it very carefully, but I would expect that we will continue on as we are.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that answer. Gary, I realize it's not always easy to those kind of questions. My follow up is really on the dividend. Obviously, a nice bump last night, you're now in kind of the mid-range with the peers. Going forward, what are your thoughts
componenttext: I appreciate that answer. Gary, I realize it's not always easy to those kind of questions. My follow up is really on the dividend. Obviously, a nice bump last night, you're now in kind of the mid-range with the peers. Going forward, what are your thoughts on the balance in terms of distributions between buybacks and continued dividend growth? And I will leave it there.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Tim?
componenttext: All right. Tim?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Doug, I think our thinking has been and really since the time of the spend that we would have a focus around maintaining a regular dividend that's got a growth cycle to it, that's really sort of through a cycle and it's got -- what we'd love to see i
componenttext:
Yes. Doug, I think our thinking has been and really since the time of the spend that we would have a focus around maintaining a regular dividend that's got a growth cycle to it, that's really sort of through a cycle and it's got -- what we'd love to see is sort of double-digit over an extended period of time. So that's sort of our primary focus to make sure that we sort of baselined the capital turnaround in attractive and growing dividend that has got sustainability through cycle. Share purchase for us continues to be sort of a flywheel depending on the cash needs of the business, where we sit from a core liquidity perspective, and certainly how we're viewing things. Obviously, we've taken down our capital spending plans in 2016. And I think some of the reductions that we've seen on the share purchase side has gone in parallel with really a careful look at how the year will play out and what the cash flow generation looks like. But I think it will continue to be an important source, and it will really be a function of the cash and liquidity position, we find ourselves in as we move forward.
So continued focus, I know the activity is lower in second quarter and in the first quarter than it's been over the last several years. But again, it's really just a function of what the liquidity needs of the business are at different points in time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Doug one more point to that as many leading analyst have already printed this morning, as MPLX now as gone into a good rhythm within the capital structure, their balance sheet and our growth going forward. And as we expect that the yield will continue
componenttext: And Doug one more point to that as many leading analyst have already printed this morning, as MPLX now as gone into a good rhythm within the capital structure, their balance sheet and our growth going forward. And as we expect that the yield will continue to improve within MPLX, that's going to give us that ability in the future as we have drop downs to be able to bring that cash back in and for the buy back shares. So that's a very important ingredient in our strategy as well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is some follow up to Doug's first question. And maybe a different way to partially monetize the value arbitrage. I know you filed IRS the letter not to expand the characterization wholesale EBITDA, which would add to your droppable inventory.
componenttext: My question is some follow up to Doug's first question. And maybe a different way to partially monetize the value arbitrage. I know you filed IRS the letter not to expand the characterization wholesale EBITDA, which would add to your droppable inventory. Any update there? And can you kind of dimension the potential range for expansion of what might be MLP out of what's currently characterized as retail. I would appreciate it.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well Evan, now we continue to wait on the IRS to answer our PLR. We're expecting that soon, but I don't know if that means this quarter, next quarter or the following quarter. We filed a long time ago, but still awaiting. The fuels distribution that we
componenttext:
Well Evan, now we continue to wait on the IRS to answer our PLR. We're expecting that soon, but I don't know if that means this quarter, next quarter or the following quarter. We filed a long time ago, but still awaiting. 
The fuels distribution that we discussed earlier is really I think an elegant way to consider Tim talked about a flywheel before, but that is an elegant way without getting caught up in a retail -- kind of a blocker if you will, a tax blocker to be able to drop down part of those of that value. So we need to remain in our seats and wait for the IRS to opine on our request. But we feel confident that it will go forward and I'll be able to give you a better range after we get that work back from the IRS.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I appreciate that. And the second question is on Midstream. Shell's now building a cracker in Pittsburgh. I know it's still 5 years out, it's very positive for MPC and MPLX both from volume growth and what it means for pricing and relative northeas
componenttext: Great. I appreciate that. And the second question is on Midstream. Shell's now building a cracker in Pittsburgh. I know it's still 5 years out, it's very positive for MPC and MPLX both from volume growth and what it means for pricing and relative northeast pricing. Which you could put at parity with Mont Belvieu. I mean could you discuss that project? Or how it could affect your business and maybe how you're thinking about our positioning for that today?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Evan. This is Don. We have a leading ethane position in the Marcellus and the Utica, we have invested considerable capital in the past to be able to handle ethane recovery. And our view is that there is going to be continued production of -- and grow
componenttext: Yes, Evan. This is Don. We have a leading ethane position in the Marcellus and the Utica, we have invested considerable capital in the past to be able to handle ethane recovery. And our view is that there is going to be continued production of -- and growth in ethane, which will give us an opportunity, we're estimating probably depending on where the forecasts -- where the forecasts end up. We've heard or seen forecasts that would suggest in the early 2020s that there would be 500,000 barrels per day of ethane production. And if you got to those kinds of volumes, we could anticipate having capital projects that would be in the $500 million to $1 billion range in order to be able to extract that ethane to be able to support things like the crackers, but also to support ethane needs in the Gulf Coast and also for pipelines and other projects that are taking it to the East Coast.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you comment on the state of the product markets as you see it? Inventories are elevated right now. Do you think that's a function of refining supply or demand? And how do we work our way out of this? Do you ultimately think we need to see run cu
componenttext: Gary, can you comment on the state of the product markets as you see it? Inventories are elevated right now. Do you think that's a function of refining supply or demand? And how do we work our way out of this? Do you ultimately think we need to see run cuts later this year in the world and if so, where?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Neil, that's a very prudent question. Especially if you look at the same period last year, when we were in a very strong refining market last year. But refiners ran full out and that tremendous build in excess inventories is what really led to the do
componenttext: Yes. Neil, that's a very prudent question. Especially if you look at the same period last year, when we were in a very strong refining market last year. But refiners ran full out and that tremendous build in excess inventories is what really led to the downturn in the fourth quarter and early first quarter this year because of the rapid build of inventories and the long-term to be able to run those off. When I look at the inventories, that came out yesterday Neil, in the pads where we predominantly operate, gasoline in PADD II is 2.9 million barrels over same period last year. And we were down 2 million barrels for the week. So we're in pretty good shape. The Gulf Coast is still a bit high on inventories, but Mike Palmer pointed out to me earlier today, if you look at the turnaround schedule coming up in the Gulf Coast for PAD III and early into PAD IV, it appears to be a significant turnaround and scheduled somewhere between 700,000 and 1 million barrels are going to be down over this period of time. And then, of course, we're going to switch to the winter grade gasoline before long. On distillates, both PADD II and PADD III we're fairly balanced on distillates. The way I look at across the chain or I should say across the industry. But the key point is and I believe that the refining industry has shown pretty good resolve in the past that there is no need to be running inventories up that are going to cause a degradation in margins into the future. But let's say, this looks pretty good shape right now, gasoline PADD II were in good shape, it's just PADD III gasoline is a bit high.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might have misheard out that, but I think -- did you call out same-store gasoline stales and Speedway were down 1% in July. Do you think that's just a function of comps? And if you could just speak to how you see the demand trends on the gasoline side f
componenttext: I might have misheard out that, but I think -- did you call out same-store gasoline stales and Speedway were down 1% in July. Do you think that's just a function of comps? And if you could just speak to how you see the demand trends on the gasoline side for the balance of the year.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's what we said, you are right Neil. Gasoline has been a real strong contributor to Speedway over the first half of the year. And I think somewhat can be timing. As you know, weather has been outstanding across most of the markets so far early in
componenttext: And that's what we said, you are right Neil. Gasoline has been a real strong contributor to Speedway over the first half of the year. And I think somewhat can be timing. As you know, weather has been outstanding across most of the markets so far early in Q3 here. So I would say a bit more timing. I know Tony is on the line. Tony, would you like to add what you're seeing across the market?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You're right about the weather. That is driving traffic. We're seeing some nice benefits inside the store. On the volume though, I think the comment about the comps that we're hurdling from last July, fairly significant, we're close to 2% up last yea
componenttext: Yes. You're right about the weather. That is driving traffic. We're seeing some nice benefits inside the store. On the volume though, I think the comment about the comps that we're hurdling from last July, fairly significant, we're close to 2% up last year. And that's a big -- it's a relative to both years' performance isn't all that bad.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats also on the MPLX raise. So we'll see when the market opens in 2 minutes where the yield on MPLX goes. But I mean, do you think the yield that MPLX is now low enough bearing in mind you got the IDRs to get on the front foot growing projects at thi
componenttext: Congrats also on the MPLX raise. So we'll see when the market opens in 2 minutes where the yield on MPLX goes. But I mean, do you think the yield that MPLX is now low enough bearing in mind you got the IDRs to get on the front foot growing projects at this cost of capital? Assuming that the upstream customers are there to do it. And then also to start dropping down for cash.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's kind of a softball question Ed on whether I think the yields are where it should be. No, I think the yields should be much lower than where it is based on the tremendous suite of assets, both drop-down assets and organic assets. And then the other
componenttext: That's kind of a softball question Ed on whether I think the yields are where it should be. No, I think the yields should be much lower than where it is based on the tremendous suite of assets, both drop-down assets and organic assets. And then the other thing that we pointed out in the release this morning is we've indicated a double-digit growth in 2017, and we have not talked about that previously. So I think that with the increase we just had in MPLX, with the expectations of growth in 2017, with the success that we've had and what we believe we'll be growing volumes in our base business. And the other key to watch within MPLX, as well that is, if you look at our capacity utilization, as commodity prices improve, we have a tremendous amount of basically, free space to be able to fill up some of the capacity that we already have invested in, that will fall directly to the bottom line. So we're expecting that our yield is going to continue to improve with the solid performance again that we've had. Our balance sheets are in good order. But in order to be able to make a real step improvement and being able to drop-down more at favorable multiples, we expect to be more competitive in the yield going forward.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just guess -- I was trying to get to the point that obviously, there's been an improvement in cash this quarter. Obviously, part of it is the pre-vert and working capital release. But if you can start dropping down for cash you can start to build ca
componenttext: I was just guess -- I was trying to get to the point that obviously, there's been an improvement in cash this quarter. Obviously, part of it is the pre-vert and working capital release. But if you can start dropping down for cash you can start to build cash at MPC level drive the LP/DCF per unit up and also then obviously buyback stocks. So just trying to get a sense of when that process might start in your opinion?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You are absolutely, right and as we stated earlier, we are in very good shape. We don't need to have another drop here in '16. But we'll continue to see how the markets perform. And we can always pivot if we need to. But I think we're in very good shape a
componenttext: You are absolutely, right and as we stated earlier, we are in very good shape. We don't need to have another drop here in '16. But we'll continue to see how the markets perform. And we can always pivot if we need to. But I think we're in very good shape as we said.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is just on the synergy capital progress. I mean, obviously that's a big chunk of potential future EBITDA $6 billion to $9 billion. I mean, obviously industry is not on the front foot yet, but I'm sure you're doing a lot of work in th
componenttext: And then my follow-up is just on the synergy capital progress. I mean, obviously that's a big chunk of potential future EBITDA $6 billion to $9 billion. I mean, obviously industry is not on the front foot yet, but I'm sure you're doing a lot of work in the background. So maybe just give us a bit of color on I guess, you got 9 projects. How those projects -- maybe not each one, but how those projects in aggregates are coming on?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Don. We are very focused on progressing a number of those projects. And as we think about the ones that we have sort of prioritized, the first priority is to help move NGLs to the East Coast. So we think about our producer customers, they are
componenttext: Yes, this is Don. We are very focused on progressing a number of those projects. And as we think about the ones that we have sort of prioritized, the first priority is to help move NGLs to the East Coast. So we think about our producer customers, they are seeing some optimism in terms of NGL pricing and improvement in NGL pricing, but the flat price isn't the only issue for our producer customers in the Utica, Marcellus in that basin. It's been the differential that they've been experiencing to like Mont Belvieu pricing. So very focused on moving NGLs to the East Coast, and I can say that project is probably the 1 that's furthest ahead in terms of a in-service date and getting a solution. We're also looking at moving NGLs to the Gulf Coast and have been in regular discussion with our partner enterprise on Centennial and evaluating the feasibility of a reversal of Centennial. And then the third major project that we've been spending a lot of time on is a project to a butane to alkylate project that would likely be positioned somewhere near our processing facilities in the Utica, Marcellus. And that would allow us to convert butane to alkylate and allow our producer customers to see an uplift in their overall valuation. But that's a big project. That's a multiyear -- would be a multiyear project and we're in -- I would say, the heavy part of the engineering right now. In terms of evaluating that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary or maybe for Tim, circling back on repurchases for this quarter. Obviously there was the big working capital benefit and the cash balance was up pretty significantly on a sequential basis. Can you talk about why there weren't more repurchases? Is it
componenttext: Gary or maybe for Tim, circling back on repurchases for this quarter. Obviously there was the big working capital benefit and the cash balance was up pretty significantly on a sequential basis. Can you talk about why there weren't more repurchases? Is it a matter of that working capital potentially reversing next quarter?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well again, anytime we're making decisions on the liquidity position, where we are positioned it also incorporates sort of how we see things playing out from the forecast basis over the coming months and quarters. So I think we're sort of mindful that, th
componenttext: Well again, anytime we're making decisions on the liquidity position, where we are positioned it also incorporates sort of how we see things playing out from the forecast basis over the coming months and quarters. So I think we're sort of mindful that, the working capital benefit obviously is a big function of where absolute crude prices are at and how quickly they move. So a lot of what -- and frankly, a lot of what was done from cash basis was done as really sort of a prefunding for capital spend. We would have expected MPLX over the course of the year. So that capital raise was less about trying to build into a big capital, a big cash position that could be spent and more about really taking care of the needs of the partnership over the back half of the year. We did pay down some of the debt again and just opened up some capacity. But it's really I would say most of the proceeds that were brought in are sort of spoken for it at this point. And would probably not go back in the former share purchase.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then in the prepared comments you talked about the Phase I of the STAR project coming online and the $80 million in EBITDA. I'm curious is that all EBITDA that comes online when you guys flip the switch on that? Or is -- has some of
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then in the prepared comments you talked about the Phase I of the STAR project coming online and the $80 million in EBITDA. I'm curious is that all EBITDA that comes online when you guys flip the switch on that? Or is -- has some of that's been seen in previous quarters? And additionally, what's the underlying assumption for that $80 million in EBITDA? Is that at current cracks or is that some sort of five-year average number?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Ray Brooks. I'll take a shot answering that question. The $80 million of EBITDA is on an annualized basis. So as Gary mentioned, we're bringing on Phase I of STAR this year, which is actually 2 parts of that. 1 part that we did a few months a
componenttext: Yes, this is Ray Brooks. I'll take a shot answering that question. The $80 million of EBITDA is on an annualized basis. So as Gary mentioned, we're bringing on Phase I of STAR this year, which is actually 2 parts of that. 1 part that we did a few months ago, where we send the asphalting unit. We essentially did a project to turn that into its original purpose to be asphalt resid. And then, as Gary said, by the end of next month we'll have the rest of that project completed. But we're actually expanded by 12,000 barrels a day. So those 2 parts together lead to a combined EBITDA contribution of $80 million a year. And we continue to look at this economics on a point-forward basis and we're still good based on the assumptions here that it's in that range.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeff Dietert from Simmons.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeff Dietert from Simmons.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on as you look at your linear program models with the current margin environment, it looks to continue to drive relatively strong throughput per your guidance. How is the LP evolving, still maximizing summer grade gasoline? Is there -- are there
componenttext: Question on as you look at your linear program models with the current margin environment, it looks to continue to drive relatively strong throughput per your guidance. How is the LP evolving, still maximizing summer grade gasoline? Is there -- are there any regions where you're shifting to a more distillate based yield? And there's been some commentary about shifting to winter grade gasoline production. Could you talk about how the current pricing is shaping up for you.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Ray Brooks and I'll take a shot at that question too. The asset -- a couple of different things here. First regarding the LP model, yes, we do run the LP model on a weekly basis and we look at our crude avails and our product mix and determi
componenttext: Sure. This is Ray Brooks and I'll take a shot at that question too. The asset -- a couple of different things here. First regarding the LP model, yes, we do run the LP model on a weekly basis and we look at our crude avails and our product mix and determined what we're going to make and at what rate. And we will only run to what's economic for us, makes economic sense for us. Regarding distill and gasoline and winter grade production, right now we're producing summer grade. And we have about 2 months before we can legally sell -- start selling higher gasoline -- vapor pressure gasoline to our customers. So we're still in that mode. Now as far as distillate to gasoline, as you know, the economics interchange frequently and right now predominantly we're pointed towards diesel. And just to give you a little flavor, we have about 10% swing -- that we have the ability to swing back and forth on our swing straints between gasoline and diesel.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And secondly, product exports have been an important part for your strategy. Could you talk about what you saw on second quarter product exports and perhaps give a view on early 3Q outlook on exporting products?
componenttext: Great. And secondly, product exports have been an important part for your strategy. Could you talk about what you saw on second quarter product exports and perhaps give a view on early 3Q outlook on exporting products?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. It's Mike Palmer. I'd be happy to talk a little bit about exports. If you look at the second quarter of '16, we have exports of 325,000 barrels a day. So exports were strong. Things looked very good for us in the second quarter. When we look ar
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. It's Mike Palmer. I'd be happy to talk a little bit about exports. If you look at the second quarter of '16, we have exports of 325,000 barrels a day. So exports were strong. Things looked very good for us in the second quarter. When we look around the market, most of the strength was in Latin America. Although -- and obviously we're well situated to supply Latin America due to the proximity. But we're also finding that we've had diesel cargoes that are making its way over Europe. So that ARB has been more difficult, but still works under certain circumstances. So we see the exports been strong. We have no reason to believe that, that will change at all in the third quarter. The first quarter was a little light due to supply, really -- due to turnaround activity, but things continue to go very well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering, Holt.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just couple of questions I guess. 1 on the crude slate. It looks like you ran a really high percentage at WTI-based crudes in the Gulf Coast in 2Q relative to recent history. That's bit surprising given the TI spreads. Can you talk about that? And also, i
componenttext: Just couple of questions I guess. 1 on the crude slate. It looks like you ran a really high percentage at WTI-based crudes in the Gulf Coast in 2Q relative to recent history. That's bit surprising given the TI spreads. Can you talk about that? And also, it looks like the heavy and medium sour crude differentials have narrowed recently. Particularly on a percentage basis. What's your outlook there on the dynamics on the heavier crude markets going forward?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chi. Mike Palmer again. With regard to your second question first I guess, with regard to sour crude. We're finding a lot of opportunities in sour crude right now. Not only in the Gulf of Mexico, where if you look at those spreads over the last 6 mon
componenttext: Yes, Chi. Mike Palmer again. With regard to your second question first I guess, with regard to sour crude. We're finding a lot of opportunities in sour crude right now. Not only in the Gulf of Mexico, where if you look at those spreads over the last 6 months, Mars has been discounted to LLS in the range of $5 to $6. It's been pretty stable, we see that continuing, the sour crudes in the Gulf are still growing. And we see really good value there. With the ARB coming in, we're also seeing some really good opportunities worldwide. We're bringing in more spot, sour cargoes than typically we have been able to find value in. And because Galveston Bay and Garyville have the ability to run the heavy, more difficult crudes, high TAN crudes. That's what we tend to focus on because that's where we get the discount. So we see that continuing to go forward.  In terms of the additional WTI kind of base crudes, that's going to shift back and forth depending on what's happening at the plants, what crudes were really optimizing kind of an daily basis. And between the WTI and the LLS base crudes. So I don't think there's anything structural in the market there. It's just part of the overall optimization.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was the right question, if you look at our slate, because we talked about this same last year. Last year, we were running about 55% of sour, this year we ran a little over 61%. So we have the ability to swing back and forth due to the composition of ou
componenttext: It was the right question, if you look at our slate, because we talked about this same last year. Last year, we were running about 55% of sour, this year we ran a little over 61%. So we have the ability to swing back and forth due to the composition of our refineries and take advantage wherever the best margins are in the market. So 61% is 1 of the highest percentages of sour we've run for some time. So I just want to give you those parameters.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really high. But are you seeing Canadian barrels back to normal levels of availability at this point? And I guess, on the Gulf coast, just from the Latin America barrels, any concerns about the steep production and climbs we're seeing in Mexico, Co
componenttext: That's really high. But are you seeing Canadian barrels back to normal levels of availability at this point? And I guess, on the Gulf coast, just from the Latin America barrels, any concerns about the steep production and climbs we're seeing in Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela, on the heavier crude availability out of those regions?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've had a hard time trying to make sense of a lot of the Venezuelan crudes for sometimes there. They are not very dependable and they have been declining. So I don't -- I would say that we really haven't had a big focus on much of the Latin American cru
componenttext: We've had a hard time trying to make sense of a lot of the Venezuelan crudes for sometimes there. They are not very dependable and they have been declining. So I don't -- I would say that we really haven't had a big focus on much of the Latin American crudes. There are some out of Columbia that have made a lot of sense for us. But it's not -- we don't really see that is a big deal. We've seen more interest in, for example, some of the Middle Eastern heavy crudes. With regard to Canadian yes, the wildfire situation is behind us now. And we've seen the Canadian spreads return back to normal. They look a lot more attractive to us than they did before. As you know, the Canadian heavy with these projects that were sanctioned prior to this fall in crude prices, those projects continue. So the Canadian heavy continues to grow. And we see a lot of value in the Canadian heavy.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then 1 question on the potential drop of the fuels' distribution margin. When you look at that, I guess, what happens to the RIN? If hypothetically you do drop the fuels distribution margin down. Does the RIN go with it or does the RIN stay with the M
componenttext: And then 1 question on the potential drop of the fuels' distribution margin. When you look at that, I guess, what happens to the RIN? If hypothetically you do drop the fuels distribution margin down. Does the RIN go with it or does the RIN stay with the MPC level?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The RIN would -- we would expect Chi, that the RIN would still be controlled by MPC.
componenttext: The RIN would -- we would expect Chi, that the RIN would still be controlled by MPC.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Even though you've got the whole Southeast going? This structure that you been....
componenttext: Even though you've got the whole Southeast going? This structure that you been....

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where we're looking at the fuels distribution, it would be -- it would be after the RIN or after the blending that have taken place. So I would expect that we would not be putting up any RIN volatility inside of MPLX.
componenttext: Where we're looking at the fuels distribution, it would be -- it would be after the RIN or after the blending that have taken place. So I would expect that we would not be putting up any RIN volatility inside of MPLX.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the other important piece of that for how we have thought about this and the potential for structuring it. We're looking at as a sort of service arrangement as opposed to the transfer of inventory necessarily. So I don't think we would expect any
componenttext: I think the other important piece of that for how we have thought about this and the potential for structuring it. We're looking at as a sort of service arrangement as opposed to the transfer of inventory necessarily. So I don't think we would expect any change to sort of where the RINs are resident and then where the benefit resides.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Roger Read from Wells Fargo.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guess I'd like to catch up a little more on trying to how to think about the share repurchases and how they will fit in. I mean, I understand a little early to layout '17 CapEx, but you did improve the balance sheet year-to-date. It sounds like in every w
componenttext: Guess I'd like to catch up a little more on trying to how to think about the share repurchases and how they will fit in. I mean, I understand a little early to layout '17 CapEx, but you did improve the balance sheet year-to-date. It sounds like in every which way MPLX is on much firmer footing and a solid growth outlook. Refining probably better in '17 than it is right now. So as you get free cash flow, how should we think about it between consistent raising of the dividend, further balance sheet repair need be and then the share repurchases?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well again, the focus around capital return and how we do that is going to continue in the business for as long as we can imagine. How we balance that, I think -- the key part Roger is maybe as you allude to a little bit that, this is really going to a ba
componenttext: Well again, the focus around capital return and how we do that is going to continue in the business for as long as we can imagine. How we balance that, I think -- the key part Roger is maybe as you allude to a little bit that, this is really going to a balanced approach. And I think we're not inclined to go all in on full investment, we're not inclined to go all in on full share repurchase. It's really going to be sort of finding that balance within in the business, based on what the earnings looks like, what the cash flow generation could be and exactly where we find ourselves financially at each point in time. So again, as I referenced earlier, this really becomes sort of the flywheel as we evaluate exactly how we want to position the business from a capital allocation perspective. We expect a level of activity will be there and could vary in different periods in time, but will be an important part of our balanced approach in the capital allocation side.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up to that, Gary certainly, Marathon has been an acquisitive company. I understand you maybe in a more of a digestive phase right now, but as you do free up more capital, whether from a retail wholesale drop down or further growth inside o
componenttext: And as a follow-up to that, Gary certainly, Marathon has been an acquisitive company. I understand you maybe in a more of a digestive phase right now, but as you do free up more capital, whether from a retail wholesale drop down or further growth inside of MPLX, what else looks interesting on the M&A front? Is there a desire to expand the Refining or should we think about it as a Midstream retail growth really only at this point?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the valuation metrics of Refining today, I think we're -- we have a very good platform and good footprint in Refining and maybe want to -- where we like being today. Doesn't say that we won't look at the other opportunities that may come
componenttext: When you look at the valuation metrics of Refining today, I think we're -- we have a very good platform and good footprint in Refining and maybe want to -- where we like being today. Doesn't say that we won't look at the other opportunities that may come about. We will. On the retail and Midstream side of course, we're very interested in continuing to build out within our footprint. And the retail side, we have the platform, the ability and as Tony's team has been able to certainly illustrate the expertise to be able to step outside of our footprint and perform very well. So we'll continue to be interested in retail. I think retail and midstream probably give us higher returns. But I would say where our share prices are as Tim just alluded to, buying back share is -- will be top of mind as well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, with MPLX sort of stabilized. Do you that this point and going forward whenever there is new investment opportunity, whether it's building out more NGL distribution business over there, they will all be self funded? That the need for the parent corp
componenttext: Gary, with MPLX sort of stabilized. Do you that this point and going forward whenever there is new investment opportunity, whether it's building out more NGL distribution business over there, they will all be self funded? That the need for the parent corporation and any support is really just totally behind? And you're not going to consider going forward? Or would that if it may have opportunity there, that at some point it would be so great from the MPLX that you would still consider, support from the parent?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well -- and you're right Paul. It just depends on the situation. As Don just mentioned, we have -- was speaking to some of big organic projects we talked about. And some of those can be hefty because of the size of the projects. And we'll see what the car
componenttext: Well -- and you're right Paul. It just depends on the situation. As Don just mentioned, we have -- was speaking to some of big organic projects we talked about. And some of those can be hefty because of the size of the projects. And we'll see what the carry might be if any. But we have stabilized the balance sheet, I think the business, the base business is  picking up as commodity prices improve. The coverage should continue to improve. So I believe that, it can stand on its own into '17. And we'll see at that point. But I don't see anything over the next few quarters that MPC would need to step in and support their balance sheet.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know it's early. Any preliminary CapEx for 2017 even from a direction standpoint, you can share? Given the recent weaknesses in the Refining margins so that we assume, the CapEx is going to be somewhat similar to this year? Or that you think is going to
componenttext: I know it's early. Any preliminary CapEx for 2017 even from a direction standpoint, you can share? Given the recent weaknesses in the Refining margins so that we assume, the CapEx is going to be somewhat similar to this year? Or that you think is going to be down or going to be up?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Paul. I would say when we come to your conference here in September we're going to be able to have a pretty good idea of where we're looking at CapEx going forward. We're not in that phase right now. I wouldn't expect it to be up from where we are i
componenttext: Well, Paul. I would say when we come to your conference here in September we're going to be able to have a pretty good idea of where we're looking at CapEx going forward. We're not in that phase right now. I wouldn't expect it to be up from where we are in '16, but we're just in initial phase of looking at the capital for '17 and beyond.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The final 1 maybe for this is for Mike. Sandpiper, with a number of major projects origin from getting oil out from Bakken. Are we going to have enough oil from Bakken to fill that line?
componenttext: The final 1 maybe for this is for Mike. Sandpiper, with a number of major projects origin from getting oil out from Bakken. Are we going to have enough oil from Bakken to fill that line?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike will take that. Mike?
componenttext: Yes, Mike will take that. Mike?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That really depends -- I guess, Paul on what happens with crude prices, and we think that things are rebalancing quickly now. We think that oil prices will be up and do believe that North Dakota production -- it's a big resource, we believe North Dakota p
componenttext: That really depends -- I guess, Paul on what happens with crude prices, and we think that things are rebalancing quickly now. We think that oil prices will be up and do believe that North Dakota production -- it's a big resource, we believe North Dakota production will go up as well. So there will be oil into the future to feed the various pipelines.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Phil Gresh from JPMorgan.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps just as a follow-up to Ed's question on the drop potential. I mean, how do you think about the ideal pace of drops going forward, in terms of maybe on an annualized basis. What you think MPC can get back from jobs that can be reallocated. And then
componenttext: Perhaps just as a follow-up to Ed's question on the drop potential. I mean, how do you think about the ideal pace of drops going forward, in terms of maybe on an annualized basis. What you think MPC can get back from jobs that can be reallocated. And then also in terms of value unlock opportunities. How are you thinking about the GP here? Do you think it's at mature enough state to consider unlocking some value there or do you think you need more time?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, Phil -- we don't look at it has what can we hurry up and drop. We look at it as what is the growth rate that we're trying to achieve and what are the mechanisms that we use to achieve that growth rate. And as we stated in our release th
componenttext: Well, I would say, Phil -- we don't look at it has what can we hurry up and drop. We look at it as what is the growth rate that we're trying to achieve and what are the mechanisms that we use to achieve that growth rate. And as we stated in our release this morning that we expect double-digit growth rate. We're on target first of all, to meet that, parameter that we set out at 12% to 15% this year and then a double-digit growth next year. So that's directionally how we look at it Phil.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the GP?
componenttext: And then on the GP?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The GP when you're all visiting with us we still believe that the GP -- this is a -- it has to mature more to consider that this clearly, isn't the market to be -- to try to float a GP IPO. And the other thing that as we certainly have recognized in the m
componenttext: The GP when you're all visiting with us we still believe that the GP -- this is a -- it has to mature more to consider that this clearly, isn't the market to be -- to try to float a GP IPO. And the other thing that as we certainly have recognized in the market with some changes in structure, is that it appears that simplification is better. But we continue to analyze and we'll continue on that path.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up is just around the level of maintenance spending that we're seeing this year in the Refining side. As look ahead, would you say that this above normal in terms of maintenance this year? Or how might you suggest or think about having a nor
componenttext: And my follow-up is just around the level of maintenance spending that we're seeing this year in the Refining side. As look ahead, would you say that this above normal in terms of maintenance this year? Or how might you suggest or think about having a normal level of maintenance spending moving forward?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well this year was definitely a step up on the maintenance side from the standpoint. It was a heavy turnaround year. So it was definitely a step up, but our goal in Refining is what do we have to do year in year out to level that spend as much as possible
componenttext: Well this year was definitely a step up on the maintenance side from the standpoint. It was a heavy turnaround year. So it was definitely a step up, but our goal in Refining is what do we have to do year in year out to level that spend as much as possible. Take care of our turnarounds, but try to keep things as constant as possible.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question for you Gary knowing how involved you are in Washington and what's your stance first on what you think should happen and what do you guys actually want as Marathon Petroleum? What do you feel is in your best interest as regards RINs?
componenttext: My question for you Gary knowing how involved you are in Washington and what's your stance first on what you think should happen and what do you guys actually want as Marathon Petroleum? What do you feel is in your best interest as regards RINs?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. Clearly, we need to have our best interest, of which we continue to strive for is full repeal of the renewable fuel standard. But knowing that, that is a heavy lift, there's been a bill that's been introduced on the floor known as The Flores'
componenttext:
Sure, Paul. Clearly, we need to have our best interest, of which we continue to strive for is full repeal of the renewable fuel standard. But knowing that, that is a heavy lift, there's been a bill that's been introduced on the floor known as The Flores' Bill, that would limit blending at 9.7%, which really takes into account the need gasoline that's in the market as well. We think that needs to be supportive with a tremendous amount of support, already inside the house on this bill and we need to get others on schedule as well.
The RIN prices, you're right. Upwards $0.95, $0.98, I know they've hit $1 over the last couple of weeks. And it's a -- and I think -- I don't think I know the reason is because the market is understanding that we're going to be very close and probably will tip over the 10% ethanol blend wall this year. Therefore, RINs are going to be at -- the demand for RINs are going to outpace the supply. The steps that we've taken over the years as illustrated as well in this morning's comments is that, we're in very good shape and we're fairly balanced on the RIN side. But nevertheless, we want a significant amendment or repeal of the renewable fuel standards and we're working very hard towards that -- or in that direction.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And our final question comes from Spiro Dounis from UBS.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 1 really quick 1 for me, hopefully. I just thought on M&A and I know the question was asked earlier, but maybe just from a different perspective. In terms of opportunities set out there and maybe quarter-over-quarter, it seems like things are pretty
componenttext: Just 1 really quick 1 for me, hopefully. I just thought on M&A and I know the question was asked earlier, but maybe just from a different perspective. In terms of opportunities set out there and maybe quarter-over-quarter, it seems like things are pretty dire in the first quarter and gradually improved. Wondering if you saw maybe a lot of fire sales come out of the market? Or if you still see a lot of opportunity out in terms of what's available to be picked up in whether be Retail, Refining or Midstream?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think for the most part, except on the Midstream side, for the most part R&M and Retail has really ridden the wave here to the fourth quarter and first quarter. There is nothing pending on the refining side of the slate. There are rumors on different th
componenttext: I think for the most part, except on the Midstream side, for the most part R&M and Retail has really ridden the wave here to the fourth quarter and first quarter. There is nothing pending on the refining side of the slate. There are rumors on different things that might be available. But I think the refining side still would be fairly pricey and be pricey versus the multiples that are achieved in the marketplace today. But beyond that, I would say that -- there has been some movement in the retail space. But Don can mention here on the midstream side what he's seeing across the midstream space.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Spiro. We haven't really seen any significant change. I think the people that were really in a desperate situation at the end of the fourth quarter going into the first was primarily on the EMP side, I mean clearly, the cost of capital was increasing
componenttext: Yes, Spiro. We haven't really seen any significant change. I think the people that were really in a desperate situation at the end of the fourth quarter going into the first was primarily on the EMP side, I mean clearly, the cost of capital was increasing for the mainstream producers or Midstream players. But I just haven't seen a dramatic change one way or the other. The folks that would be potentially in play in the first quarter are still in play and we haven't seen any big pullback in terms of opportunities.
