headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Audio Gap]These negative impacts for the quarter were partially offset by lower income taxes and higher income contributed by our Midstream segment. Turning to Slide 6, our Refining & Marketing segment reported income from operations of $306 million
componenttext:
[Audio Gap]
These negative impacts for the quarter were partially offset by lower income taxes and higher income contributed by our Midstream segment. 
Turning to Slide 6, our Refining & Marketing segment reported income from operations of $306 million in the third quarter 2016, compared with $1.4 billion in the same quarter last year. The decrease was primarily due to weaker crack spreads in both the Gulf Coast and Chicago, and less favorable product price realizations compared to the LLS base crack spread. The lower blended crack spread had a negative impact on earnings of approximately $711 million. The blended crack spread was $4.10 per barrel lower at $8.08 per barrel in the third quarter compared to $12.18 per barrel for the same period last year.
There were 4 primary contributors to the $463 million unfavorable other gross margin brands in this walk. First, we experienced narrower gasoline and diesel price realizations versus the reported market metric LLS base crack spread in the third quarter of '16 compared to the same quarter last year. Second, our price realizations were negatively impacted by less favorable margins on non-transportation products, which include the asphalt. Asphalt realizations were exceptionally strong in the third quarter 2015, and have not increased at the same rate as the rise in the price of crude. Third, as I mentioned, we experienced weaker crack spreads during the quarter. At the same time, our outright RIN purchase cost more than doubled when compared to the third quarter of 2015. Our cost of purchase RINs to comply with the RFS standards was $80 million this quarter. Finally, refinery volume metric gains also continue to be lower this quarter due to the lower commodity price environment we're in. R&M segment income benefited $79 million by an approximately $0.40 per barrel widening of the sweet/sour differential as well as higher severance in the quarter versus the same quarter last year. The LLS-WTI differential narrowed by $2.14 per barrel from $3.72 per barrel in the third quarter of '15 to a $1.58 per barrel in this third quarter.
This had a negative impact on earnings of about $69 million based on the WTI-linked crudes in our slate. The market structure or contango effect during the quarter is reflected in the $32 million favorable variance on the walk and relates to the difference between the prompt crude prices we used for market metrics and the actual crude acquisition cost in the quarter. The $35 million year-over-year increase in direct operating cost relate primarily to higher turnaround activity in the quarter versus last year. Turnaround and major maintenance cost increased $0.25 per barrel or over $46 million compared to the third quarter of 2015.
Moving to our other segments. Slide 7 provides the Speedway segment earnings walk compared to the same quarter last year. Speedway's income was down $34 million compared to the third quarter of 2016, primarily driven by lower light product margins. Gasoline and distillate margins were $0.177 per gallon in the third quarter of 2016, which was $0.37 lower than the third quarter of 2015, which is a period of very strong margins. On a sequential basis, light product margin was $0.022 per gallon higher than second quarter 2016.
Partially offsetting lower fuel margins, were higher gasoline and distillate sales volumes and higher merchandised margins. Gasoline and distillate sales volumes were up 20 million gallons over the same quarter last year. On a same-store basis, gasoline volumes decreased 0.6% over the same period last year. Our focus continues to be on optimizing total gasoline contributions between volume and margin to ensure fuel margins remain adequate.
Increasing merchandise sales continue to be a focus, the results of which can be seen in the $28 million increase in Speedway's merchandised gross margin compared to third quarter of 2015.
Merchandise margins increased due to higher overall merchandise sales as well as higher margins realized on those sales. Merchandise sales in the quarter, excluding cigarettes, increased 4% on a same-store year-over-year basis. In October, we've seen a decrease in gasoline demand, is approximately 4% decrease in same-store gasoline sales volumes compared to last October. The decrease we expect to be temporary and largely reflects the impacts of Hurricane Matthew on approximately 500 Speedway locations.
Slide 8 provides the changes in the Midstream segment income versus the third quarter last year. The $165 million increase quarter-over-quarter was primarily due to the combination with MarkWest at the end of last year, which contributed a $121 million of incremental segment income to the quarter.
The remaining increase of $44 million was primarily due to an increase in income from our equity affiliates and lower operating expenses versus the third quarter last year. 
Slide 9 presents the significant elements of changes in our consolidated cash position for the third quarter. Cash at the end of the quarter was just over $700 million. Core operating cash flow was a $1.1 billion source of cash. The $666 million use of working capital noted on the slide, primarily relates to a decrease in accounts payable and accrued liabilities and an increase in crude and refined products inventory levels during the quarter. The decrease in accounts payable and accrued liabilities was primarily due to the lower crude prices and volumes as well as timing of tax payments. Given the weaker refining margins we've seen this year, we took the opportunity to selectively prepay some of our debt during the quarter, which is reflected in the $516 million of net debt cash outflow shown in the walk.
MPLX opportunistically issued equity through its ATM program during the quarter with net proceeds of $184 million as shown on the walk. Return of capital during the quarter included share repurchase of $51 million and dividends of $190 million. During the third quarter, we increased our dividend 12.5% or $0.36 per share. We have increased our dividend 6 times since becoming a standalone company 5 years ago, resulting in a 28% compound annual growth rate on the dividend. Our continued focus on growing regular quarterly dividends demonstrates our ongoing strategy to share in the success of the business with our shareholders and this dividend increase just reaffirms that strategy.
Slide 10 provides an overview of our capitalization and financial profile at the end of the quarter. We had $10.6 billion of total consolidated debt including $4.4 billion of debt at MPLX. Total debt to book capitalization was about 34%, and represented 2.3x last 12 months pro forma adjusted EBITDA on a consolidated basis or about 1.8x if we exclude MPLX. We're showing the metric without MPLX since the debt is nonrecourse MPC and MPLX will maintain a capital structure, which uses relatively higher leverage, making consolidated debt-to-EBITDA increasingly less useful given the size and continued growth of the partnership. 
Slide 11 provides updated outlook information on key operating metrics for MPC for the fourth quarter 2016. We're expecting fourth quarter throughput volumes to be down slightly compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, due to more planned maintenance in the quarter. Total direct operating cost is expected to be $8.05 per barrel on total throughput of 1.83 million barrels per day. Beginning this quarter, we're also providing our estimated percentage of sour crude throughput, which we expect to be 58% in the fourth quarter due to the continued sour crude advantage.
Our projected fourth quarter corporate and other unallocated items are estimated at $75 million.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Lisa. Lisa?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you provide some early flavor as it relates to some of the strategic changes that you talked about drop-downs to GP structure and some of the accounting changes? And then, talk about how retail fits into it, if at all?
componenttext: Gary, can you provide some early flavor as it relates to some of the strategic changes that you talked about drop-downs to GP structure and some of the accounting changes? And then, talk about how retail fits into it, if at all?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure Neil. As we -- in our separate release this morning, we have been working on this for quite some time on -- we spent the early part of the year in the transition to get MarkWest into the fold and to really get our businesses lined out. And then, real
componenttext: Sure Neil. As we -- in our separate release this morning, we have been working on this for quite some time on -- we spent the early part of the year in the transition to get MarkWest into the fold and to really get our businesses lined out. And then, really focused on what is the proper growth strategy and how do we -- we have tremendous portfolio of assets that can be considered over time to be drop-down. And we felt that it was the best to get into a very aggressive strong rhythm on how to drop-down the assets that we have. It's not just a drop-down strategy Neil, we expect to be acquisitive in certain markets where it makes sense for the Midstream as well as we have a very good organic suite of projects to work on. But as we step back and looked at our total Midstream business, we felt that now is the time to take this very bold, aggressive action. And then -- we have also stated, not just the drop-downs for 2017, of approximately $350 million, but we're also then are talking about the future drop-down strategy of the approximate $1 billion of other assets. Let me be specific about that $1 billion of other assets. As you know, Neil, you and I talked about this many times. We have a significant portion of those assets under the fuels distribution piece, that we have a private letter ruling request into the IRS. So we have to be careful and make sure we don't have any potential tax liability of dropping those down sooner than -- that we would believe we have approval from the IRS. An additional thing that we highlighted, the value of the general partner interest, let me have Tim talk about some of the actions and the aspects that we would have around looking at the general partner interest.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neil, as we sort of outlined, I think the key for us is that we have -- we've seen pretty clearly that the value of the GP is not being fully recognized in the value of MPC. So I think we want to take a careful but aggressive look at exactly ways tha
componenttext: Yes, Neil, as we sort of outlined, I think the key for us is that we have -- we've seen pretty clearly that the value of the GP is not being fully recognized in the value of MPC. So I think we want to take a careful but aggressive look at exactly ways that we can highlight that value, capture it and optimize the cost to capital for the partnership. So again, I would say that we really want to look at everything. There is no preconceived notion or conclusions as to where ultimately this may lead us. Again with that objective of highlighting that value and optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership, it could include things like a buy-in of the IDR's at the partnership level, public sale of some portion of the GP, other alternatives around restructuring the GP interest. Again, we want to make sure that we're going to look at everything and make sure that we understand what might be the best path to really have that value better reflected in the overall valuation of MPC.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, to your question on Speedway. We've talked many times about Speedway as well, you and other sell-side analysts have discussed this, how important Speedway is, along with the Midstream in trying to balance our cash flow across all cycles. And we real
componenttext: Neil, to your question on Speedway. We've talked many times about Speedway as well, you and other sell-side analysts have discussed this, how important Speedway is, along with the Midstream in trying to balance our cash flow across all cycles. And we really believe that significant portion of the discount in our share prize today really is reflected in the Midstream space. And Speedway is not the catalyst or the driver. Speedway is continuing to perform very, very well as indicated again, and the performance for this quarter. So we look at the integration value, we look at kind of the dyssynergy if we were to do something different with Speedway and we still believe that it has a very strong fit in our system.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, my follow-up here is that, you cited 4 reasons that other gross margins were under pressure, narrow gasoline and diesel, the nontransportation products, RINs, and I believe, volume metric gains. How much of that is a third quarter phenomena here as
componenttext: Gary, my follow-up here is that, you cited 4 reasons that other gross margins were under pressure, narrow gasoline and diesel, the nontransportation products, RINs, and I believe, volume metric gains. How much of that is a third quarter phenomena here as opposed to a recurring point? And I guess, the reason I'm going here is that, when I think about MPC's portfolio, historically, you guys have outperformed your indicator margins by taking advantage of the logistics in the infrastructure advantages that you guys have. I want to make sure that's going to be a recurring advantage for MPC on a go-forward basis.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, you are spot-on there with the outcome. Let's go back and look at the third quarter of '16 versus the third quarter of '15. Third quarter of '15 had a rapid drop in the price of crude. And when you have that, you're able to retain margins in all asp
componenttext: Neil, you are spot-on there with the outcome. Let's go back and look at the third quarter of '16 versus the third quarter of '15. Third quarter of '15 had a rapid drop in the price of crude. And when you have that, you're able to retain margins in all aspects of our business and all the way through asphalt. Asphalt was one of the major contributors to our third quarter last year. This year, when we started to see a steady climb in crude prices and with some of the problems that you had in the third quarter, you have to look at Colonial, while sometimes a dislocation in markets, such has happened with Colonial, sometimes you recognize different pockets of the country and we're able to capture some of that value through the logistics arm that we have. That did not happen with that downturn, and in fact it backed product, back into the Gulf Coast, and in fact, backed products for the West. On top of that, we spent a lot of incremental money in order to be able to service our customers and keep our customers full during that period of time. So that was a phenomena, but it really -- Tim mentioned the gas and diesel prices -- the price realization, but it really got into the bottom components and asphalt was a big marker that was held as well. So I would say, those are the big things. I would say they are non -- expect them to be nonrecurring, kind of a follow on to that here, early in the fourth quarter, with Hurricane Matthew, that had an upset across the entire Gulf Coast, some don't think about the tropical storm Hermine that hit in the third quarter. That had an effect as well. When you lose that volume from these tropical storms, it's gone. So all those effects -- all those things affected the third quarter and some into the fourth quarter, but I would expect that they would be nonrecurring.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulation on the more aggressive strategy. I guess, in MPLX, debt to pro forma or adjusted EBITDA, I think was 3.5x at September 30. So when you think from the MPC perspective of the cash versus units debate, maybe just give some color as to what sor
componenttext: Congratulation on the more aggressive strategy. I guess, in MPLX, debt to pro forma or adjusted EBITDA, I think was 3.5x at September 30. So when you think from the MPC perspective of the cash versus units debate, maybe just give some color as to what sort of expectation of how much cash you could get from these drops over the next year, and then maybe next 3 years?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Tim, This is something that I think we're going to sort of carefully evaluate. I mean, the drops that we've talked about here and contemplated are certainly bigger than we've done in the past. But I think we will always be mindful of what the m
componenttext: Sure. It's Tim, This is something that I think we're going to sort of carefully evaluate. I mean, the drops that we've talked about here and contemplated are certainly bigger than we've done in the past. But I think we will always be mindful of what the market capacity is to absorb new units. I think we would certainly want to take advantage of opportunity that exists, but clearly, would not want to overwhelm the market with the number of units. We will assess as we go forward and make sure that we're being smart about it. I think, from the overall enterprise perspective, we'll have a tremendous amount of flexibility here to take back units where we need to and we'll access the market in an opportunistic way as we go forward.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you just have this new 707 taxable, which reduces the amount of debt that you can use in basis for drop-downs. So I don't know, it maybe still early, but have you got any idea in terms of what tax leakage you would expect at the MPC level in term
componenttext: And then you just have this new 707 taxable, which reduces the amount of debt that you can use in basis for drop-downs. So I don't know, it maybe still early, but have you got any idea in terms of what tax leakage you would expect at the MPC level in terms of the drops or the impact of that ruling has.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well -- obviously doing things as tax efficiently as possible always be a primary focus. I mean, the changes to the 707 regs, to be honest, Ed, don't have a massive impact on our strategy. Utilizing sort of debt finance distributions back would not have b
componenttext: Well -- obviously doing things as tax efficiently as possible always be a primary focus. I mean, the changes to the 707 regs, to be honest, Ed, don't have a massive impact on our strategy. Utilizing sort of debt finance distributions back would not have been part of our normal mode with regard to the drops anyway. So the -- and frankly, even before the 707 regs, a more aggressive tax that the IRS has sort of been targeting and obviously the change in regs is a -- it sort of demonstrates that, that's where that focus has been. So I don't think from our prospective, we view the change in the regs under disguised sale as substantially impactful to our strategy. But again -- even the notion of taking back units and identifying assets with the greatest amount of basis to shield as much tax as possible will be an important consideration as we evaluate which and what timing will undertake for the dropped portfolio.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could sneak a quick one in. The cash flow was the full working capital, $1.07 billion, but your earnings collapsed. Obviously, that's the impairment, but even adjusting for that, so any color as to why cash generation is diverging from earnings
componenttext: Okay. If I could sneak a quick one in. The cash flow was the full working capital, $1.07 billion, but your earnings collapsed. Obviously, that's the impairment, but even adjusting for that, so any color as to why cash generation is diverging from earnings, would be helpful.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, there's nothing specific. I would say, we had certainly some working capital impacts on the quarter, that again, really build out -- based on some changes in prices and some inventory build in the quarter. That was a relatively big use of working capi
componenttext: Ed, there's nothing specific. I would say, we had certainly some working capital impacts on the quarter, that again, really build out -- based on some changes in prices and some inventory build in the quarter. That was a relatively big use of working capital in the quarter. That's probably the biggest item of potential divergence that we would highlight.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor Pickering Holt.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor Pickering Holt.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you talk about the specific assets you're targeting for the '17 drops?
componenttext: Gary, can you talk about the specific assets you're targeting for the '17 drops?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me ask Don to cover that. Don has been doing most of the work on this.
componenttext: Yes. Let me ask Don to cover that. Don has been doing most of the work on this.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chi. We would expect that particularly the first drop that we're targeting, those assets would be predominantly pipeline and terminal assets. So very, very traditional midstream assets that we currently own. And then later in the year, we also have s
componenttext: Yes, Chi. We would expect that particularly the first drop that we're targeting, those assets would be predominantly pipeline and terminal assets. So very, very traditional midstream assets that we currently own. And then later in the year, we also have some joint interest pipelines and other. So it will be in that vein of assets, typical straight down the fairway midstream assets that will be moving from MPC to MPLX.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you comment at all on what sort of multiple range you're targeting for the drops?
componenttext: And can you comment at all on what sort of multiple range you're targeting for the drops?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, we're not targeting a specific multiple range. I think, it will be a fact and circumstance-driven function based upon making sure that the drops are appropriately accretive for MPLX. One of the really important things about these drops was that w
componenttext: I guess, we're not targeting a specific multiple range. I think, it will be a fact and circumstance-driven function based upon making sure that the drops are appropriately accretive for MPLX. One of the really important things about these drops was that we wanted to -- we don't believe that our yield is as low as we would like it to be at MPLX, and we're trying to take actions to lower that yield and lower our cost to capital. So driving a distribution growth rate that is 12% to 15% in double-digit in out-years is important to us, and having a valuation or multiple on the drop that makes sense to support that is, I think is in the best interest of both MPC and MPLX.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, one other question. Can you comment on Marathon's interest in utilizing the reversal of the Laurel Pipeline once that becomes operational? And what are the opportunities this might open up for you down the road?
componenttext: And then, one other question. Can you comment on Marathon's interest in utilizing the reversal of the Laurel Pipeline once that becomes operational? And what are the opportunities this might open up for you down the road?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chi. This is Mike Palmer, I can answer that for you. Obviously, when you look at the Midwest, we have a lot of refining capacity. And in the wintertime when gasoline demand goes down, certainly, we have -- we have gasoline and distillate that needs t
componenttext: Yes, Chi. This is Mike Palmer, I can answer that for you. Obviously, when you look at the Midwest, we have a lot of refining capacity. And in the wintertime when gasoline demand goes down, certainly, we have -- we have gasoline and distillate that needs to seek new markets. So we've been looking at a number of opportunities, but the reversing Laurel such that Pittsburgh becomes primarily a pipeline supplied from the Midwest market is certainly big for us and we would participate in that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Chi, we've been saying for some time, in fact, I think Marathon was one of the catalyst of this idea that it really makes sense to go west to east and starting to supply the PADD I market, and that further balances all of PADD II. So we won't get spec
componenttext: And Chi, we've been saying for some time, in fact, I think Marathon was one of the catalyst of this idea that it really makes sense to go west to east and starting to supply the PADD I market, and that further balances all of PADD II. So we won't get specific yet into how many barrels we might move. I just say that, this open season that has been just completed is going to be a big event for the entire PADD II industry because it has another outlet for us to balance the Midwest.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I agree. Do see you enough demand from PADD II to eventually force the reversal all the way back to Philadelphia?
componenttext: I agree. Do see you enough demand from PADD II to eventually force the reversal all the way back to Philadelphia?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really believe long-term and I have talked about this long-term that this is something that needs to happen and as a big strategic move. First, I think we're looking to Altoona, Mike but, yes, eventually we will see it going all the way to the East Coas
componenttext: I really believe long-term and I have talked about this long-term that this is something that needs to happen and as a big strategic move. First, I think we're looking to Altoona, Mike but, yes, eventually we will see it going all the way to the East Coast.

componenttext: The decision to take or the potential to take MPLX units in lieu of cash, obviously the quantity or the balance hasn't been determined yet, but what would that mean for your subsequent monetization of those units as it relates to your buyback strategy for MPC?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug, its Tim. Obviously that -- if we did take back units, the percentage and number of units at MPC holds -- it becomes substantial, and I think the things like potential sale of those units is something we'll evaluate over time. I mean, again, wanting
componenttext: Doug, its Tim. Obviously that -- if we did take back units, the percentage and number of units at MPC holds -- it becomes substantial, and I think the things like potential sale of those units is something we'll evaluate over time. I mean, again, wanting to make sure that anything that we do around that is tax efficient and we can minimize the amount of leakage around it. Again, I think our focus is much more around the total value getting realized within the system as opposed to the net cash. But I think, we will look at if there are efficient ways for us to potentially look at those units over time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just for clarification on that question. So if you took MPLX units, would you expect your buyback pace to moderate?
componenttext: I guess, just for clarification on that question. So if you took MPLX units, would you expect your buyback pace to moderate?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again the drop-down itself is not predicated on producing a huge amount of cash for buyback necessarily. I mean, the buybacks will always be a function of the cash that's being generated on an operating basis, and potentially some from what gets dro
componenttext: Well, again the drop-down itself is not predicated on producing a huge amount of cash for buyback necessarily. I mean, the buybacks will always be a function of the cash that's being generated on an operating basis, and potentially some from what gets dropped. So again, we'll evaluate as we go forward, as we said, even if there are a number of units taken back, there's probably still a fair amount of debt that gets undertaken at the MPLX level on those assets. So I think the cash opportunity around it is beyond just the equity units themselves.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -Doug, this is Don. In 2016, one of the things that we were doing at MPLX was, we had a leverage ratio that was noninvestment grade in our view. And so we committed to taking that leverage down. And now, we are in the zone that we want to be with
componenttext: I think -Doug, this is Don. In 2016, one of the things that we were doing at MPLX was, we had a leverage ratio that was noninvestment grade in our view. And so we committed to taking that leverage down. And now, we are in the zone that we want to be with respect to our leverage and to supporting an investment grade credit profile. So we would likely be thinking about funding future growth, whether it is organic growth or whether it is drop-downs with a more sort of balanced 50-50 debt and equity type of arrangement. So I think, hopefully that answer's some of your question as well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful, Don. I guess, my follow up is probably also for you Don, because the more traditional nature of the assets, pipelines, terminals and so on, accelerating the drop-downs, it obviously means accelerating the increase in the refining cos
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful, Don. I guess, my follow up is probably also for you Don, because the more traditional nature of the assets, pipelines, terminals and so on, accelerating the drop-downs, it obviously means accelerating the increase in the refining cost basis. Can you quantify what that would look like based on the plan you have, would you expect the cost basis for refining to go up as you monetize these assets? And I will leave it there.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'm not sure. From the MPLX perspective, I mean, what we're trying to do is, to build an EBITDA portfolio so that we can continue to support that high-growth rate that we're committing to.
componenttext: I guess, I'm not sure. From the MPLX perspective, I mean, what we're trying to do is, to build an EBITDA portfolio so that we can continue to support that high-growth rate that we're committing to.

I guess, it's going to come out in the Washington  accounting, but order of magnitude would be useful?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes again, Doug, I know we've had a similar dialogue as over time. We're really are viewing this at sort of the enterprise level with regard to the earnings that are available from the business, and where ultimately they may reside rather -- as part of the traditional R&M segment or part of MPLX, and obviously, with the IDRs around them and the sort of recycle of cash, I mean, we have tended to look at this and I think we'll continue to look at this on an enterprise-wide basis as opposed to the specifics around the impact on a particular segment within the business.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, just circling back to some of the earlier questions about the general partner. I'm curious about the comment that you made, specifically about reducing the cost of capital or optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership. I'm curious how that i
componenttext: Gary, just circling back to some of the earlier questions about the general partner. I'm curious about the comment that you made, specifically about reducing the cost of capital or optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership. I'm curious how that interacts with also unlocking value and how, maybe having a public marker on the GP would help reduce the cost of capital. And really what I am getting at here is, is there a chance that maybe there is an IDR waiver that comes out as part of this process?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well again, Brad, I don't think there's any preconceived conclusions as to the exactly the path we take. But I think modifications to the GP interest or potentially IDR modifications, again, the buy-in, the public sell, these are all things that are on th
componenttext: Well again, Brad, I don't think there's any preconceived conclusions as to the exactly the path we take. But I think modifications to the GP interest or potentially IDR modifications, again, the buy-in, the public sell, these are all things that are on the table. I don't think we want to exclude anything from our considerations to make sure that -- again, the focus really here is on highlighting that value and making sure that everyone sort of understands and the market can see and understand that value, and making sure that we're focused on optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership, which obviously over time and certainly in the lifecycle of MPLX, is at a point where the IDRs continue to be a cash flow that has to be covered with regard to growth. So I think we want to be mindful of all of these considerations before we land on any solution and we'll certainly let the market know once we reach some conclusions.

componenttext: And then, thinking about the drops that you're talking about before. I think pipelines and terminals were mentioned. I know that the RINs are generally internal within the refining and marketing business, but I'm wondering if any of these drops are going to include the RINs?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more quick one if I could. Gary, I think that, couple of months ago, you talked about a potential reduction in the scope of the STAR project from $2 billion to $1.5 billion. I'm curious where you are in that review, and if you have any sort
componenttext: Okay. And one more quick one if I could. Gary, I think that, couple of months ago, you talked about a potential reduction in the scope of the STAR project from $2 billion to $1.5 billion. I'm curious where you are in that review, and if you have any sort of updated EBITDA target for that new scope?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Let me ask Ray to answer this.
componenttext: Right. Let me ask Ray to answer this.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Earlier this year, we completed feasibility engineering of all the components of STAR. And what we concluded from that review was that one of the components, a new build distillate hydrotreater did not meet our internal minimum returns. So at this p
componenttext: Sure. Earlier this year, we completed feasibility engineering of all the components of STAR. And what we concluded from that review was that one of the components, a new build distillate hydrotreater did not meet our internal minimum returns. So at this point, we're not progressing on engineering on that portion, and we're looking for other opportunities, evaluating other opportunities of unit revamps within the refinery to accommodate distillate desulfurization. So that's a long way of saying that, we do anticipate a drop in the CapEx, we were looking at before of the $2 billion range, we were looking at something south of that now. And we'll continue to progress our engineering and just do really what makes sense there. I might add at this point that the STAR program really is a multi-year, multifaceted project. And earlier this summer, we brought on the first pay part, which was a desulfurization unit, repurposing and expansion, and that's played out very well for us. That was CapEx of about $65 million, and it delivered results and performing as expected. So we'll continue to look at the program, and just do what makes sense economically.

componenttext: But no new EBITDA target?

componenttext: Not at this time. We're still finalizing the components of the project and when we have that finished we'll make -- we'll put it into our deck.

componenttext: Well again, the inventory actions that we took in third quarter, not unlike other years, in large part for hurricane build and sort of positioning the business into the season. So nothing unusual. And again, I think a lot of those affects, we'll always manage into the sort of LIFO targets that we've got for the business. So that was probably the bigger driver on the quarter was the refined products and crude build that were not sort of unexpected relative to how we've managed the business.

componenttext: Gary, historically, you've talked about the benefits of control and basically maintaining a decent amount of control with regard to the MLP, I'm just curious with the announcement today and some considerations on changes at that level, has there been any change in your appetite with regard to control and potentially maybe foregoing a bit in an effort to drive that value at the GP level?

componenttext: No Blake. componenttext: The second question, and this is really more just clarity from a reporting standpoint, but obviously you've already got a Midstream segment, is it fair to think that the impetus behind this is to really reallocate some of that EBITDA that's coming out of the Refining segment into Midstream, and if so, I'm assuming we'll get some restated historical gross margins, et cetera?

componenttext: Yes, Blake, I think that's conceptually how we're targeting, that there is a fair amount of what we've identified as MLP eligible earnings that really have been in the R&M segment historically. So certainly for those portions that we think are and will be MLP eligible, identifying them independent from the R&M segment is conceptually I think what we're really targeting here.

I just kind of want to make sure I understand all the potential here.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, again, I think we want to be careful that we have looked at everything and have evaluated things, again with the real focus on highlighting that value and optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership. So again, I think -- as we suggeste
componenttext: Yes, I mean, again, I think we want to be careful that we have looked at everything and have evaluated things, again with the real focus on highlighting that value and optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership. So again, I think -- as we suggested this is an evaluation that we'll undertake over the course of the next several months. And again, it could include things like a buying of the IDRs, it could include a partial public sale of the GP, it could include some restructuring of the GP interest or the IDRs. Again, we want to be careful that we evaluate everything. We will look at everything and pursue the path that we think makes the most sense relative to those objectives.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And along those lines, you mentioned in the strategic plan, optimizing the cost of capital for MPLX, which presumably applies to the GP and the IDRs, et cetera. Is there an ideal cost of capital that you would plan to have there, both pre and post the $1.
componenttext: And along those lines, you mentioned in the strategic plan, optimizing the cost of capital for MPLX, which presumably applies to the GP and the IDRs, et cetera. Is there an ideal cost of capital that you would plan to have there, both pre and post the $1.3 billion of drop-downs?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't know if there's a specific number Roger that we focus on. But as Don alluded to earlier, we've been generally unhappy with where the units have traded at the LP level. And certainly, as the partnership moved into the high splits and certainl
componenttext: Well, I don't know if there's a specific number Roger that we focus on. But as Don alluded to earlier, we've been generally unhappy with where the units have traded at the LP level. And certainly, as the partnership moved into the high splits and certainly with the addition of MarkWest, we know that the IDR burden on the partnership is significant, and obviously impacts the level of growth and things that we can pursue. So I think a focus around things that will improve both in terms of the LP yield and where things are at as well as again ways to optimize the cost of capital for the over partnership given the cash requirements that the IDRs bring are part of exactly what we're going to look at here.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then my last question, just as a follow-up of all of that. Presumably, the majority of the capital raised from the drop-downs, we should expect goes towards what share repose, paying down debt, combination of the two?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it all sort of come into the total. I mean, I think for the extent that, again, we're comfortable with the liquidity position of the company and we've got cash beyond the needs, then share repurchase is high on our list. Debt pay down, I think we'll
componenttext: Well, it all sort of come into the total. I mean, I think for the extent that, again, we're comfortable with the liquidity position of the company and we've got cash beyond the needs, then share repurchase is high on our list. Debt pay down, I think we'll evaluate as we go forward. We did a little bit this quarter just to sort of calibrate the cap structure relative to the refining environment we've seen. But I would say the priority is probably more around share repurchase, and again, certainly, where the shares trade, we think there's a tremendous value there as well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Evan Calio from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is a follow-up to that last point. Accelerated drops would be a significant cash windfall. I mean, $1.4 times 9 is $12 billion before tax, before considering any GP potential monetization proceeds, which dwarf any capitalized cost referenced earlier to
componenttext: It is a follow-up to that last point. Accelerated drops would be a significant cash windfall. I mean, $1.4 times 9 is $12 billion before tax, before considering any GP potential monetization proceeds, which dwarf any capitalized cost referenced earlier today. I mean, shouldn't we assume that most of that's going to support a buyback. I mean, given your history, given your impetus for announcing today's actions that your equity is undervalued? And secondly, if drops are on the come, would you buy shares, use the balance sheet before they occur, like in the 4Q, I mean, your stock is down 5% today. And I know you didn't acquire much in the third quarter. And with that size of monetization, you have a lot of shares to put away potentially.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're right to the extent that there are big cash proceeds that ultimately come back either from equity or debt that you raise through the drop process there. Share purchase continues to be a priority for us in terms of where that money get
componenttext: Well, I think you're right to the extent that there are big cash proceeds that ultimately come back either from equity or debt that you raise through the drop process there. Share purchase continues to be a priority for us in terms of where that money gets spent. Again, our focus is I think primarily and starts with the notion that the value hasn't been recognized. So we want to make sure that, that value recognition occurs, and to the extent that produces cash at MPC level, that can be used for share buyback, all the better. Again, provided that we've done that tax efficiently and managed it relative to the total needs of the enterprise. But I think the notion that a substantial portion could take the form of share purchase is not unreasonable.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe somewhat of a follow-up to that and to prior questions on taking back equity as well as, I guess, your theory in terms of how this would be recognized by the market. But you mentioned dropping as soon as practicable, and then you drop, I know you de
componenttext: Maybe somewhat of a follow-up to that and to prior questions on taking back equity as well as, I guess, your theory in terms of how this would be recognized by the market. But you mentioned dropping as soon as practicable, and then you drop, I know you defined drops per year. I mean, so is the limiting factor on the pace that you selected here, the capital markets, the equity capital markets for MPLX. So meaning, your actual drop-down pace could be faster if access or market depth or counterparty side proves to be greater? And secondly, that your goal is really to sell units for cash, right, because that's what compresses your multiple, and that's ultimately in my opinion what forces an unlock of value versus potentially taking back units. So what's the limiting factor -- what is the limiting factor to the pace, and I guess, as your goal to optimize those -- the equity?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think our goal will definitely to be optimize. The market capacity to absorb transaction is certainly a consideration among others that we've evaluated. But again, Evan, this is really a look as to -- obviously there's a piece of the drop-d
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think our goal will definitely to be optimize. The market capacity to absorb transaction is certainly a consideration among others that we've evaluated. But again, Evan, this is really a look as to -- obviously there's a piece of the drop-down portfolio that we're just not going to get comfortable with until we can get through the QI regs and a PLR round.  So let's set those aside for a moment. The remaining piece, we're moving pretty aggressively here. We are talking about dropping down up to half of those and setting a schedule for the remaining pieces, again, provided that we can get tax comfort on the rest at a pretty good clip. I think the considerations around it, it certainly involved market capacity to absorb larger transaction, but also just in terms of the pace and the capacity to manage the growth of the partnership and making sure that we can optimize that total sort of equation with regard to how fast we build the partnership at the LP level and ultimately the cash flow that comes to the GP as well. So again, I think we are moving very aggressively here. I think we're -- there are still certainly pieces of the drop portfolio that we will need to spend some time on the readiness for, but they are all, from my perspective, likely going to be part of MPLX and we're moving very rapidly on it. So I think this is an aggressive schedule. I mean, even the drop that we've suggested for first quarter would the largest transaction for MPLX in its history. And again, we recognize that, that value is not getting picked up and this increased clarity on the drop portfolio and when it comes in, we think that help address that valuation gap.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just maybe one more if I would. I mean, in terms of your statement of taking back in, it's in conjunction with the drop. I mean, is that just a pragmatic statement that if that's what's necessary to fund? And I realized there is a debt piece that prov
componenttext: And just maybe one more if I would. I mean, in terms of your statement of taking back in, it's in conjunction with the drop. I mean, is that just a pragmatic statement that if that's what's necessary to fund? And I realized there is a debt piece that provides cash to the parent. I mean, is that statement essentially there, if that's necessary. I mean, what's -- or is it a goal to take, I guess units back, that's what I'm trying to get to.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't call it a goal. I would say that we want to be mindful of the markets capacity to absorb transactions and where we can efficiently raise that capital, I think we would be inclined to do so. We have the flexibility to take back units to help all
componenttext: I wouldn't call it a goal. I would say that we want to be mindful of the markets capacity to absorb transactions and where we can efficiently raise that capital, I think we would be inclined to do so. We have the flexibility to take back units to help alleviate any of those issues. And again, we'll manage it prudently as we go here.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Big source of cash.
componenttext: Big source of cash.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Evan, this is Don. I mean, just one more comment on that. Historically, we managed tax leakage by taking back units, so that was 1 aspect of it. And the other is, we are a substantial holder of MPLX units. So the value in the MPLX units, we want to make s
componenttext: Evan, this is Don. I mean, just one more comment on that. Historically, we managed tax leakage by taking back units, so that was 1 aspect of it. And the other is, we are a substantial holder of MPLX units. So the value in the MPLX units, we want to make sure that we're not doing anything in the market that puts an overhang on those units that causes the value of our investment to decrease. So those are all things that get into the consideration.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: And our final question comes from Paul Sankey from Wolfe Research.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, having said all that, I am still a little bit perplexed by the timing here. If I look at the MPC share price or even the MPLX share price, they do not look that troubled. I mean, I'm sure you would want them higher, but I'm still not clear why we
componenttext: I guess, having said all that, I am still a little bit perplexed by the timing here. If I look at the MPC share price or even the MPLX share price, they do not look that troubled. I mean, I'm sure you would want them higher, but I'm still not clear why we have to have this announcement right here, right now. Could just remind me why you decided that now is the moment that this needs to announced?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, we've -- as I said earlier in my comments that the first 9 months or so, we've worked very hard at getting the MarkWest transition in place. Really working with the producers. MarkWest had an outstanding reputation in the producers' field. So meetin
componenttext: Paul, we've -- as I said earlier in my comments that the first 9 months or so, we've worked very hard at getting the MarkWest transition in place. Really working with the producers. MarkWest had an outstanding reputation in the producers' field. So meeting with producers and really, as I say, getting these assets under wraps. But then as you step back and look at how MPLX has performed and how the value has really been transparent or we believe lack of transparency of that value back into MPC and the value to MPLX as well, that we felt it was important to really take a bold move here to increase the drop-downs, increase the pace of the drop-downs, but it's a very bold move around this to reflect -- in an attempt to reflect what we believe there is substantial value that is tied up inside of both components.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Gary, basically, I'm stating, obviously apologies, but do you see this as a major change in the strategy that is a much more aggressive drop-down outlook, and you felt the need to announce it right here, right now?
componenttext: So Gary, basically, I'm stating, obviously apologies, but do you see this as a major change in the strategy that is a much more aggressive drop-down outlook, and you felt the need to announce it right here, right now?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And Paul, you take it back to prior to MarkWest, our strategy was to be a company-sponsored MLP, and all we had were drop-down components and a few organic projects.At the time that we did MarkWest, we stated that we looked out into the future an
componenttext:
Right. And Paul, you take it back to prior to MarkWest, our strategy was to be a company-sponsored MLP, and all we had were drop-down components and a few organic projects.
At the time that we did MarkWest, we stated that we looked out into the future and could easily see that the rate of drop-downs from a sponsored MLP was not infinite. And as you get out over time, it was going to be much more difficult, and at that same time, the pressure from others in the marketplace of attempting to be able to find growth opportunities was going to continue to be challenging. That's why we did the merger with MarkWest to begin with. We've been very pleased with the assets. Don has talked about the rate of growth, the volumetric increases and the gathering and processing business is very solid as well as the logistics, the storage business that we have as well. But still, we were not seeing that value transferred in the yield component of MPLX. And in talking to a number of unitholders, they wanted to have a better understanding of the rhythm of how we were going to drop-down assets, and we felt that at this time it was again, after getting all this under our belt, we felt it's compelling that we needed to move forward back in line with where we said we would grow, kind of middle double-digits where we said we were growing when we first started the discussion on the merger to begin with.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I get it, and I know we are over the ebb. Can I just change subjects and ask you about the dreaded RIN thing. You have highlighted a cost here in the course by you guys, but I get the sense there's a slight difference of view among refiners as to what sho
componenttext: I get it, and I know we are over the ebb. Can I just change subjects and ask you about the dreaded RIN thing. You have highlighted a cost here in the course by you guys, but I get the sense there's a slight difference of view among refiners as to what should be done next. Could you just first talk about what you anticipate to happen at the end of November, if anything? And then, secondly, talk about how you view the issue -- the way the issue should be resolved?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well I don't know that anything is going to happen at the end of November, Paul. But our -- we've said for quite some time and I know you have reported it as well, that we believe how Marathon is positioned. We have the optionality, the flexibility
componenttext: Right. Well I don't know that anything is going to happen at the end of November, Paul. But our -- we've said for quite some time and I know you have reported it as well, that we believe how Marathon is positioned. We have the optionality, the flexibility and with our retail component, our branded component and our very large blending component as well as some methanol production capacity, we have the ability to capture RIN value, and probably more so to lessen the cost of RIN value across all those different components of our business. To change, the point of obligation, we think that is fraught with many ramifications. Today you have a, I don't know, probably the number is less than 50 of refiners and big blenders who are managing, really step back and look at this. We're managing the whole RIN cycle for the EPA today. If we're going to go put this into the hands of 150,000 people, just consider what those ramifications are. We believe the RIN cost is captured in part of the crack spread today. And part of it's in retail, part of it's in blending. So we just think that changing the point of obligation is a bigger distraction.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Audio Gap]lower income taxes and higher income contributed by our Midstream segment. Turning to Slide 6, our Refining & Marketing segment reported income from operations of $306 million in the third quarter 2016, compared with $1.4 billion in the sam
componenttext:
[Audio Gap]
lower income taxes and higher income contributed by our Midstream segment. 
Turning to Slide 6, our Refining & Marketing segment reported income from operations of $306 million in the third quarter 2016, compared with $1.4 billion in the same quarter last year. The decrease was primarily due to weaker crack spreads in both the Gulf Coast and Chicago, and less favorable product price realizations compared to the LLS base crack spread. The lower blended crack spread had a negative impact on earnings of approximately $711 million. The blended crack spread was $4.10 per barrel lower at 808 per barrel in the third quarter compared to $12.18 per barrel for the same period last year.
There were 4 primary contributors to the $463 million unfavorable other gross margin brands in this walk. First, we experienced narrower gasoline and diesel price realizations versus the reported market metric LLS base crack spread in the third quarter of '16 compared to the same quarter last year. Second, our price realizations were negatively impacted by less favorable margins on non-transportation products, which include the asphalt. Asphalt realizations were exceptionally strong in the third quarter 2015, and have not increased at the same rate as the rise in the price of crude. Third, as I mentioned, we experienced weaker crack spreads during the quarter. At the same time, our outright RIN purchase cost more than doubled when compared to the third quarter of 2015. Our cost of purchase RINs to comply with the RFS standards was $80 million this quarter. Finally, refinery volume metric gains also continue to be lower this quarter due to the lower commodity price environment we're in. R&M segment income benefited $79 million by an approximately $0.40 per barrel widening of the sweet/sour differential as well as higher severance in the quarter versus the same quarter last year. The LLS-WTI differential narrowed by $2.14 per barrel from $3.72 per barrel in the third quarter of '15 to a $1.58 per barrel in this third quarter.
This had a negative impact on earnings of about $69 million based on the WTI-linked crudes in our slate. The market structure or contango effect during the quarter is reflected in the $32 million favorable variance on the walk and relates to the difference between the prompt crude prices we used for market metrics and the actual crude acquisition cost in the quarter. The $35 million year-over-year increase in direct operating cost relate primarily to higher turnaround activity in the quarter versus last year. Turnaround and major maintenance cost increased $0.25 per barrel or over $46 million compared to the third quarter of 2015.
Moving to our other segments. Slide 7 provides the Speedway segment earnings walk compared to the same quarter last year. Speedway's income was down $34 million compared to the third quarter of 2016, primarily driven by lower light product margins. Gasoline and distillate margins were $0.177 per gallon in the third quarter of 2016, which was $0.37 lower than the third quarter of 2015, which is a period of very strong margins. On a sequential basis, light product margin was $0.022 per gallon higher than second quarter 2016.
Partially offsetting lower fuel margins, were higher gasoline and distillate sales volumes and higher merchandised margins. Gasoline and distillate sales volumes were up 20 million gallons over the same quarter last year. On a same-store basis, gasoline volumes decreased 0.6% over the same period last year. Our focus continues to be on optimizing total gasoline contributions between volume and margin to ensure fuel margins remain adequate.
Increasing merchandise sales continue to be a focus, the results of which can be seen in the $28 million increase in Speedway's merchandised gross margin compared to third quarter of 2015.
Merchandise margins increased due to higher overall merchandise sales as well as higher margins realized on those sales. Merchandise sales in the quarter, excluding cigarettes, increased 4% on a same-store year-over-year basis. In October, we've seen a decrease in gasoline demand, is approximately 4% decrease in same-store gasoline sales volumes compared to last October. The decrease we expect to be temporary and largely reflects the impacts of Hurricane Matthew on approximately 500 Speedway locations.
Slide 8 provides the changes in the Midstream segment income versus the third quarter last year. The $165 million increase quarter-over-quarter was primarily due to the combination with MarkWest at the end of last year, which contributed a $121 million of incremental segment income to the quarter.
The remaining increase of $44 million was primarily due to an increase in income from our equity affiliates and lower operating expenses versus the third quarter last year. 
Slide 9 presents the significant elements of changes in our consolidated cash position for the third quarter. Cash at the end of the quarter was just over $700 million. Core operating cash flow was a $1.1 billion source of cash. The $666 million use of working capital noted on the slide, primarily relates to a decrease in accounts payable and accrued liabilities and an increase in crude and refined products inventory levels during the quarter. The decrease in accounts payable and accrued liabilities was primarily due to the lower crude prices and volumes as well as timing of tax payments. Given the weaker refining margins we've seen this year, we took the opportunity to selectively prepay some of our debt during the quarter, which is reflected in the $516 million of net debt cash outflow shown in the walk.
MPLX opportunistically issued equity through it's ATM program during the quarter with net proceeds of $184 million as shown on the walk. Return of capital during the quarter included share repurchase of $51 million and dividends of $190 million. During the third quarter, we increased our dividend 12.5% or $0.36 per share. We have increased our dividend 6 times since becoming a standalone company 5 years ago, resulting in a 28% compound annual growth rate on the dividend. Our continued focus on growing regular quarterly dividends demonstrates our ongoing strategy to share in the success of the business with our shareholders and this dividend increase just reaffirms that strategy.
Slide 10 provides an overview of our capitalization and financial profile at the end of the quarter. We had $10.6 billion of total consolidated debt including $4.4 billion of debt at MPLX. Total debt to book capitalization was about 34%, and represented 2.3x last 12 months pro forma adjusted EBITDA on a consolidated basis or about 1.8x if we exclude MPLX. We're showing the metric without MPLX since the debt is nonrecourse MPC and MPLX will maintain a capital structure, which uses relatively higher leverage, making consolidated debt-to-EBITDA increasingly less useful given the size and continued growth of the partnership. 
Slide 11 provides updated outlook information on key operating metrics for MPC for the fourth quarter 2016. We're expecting fourth quarter throughput volumes to be down slightly compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, due to more planned maintenance in the quarter. Total direct operating cost is expected to be $8.05 per barrel on total throughput of 1.83 million barrels per day. Beginning this quarter, we're also providing our estimated percentage of sour crude throughput, which we expect to be 58% in the fourth quarter due to the continued sour crude advantage.
Our projected fourth quarter corporate and other unallocated items are estimated at $75 million.
With that, let me turn the call back over to Lisa. Lisa?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you provide some early flavor as it relates to some of the strategic changes that you talked about drop-downs to GP structure and some of the accounting changes? And then, talk about how retail fits into it, if at all?
componenttext: Gary, can you provide some early flavor as it relates to some of the strategic changes that you talked about drop-downs to GP structure and some of the accounting changes? And then, talk about how retail fits into it, if at all?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure Niel. As we -- in our separate release this morning, we have been working on this for quite some time on -- we spent the early part of the year in the transition to get MarkWest into the fold and to really get our businesses lined out. And then, real
componenttext: Sure Niel. As we -- in our separate release this morning, we have been working on this for quite some time on -- we spent the early part of the year in the transition to get MarkWest into the fold and to really get our businesses lined out. And then, really focused on what is the proper growth strategy and how do we -- we have tremendous portfolio of assets that can be considered over time to be drop-down. And we felt that it was the best to get into a very aggressive strong rhythm on how to drop-down the assets that we have. It's not just a drop-down strategy Niel, we expect to be acquisitive in certain markets where it makes sense for the Midstream as well as we have a very good organic suite of projects to work on. But as we step back and looked at our total Midstream business, we felt that now is the time to take this very bold, aggressive action. And then -- we have also stated, not just the drop-downs for 2017, of approximately $350 million, but we're also then are talking about the future drop-down strategy of the approximate $1 billion of other assets. Let me be specific about that $1 billion of other assets. As you know, Neil, you and I talked about this many times. We have a significant portion of those assets under the fuels distribution piece, that we have a private letter ruling request into the IRS. So we have to be careful and make sure we don't have any potential tax liability of dropping those down sooner than -- that we would believe we have approval from the IRS. An additional thing that we highlighted, the value of the general partner interest, let me have Tim talk about some of the actions and the aspects that we would have around looking at the general partner interest.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neil, as we sort of outlined, I think the key for us is that we have -- we've seen pretty clearly that the value of the GP is not being fully recognized in the value of MPC. So I think we want to take a careful but aggressive look at exactly ways tha
componenttext: Yes, Neil, as we sort of outlined, I think the key for us is that we have -- we've seen pretty clearly that the value of the GP is not being fully recognized in the value of MPC. So I think we want to take a careful but aggressive look at exactly ways that we can highlight that value, capture it and optimize the cost to capital for the partnership. So again, I would say that we really want to look at everything. There is no preconceived notion or conclusions as to where ultimately this may lead us. Again with that objective of highlighting that value and optimizing the cost of capital for the partnership, it could include things like a buy-in of the IDR's at the partnership level, public sale of some portion of the GP, other alternatives around restructuring the GP interest. Again, we want to make sure that we're going to look at everything and make sure that we understand what might be the best path to really have that value better reflected in the overall valuation of MPC.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, to your question on Speedway. We've talked many times about Speedway as well, you and other sell-side analysts have discussed this, how important Speedway is, along with the Midstream in trying to balance our cash flow across all cycles. And we real
componenttext: Neil, to your question on Speedway. We've talked many times about Speedway as well, you and other sell-side analysts have discussed this, how important Speedway is, along with the Midstream in trying to balance our cash flow across all cycles. And we really believe that significant portion of the discount in our share prize today really is reflected in the Midstream space. And Speedway is not the catalyst or the driver. Speedway is continuing to perform very, very well as indicated again, and the performance for this quarter. So we look at the integration value, we look at kind of the dyssynergy if we were to do something different with Speedway and we still believe that it has a very strong fit in our system.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, my follow-up here is that, you cited 4 reasons that other gross margins were under pressure, narrow gasoline and diesel, the nontransportation products, RINs, and I believe, volume metric gains. How much of that is a third quarter phenomena here as
componenttext: Gary, my follow-up here is that, you cited 4 reasons that other gross margins were under pressure, narrow gasoline and diesel, the nontransportation products, RINs, and I believe, volume metric gains. How much of that is a third quarter phenomena here as opposed to a recurring point? And I guess, the reason I'm going here is that, when I think about MPC's portfolio, historically, you guys have outperformed your indicator margins by taking advantage of the logistics in the infrastructure advantages that you guys have. I want to make sure that's going to be a recurring advantage for MPC on a go-forward basis.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, you are spot-on there with the outcome. Let's go back and look at the third quarter of '16 versus the third quarter of '15. Third quarter of '15 had a rapid drop in the price of crude. And when you have that, you're able to retain margins in all asp
componenttext: Neil, you are spot-on there with the outcome. Let's go back and look at the third quarter of '16 versus the third quarter of '15. Third quarter of '15 had a rapid drop in the price of crude. And when you have that, you're able to retain margins in all aspects of our business and all the way through asphalt. Asphalt was one of the major contributors to our third quarter last year. This year, when we started to see a steady climb in crude prices and with some of the problems that you had in the third quarter, [indiscernible] at Colonial, while sometimes a dislocation in markets, such has happened with Colonial, sometimes you recognize different pockets of the country and we're able to capture some of that value through the logistics arm that we have. That did not happen with that downturn, and in fact it backed product, back into the Gulf Coast, and in fact, backed products for the West. On top of that, we spent a lot of incremental money in order to be able to service our customers and keep our customers full during that period of time. So that was a phenomena, but it really -- Tim mentioned the gas and diesel prices -- the price realization, but it really got into the bottom components and asphalt was a big marker that was held as well. So I would say, those are the big things. I would say they are non -- expect them to be nonrecurring, kind of a follow on to that here, early in the fourth quarter, with Hurricane Matthew, that had an upset across the entire Gulf Coast, some don't think about the tropical storm Hermine that hit in the third quarter. That had an affect as well. When you lose that volume from these tropical storms, it's gone. So all those effects -- all those things affected the third quarter and some into the fourth quarter, but I would expect that they would be nonrecurring.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Westlake from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
